PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will leave Australia today to attend the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development meetings in Washington DC. He will be also having discussions in London, Frankfurt and Paris. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) will act as Treasurer until Mr Keating returns. I inform the Senate also that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) will leave Australia today to attend discussions in Rome with Italian political leaders and the Director-General of the Sinai Multinational Force and Observers. The Foreign Minister will then travel to New York for ministerial discussions and to address the United Nations General Assembly. The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) will act as Minister for Foreign Affairs until Mr Hayden returns.

PETITION.TITLE: Asbestos: Narrabundah College, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Asbestos: Narrabundah College, Australian Capital Territory
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Australian Capital Territory respectfully showeth:

The students of Narrabundah College condemn the interruption of their educational program and want the asbestos contained and areas decontaminated as soon as possible to allow classes to recommence with the assurance that the asbestos will be removed at a later date.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Abortion
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That any attempt to restrict the payment of medical benefits for abortions will result in:
(a) An increase in backyard abortionists and subsequent increased risk of infection and death.
(b) An increase in self-induced abortions which may result in failure to abort and possible birth of a severely damaged child.
(c) Failure of the mother to obtain necessary counselling prior to a decision to have an abortion.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
1. Make no alteration to the Medical Benefits Schedule with regard to abortions and
2. Seek to give women the right to decide whether or not to have an abortion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Returned Soldiers: Commonwealth Public Service Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Public Service Act, section 47A (3) be amended.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:

Amend the Act, so as to safeguard returned servicemen from dismissal from the Service on medical grounds, who are not free from physical defects due to Service in a war, or any other service, by virtue of which they are returned soldiers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef: Oil Exploration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 provided that a precisely defined area, which included the coastal low water line, called The Great Barrier Reef Region should be proclaimed a marine park in which mining and oil drilling specifically would be prohibited and that management plans would be prepared for each zone, allowing for normal uses consistent with the preservation of the natural environment.

Only a small percentage of the area has so far been proclaimed and in the Cairns section a 5km wide region for most of the coastline has been excluded. This seems to provide an opportunity for oil drilling and beach mining (causing silting) to take place. We fear that the granting of mining or drilling leases or other harmful developments, here or in the rest of The Great Barrier Reef Region may prevent the object of the Act from being achieved. We believe that most citizens share our fears.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that The Senate in Parliament assembled, should request The Government to take action so that a referendum will be held with the next Federal Elections on the question that the entire Great Barrier Reef Region be immediately declared a Marine Park as defined in and provided by The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 and amended 1978 which included the coastal low water line.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
i. a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
ii. subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
iii. farmer unrest at seed prices,
iv. monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also making crop chemicals,
v. increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Grape Spirit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the 1983 Budget imposition of the excise on grape spirit used in fortifying wine places at risk the future of the fortified wine industry in Australia.
That the requirement to pay the excise within seven days of the fortification occurring is inequitable.
That the excise will be reflected in increased costs to the consumers of fortified wines of up to 100 per cent and consumer choice will be restricted.
That this will cause reduced fortified wine sales which will result in reduced intake of grapes from grapegrowers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will reconsider their previous decision and either withdraw this tax or modify its method of application and collection.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President, and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State', and whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1)
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in-
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Mason (from 211 citizens) and Richardson (from two citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Scheyville Airport, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region, commonly called Scheyville, imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to RAAF Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the members of the Women's Services of the 1939-45 War not at present considered eligible for Defence Service Home Loans should qualify as 'Australian Soldiers' under the Defence Service Homes Act. They volunteered for service with the Naval, Military and Air Forces, serving wherever they were sent in whatever capacity they were required and yet are refused Defence Service Home Loans.

They took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies which meant to fight His Majesty's enemies, and although not used in actual combat in war zones, they were available for that use and had a sufficiently grave need arisen would have been used, to serve with distinction as have women of other lands.

In accordance with the Acts and Regulations of the period, the women of the Military Forces had enlisted for service anywhere, some of the Naval women to sail in any waters, others with service on warships optional, while the women of the Airforce could have been sent to Papua New Guinea or other territories under the control or care of Australia.

Ex-servicemen of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force who volunteered in the 1939-45 War but were not sent to War Zones are granted home loans. Not to grant eligibility to all Ex- servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you favourably consider amending the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Peter Rae proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The adverse impact on employment of the Government's broken promises and the total confusion caused by this divided Government's public disarray over its manufacturing industry policy.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

That, unless otherwise ordered, consideration of the matter of public importance be postponed until after the consideration of Government Business, Orders of the Day Nos. 1 to 4, health legislation package.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 21 September 1983.
Clauses 31 to 39.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was in midstream with my speech on this matter before it was adjourned. I refer to the situation which has arisen between the Commonwealth and Tasmania with regard to the State's tax sharing and health grants provisions. Yesterday, during the debate in the Committee stage, I outlined from the correspondence the very clear dispute about and difference of interpretation which has arisen between the Minister for Health in Tasmania and the Federal Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and between the Tasmanian Premier and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The provision to which I referred, in particular, was section 23 of the States Tax Sharing and Health Grants Act which provides:

SPEECH.PARA: If, at any time before 1 July 1985, . . . the Premier of Tasmania--
I leave out the irrelevant parts-
elects, by writing under his hand furnished to the Prime Minister-

they may terminate the cost sharing agreement. The emphasis which I place is in relation to the Premier electing, by writing under his hand furnished to the Prime Minister, that the agreement should terminate. There is clearly no such election. In fact, the correspondence which I have quoted makes it completely clear that the very reverse is the case. Tasmania has, at least since 13 July 1983, made it very clear that it has not agreed to any particular variation of its rights under an agreement formally and solemnly made between the Commonwealth and Tasmania. Quite clearly, if there is to be a revision of that agreement, if there is to be a change of the statutory provision, it is the obligation, I believe, certainly of this chamber to ensure that agreement has been reached. It is not our function, perhaps, to determine in any way what the terms of the variation ought to be, but to ensure that there has been agreement reached and that there is a meeting of the minds in relation to it are the clear obligations.

Clause 38 of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill provides for the repeal of the section in the principal legislation which provides for cost sharing agreements. At this stage we seek to have clause 38 deferred to enable there to be time for the Federal Minister for Health and the State Minister for Health to come together on this matter and for the very reasonable requests of the State Minister to be answered. I reiterate that on 13 July the State Minister said:

. . . I must express my dissatisfaction at the lack of detail provided to date to enable this State to make an informed judgment as to whether or not it should remain under cost-sharing arrangements . . .
Therefore, I request that you give these matters your urgent attention. Clarification is vital . . . before any final decision can be made.

As recently as 15 September the Premier of Tasmania, in a letter to the Prime Minister which I understand is as yet unanswered, repeated that request, making it quite clear that to this stage no agreement has been reached. It would be monstrous, I believe, for the Senate to pass legislation which terminates, not in accordance with the provisions of existing legislation but by an arbitrary overriding of the terms, the agreement made between the Commonwealth and the State of Tasmania. For that reason, I move:
That consideration of clause 38 be postponed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Rae , in some ways not unreasonably, suggested that this chamber should ensure that an agreement is reached between the Tasmanian Government and the Federal Government, although he pointed out that it was not necessarily our job to work out just what the details of that agreement should be. I put it to Senator Peter Rae that that is not an easy thing to do when his colleagues the Premier of Tasmania and the Minister for Health, Mr Cleary, are involved. I think we should go through in steps what has happened to find out what this is all about. At the end of the Premiers Conference a communique was issued on behalf of the heads of government. It was issued with the agreement of the heads of government and those heads of government included the Tasmanian Premier. The communique stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The heads of government agreed on the revised proposals for Medicare as outlined by the Minister for Health in Premiers' Conference, including the basis for compensation payments to each of the States as outlined by the Minister . . .
The document referred to in that communique is in fact the Medicare program financial proposals by the Commonwealth dated 30 June 1983 and circulated at the Premiers Conference. That document stated:

South Australia and Tasmania to be reimbursed for both in-patient and out- patient revenue losses on the basis of existing cost-sharing agreements being terminated, and their replacement by identified health grants equal in value to the cost-sharing grants applicable at 1 February 1984; plus revenue loss adjustments . . .

The Premier of Tasmania signed the communique, agreed to the communique and made no objection to it. Senator Walters told us that he signed it only because he had had a yarn to Paul Keating in the corridor and Paul Keating had told him that it would be all right. Quite frankly, if she is really suggesting that the Premier of Tasmania signs communiques between governments at Premiers conferences on that basis, I think the people of Tasmania ought to have a look at whom they have as Premier. What Senator Walters said is clear nonsense. The Premier signed the document and, as far as the Commonwealth and everyone at the Premiers Conference were concerned, the communique was agreed to.

The Tasmanian Minister for Health, Mr Cleary, then attended a conference of Australian Health Ministers in Sydney on 14 July 1983. At that conference, he pointed out that he was at the Premiers Conference and that what was agreed to at the Premiers Conference was the broad concept; that he was present at the Conference when his Premier agreed to the final communique and the cost sharing agreement being terminated and replaced by identified health grants equal in value to the cost sharing grants applicable at 1 February, plus the revenue loss adjustment. The meeting of the Health Ministers in Sydney was held to clarify the details of that situation. The Federal Health Minister has always recognised -Senator Rae will see this if he reads the letter of 28 July-that there were matters of detail to be settled and he has offered discussions between officers and discussions between himself and the State Minister to work out these details . But what we have had from the Tasmanian Minister ever since is a shopping list of new claims which are, as the Minister for Health said in his last letter, peripheral to and outside the Medicare arrangements. It may be good politics to play this game of adding a shopping list which includes things like the Launceston general hospital and anything else Tasmania can think of to add to the negotiations when it knows we are trying to introduce Medicare and to get a smooth transition. It may be good politics; it may even be considered smart politics for home consumption down there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you like to identify the letter in which the alleged shopping list is contained?
—The honourable senator has a whole series of letters that keep adding new claims all the time, but I will get them out for him in a moment. I quote the Premier of Tasmania:

SPEECH.PARA: A significant change will take place this financial year with the introduction of the Commonwealth's Medicare program. This will come into effect from 1 February 1984 and from that date no charges will be levied on inpatients or outpatients receiving treatment as public patients in public hospitals.

That, I would have thought, was a pretty definite statement that something was going to happen, that the Premier knew something was going to happen and that he knew he was part of what was going to happen. That statement happens to have come from his Budget Speech to the Tasmanian Parliament. So we have the situation of the Premier of Tasmania signing the communique which says there is to be agreement, he talks in his Budget Speech as though the whole thing is a fait accompli and that in fact Medicare is coming in and will affect the State in that way. Yet we have this continuous sniping between Mr Gray and the Federal Minister for Health in all that time. The Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, wrote again, on 20 September, to Mr Cleary. It is a letter that I assume Senator Rae and the others do not have.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably a letter that the Premier of Tasmania has not got because of the postal situation.
—It could be, Senator Harradine. I think the sensible thing to do is to table that letter and let the people in this place read it. I seek leave to table the letter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, may I clarify something? Can we defer consideration of clause 38 until after the Minister has finished speaking so that we can get a copy of the letter and consider it?
—For how long?
—Just while the other clauses are dealt with.
—Yes, we can defer consideration of that clause while other clauses are being dealt with so that you can have a read of the letter.
—Mr Chairman, I seek some guidance on procedure. I take it we are talking about clause 38 but the Committee is considering clauses 31 to 39 .
—The Committee has agreed that clauses 31 to 39 be taken together.
—Would it not be appropriate to dispose of clauses 31 through 37? I understand from what Senator Grimes has just said that he would be happy to defer consideration of clause 38 for a few moments.
—I will stretch it a bit further than that.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 38 postponed.
Clauses 31 to 37-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 39 agreed to.
Clause 40 (Daily bed payments).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 25, clause 40, proposed new sub-section 33 (1), line 30, leave out '12', insert '8'.

This clause repeals existing section 33 of the principal Act and inserts a new section 33 which provides for the making of daily bed payments by the Commonwealth to the proprietors of private hospitals. Sub-section 1 of the proposed new section provides for a daily bed payment to be made to the proprietor of an approved hospital for each day on which an eligible person is an in-patient for a period of more than 12 hours. The difficulty that has arisen is that some feel that there are people who should qualify for a daily bed payment for admissions of less than 12 hours.

I will not rehearse all the arguments; I will just bring out one obvious example. Those of us who are medical practitioners know that when a woman is required to go to hospital for a diagnostic curettage the usual arrangement is that she is admitted in the morning and discharged some hours later-whatever the appropriate time is, say eight or nine hours later. That is an arrangement that is appropriate for the procedure. The procedures are necessary and if this 12- hour period stood-I have only used that one example; many others could be used- all that would happen is that the hospitals would modify their behaviour and people would be held until they had been in hospital for a sufficient time to qualify for the benefit. I do not think it is the intention of this proposed new sub-section to exclude people going into hospital for that kind of diagnostic test from getting a daily bed payment. They require to be admitted; they require the services of the hospital.

The amendment which we are proposing is one which we think will try to meet the Government's purposes, but sets a more realistic figure for the minimum stay. We have suggested that the eight-hour figure is appropriate. The 12-hour figure, I understand, was determined without what the major private hospital groups thought was appropriate consultation. Many groups would think that the period should be even less than eight hours, but the Opposition's view is that it represents a reasonable length of time to protect the public interest and that the 12-hour period, on reflection, is unduly long. The amendment that we have proposed is reasonable and I hope one to which the Committee will agree.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share, as does my Party, Senator Peter Baume's concern about the definition of a day as being 12 hours. As I indicated in my speech during the second reading debate we believe that this would inadvertently-I am sure quite unwittingly-and unnecessarily disadvantage quite a large number of people. People who go into hospital, for instance, for renal dialysis are required to take hospital based treatment that lasts somewhere between six and eight hours. It is a convenient form of getting their treatment for both them and their medical practitioner. Of course, in the long run, it is also cheaper for all concerned. In addition, patients suffering from cancer are admitted for blood transfusions and chemotherapy. Cardiac patients who are admitted to hospital for restoration of cardiac rhythm by electrical stimulation need to be monitored for some hours after receiving their treatment. Patients undergoing a wide range of surgical procedures, from general surgical procedures to gynaecological, paediatric and orthopaedic procedures, often spend less than 12 hours in hospital. We run into the situation that I think I mentioned briefly during my speech on the second reading of the Bill, in which children are admitted to hospital for what should be a non-overnight stay simply for their own benefit, and women with young families may go into hospital, for instance for a breast biopsy with a frozen section, may not want to stay overnight because it is not convenient. Yet they require some number of hours of treatment and oversight following that treatment.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that, given trends towards decreasing hospital stay for patients, a strict interpretation of a day for receipt of the bed day subsidy of 12 hours would unnecessarily go against this very improved trend in health care. We certainly support the removal of the figure '12' and its replacement with the figure '8', since we believe that a provision embodying eight hours will get over the problem of some patients being induced at some less ethical hospital- they are certainly in a minority-to stay for just over four hours. This would be of no inconvenience to them. But it is not going to launch us into the problems that are associated with a 12-hour stay requirement. We believe that eight hours is a reasonable compromise and we may even be able to reach that magical word ' consensus' on the issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The overwhelming clarity and lucidity of the arguments of the opposite parties have swayed us completely. We not only accept the amendment but also agree with it. It is a sensible amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 41 to 44-by leave-take together, and agreed to.
Clause 45 (Review of decisions).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has an amendment to clause 45. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 27, clause 45, proposed new paragraph 38 (1) (b), line 23, after 'sub- section', insert '18 (2) or'.

This clause inserts into the principal Act a new provision to provide that people who are affected by certain decisions may request the Minister for Health to reconsider a decision and to give them the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It is the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal that concerns us. The Committee will remember that last night we looked at the position of doctors with contracts between the doctors and hospitals. The Committee was not disposed to make certain matters in relation to those contracts subject to the approval of Parliament. That is one arm of the argument. The other arm of the argument is that the doctors who are affected should have a right of appeal through the route provided under this clause. As the clause is written, it does not include those doctors among the groups of people who would have a right of appeal.

The amendment which we propose, which is to insert the reference to section 18 (2), which deals with the contract, would confer upon those doctors a right of appeal. It would seem to us that that is an appropriate route to take. It is particularly appropriate in view of the Committee's decision last night not to take up the other possible issue of parliamentary approval. I commend to the Committee the amendment and the right of appeal which it will give to any doctor who may feel aggrieved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On this occasion I am afraid that we oppose this amendment. What we are talking about here are doctors' existing contracts which may not be in line with the guidelines. The clause in fact allows the Minister for Health to determine that contracts entered into before February 1984, which do not meet the guidelines, can be treated as approved agreements for a specified time. In other words, it is a transitional clause designed to allow the Minister's discretion to allow existing arrangements to continue until the new contract, if necessary, can be regularised. The contract may have been in existence for many years. The amendment will allow an appeal, against the Minister's decision in this transitional period, to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. We think this is completely unnecessary.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, representatives of the medical profession did not raise the matter at all in my discussions with them because they recognised that this clause was in fact a benefit to the medical profession. It is not a restriction; it is a benefit. It allows contracts which have been in existence for a considerable time to continue for a specified time. The clause gives the Minister the power to do this. Agreements could not be affirmed if the Minister did not have this capacity. The Minister has a discretion to allow a transitional period for appeals. If ever an appeal were likely, it is hard to imagine one having to trot off to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, with all the problems which arise from that. We think the amendment is absolutely unnecessary. We really think that the Opposition ought to think again before it pushes forward this sort of amendment.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be inserted (Senator Peter Baume's amendment) be inserted.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Chairman. I am really seeking your guidance on this matter. I am unable to point to the relevant standing order. I do not have time to sit down and go through the Standing Orders. Before that division was called I heard Senator Haines call: 'The ayes have it'. But Senator Haines voted against the clause. It seems to me that it is a fundamental principle in this place that a person must vote the way he or she calls. What has happened seems to me to be quite wrong. Senator Haines was the second person calling for the ayes. To have a division, two people must be calling for it. That is in the Standing Orders. Senator Haines was the second one. She quite clearly said: 'The ayes have it'. Mr Chairman, you said: 'Division required?' A division was called on the basis of Senator Haines and Senator Peter Baume calling for one. But in fact Senator Haines voted against the clause.

—Standing Order 170 requires each senator to vote in accordance with his voice. But this matter is a very difficult one for the Chairman to judge. I heard voices from the Opposition benches, from Senator Peter Baume in particular and from at least one other. I did not notice which way Senator Haines called, so I decline to rule on the question.
—Am I allowed to say anything, Mr Chairman?
—There is no need for you to say anything. You have been exonerated . But you are perfectly entitled to make an explanation, by leave, if you wish.

—by leave-Senator Peter Baume was aware that we were not supporting this clause. Indeed, I had sent you, Mr Chairman, a note saying that we would not be supporting it. If Senator Lewis thinks I said 'Aye', all I can say is that, at the end of four months of carrying on about Medicare, I am probably at the stage of saying just about anything.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —That explanation was not relevant to the point of order. Nevertheless, it has been heard.

INTERJECT.PARA: Clauses 46 to 48-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has an amendment to clause 49. The amendment has been circulated. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 29, clause 49, paragraph (1) (b), lines 8 and 9, leave out the paragraph.

Clause 49 relates to the Medical Benefits Advisory Committee which helps to advise the Government on the appropriate level of medical benefits. It is a matter which affects the Government. It also affects patients and doctors. I suppose, in industrial terms, it is a matter which affects their wages and conditions. Clause 49 (1) (b) proposes to amend the section so that the Minister no longer has to consult with the Australian Medical Association before appointing the medical practitioner members of that Committee. The Committee is important because of the advice it gives to the Minister on what should be in the schedule. It is only proper that those who will be directly affected should know that they will have some input.

The Opposition's amendment deletes the new provision. The deletion of the new provision means that the existing provision would stand. The existing provision provides that the Government should do certain things, including consulting with the Australian Medical Association before appointing the medical practitioner members of the Committee. Our concern is that a body which has the job of advising the Minister on the nature of the medical schedule of fees and the items to be on that schedule should include some of the people from the medical profession who will be directly affected and who are medical practitioners. The deletion which is proposed would maintain the status quo which in fact involves the Australian Medical Association being consulted.

If the Government's proposal in the Bill were to stand we would have the anomalous position where the Government would not be required to consult with the Australian Medical Association on the appointment of members of the Committee but would still be required to consult with the AMA on the filling of casual vacancies because that is provided for in another Bill and has not been included in what is before us. In terms of good sense and consistency I have moved this amendment on behalf of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to get it quite clearly on the record, Mr Chairman, I and other Australian Democrats are supporting the amendment moved by Senator Baume. Contingent on that clause being removed, the Australian Democrats will be moving our own amendment which will read:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 29, clause 49, after paragraph (a) insert the following paragraph:
''(b) by adding at the end of sub-section (2) the following words 'and such other organizations and associations as the Minister considers appropriate' ''.

I certainly share Senator Baume's concern that the largest group representing medical practitioners in this country should have been summarily removed from the consultation and discussion process. I wonder whether perhaps it would not be equally as appropriate, in an industrial relations or public relations exercise, for the opportunity to be given to the Minister to consult not only with the Australian Medical Association but also with other such organisations and associations as he considers appropriate. Is this an appropriate time for me to move my amendment, Mr Chairman?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not an appropriate time. Your amendment is dependent on Senator Peter Baume's amendment being agreed to.
—I foreshadow my amendment and undertake not to make another speech.
—Senator Haines, I will allow you to move your amendment without a further speech after Senator Baume's amendment has been dealt with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Senate wishes to amend this clause, and clearly it does, the Government certainly prefers the amendment foreshadowed by Senator Haines to the amendment moved by Senator Baume. The situation is simply this: In the past the medical practitioner members of this body have not only been selected by the Minister, in consultation with the Australian Medical Association-the Association has told the Minister who it wants and the Minister has then appointed them. We are of the view that the Australian Medical Association is not the only voice of the medical profession in this country. We are of the view that the Minister should, in fact, negotiate with not only the Australian Medical Association but also other medical organisations. Therefore, rather than specifically mention one group we thought it best to leave out a reference to that single organisation. We thought it best to remove the expectation of the Australian Medical Association that it would nominate the medical members of the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I have discussed this with representatives of the Australian Medical Association. I know how indignant they were that their name had been left out. I accept the fact, as Senator Peter Baume has pointed out to us, that somehow along the line the draftsmen have forgotten to pull out of the legislation the condition that the Australian Medical Association should be consulted about casual vacancies and it was a silly but minor mistake in the legislation. If the Minister intends to consult with the profession-and the Minister should and will consult with the profession-of course he should consult with the Australian Medical Association, but he should consult with other medical organisations also . As I have said to the Australian Medical Association, I think the time has come when the Australian Medical Association has to realise that it represents something like 55 per cent of doctors in the country and not 100 per cent, as it claims. The Association does not have the exclusive right to speak on behalf of the medical profession in this country; nor should it claim to have that exclusive right. All that our change to the legislation did was make it clear that we were going to negotiate not only with the Australian Medical Association but also with other medical organisations.

If the words 'Australian Medical Association' are to be put in the legislation, as Senator Peter Baume wishes, the sensible thing to do would be what Senator Haines has suggested and add 'and other organisations and associations which the Minister considers appropriate'. At one stage I thought of getting officers of the Department of Health to give me a list of all the medical organisations in this country so that I could add those to the legislation to point out how silly this sort of behaviour is. If we are to persist in this country-in a way in which the media no longer does, for instance-in assuming that the Australian Medical Association is the only voice of the medical profession in this country, Senator Peter Baume's approach is a good way to go about it. I can remember the days when the only comment one heard from the medical profession in this country was the comment on the news 'A spokesman for the AMA said'.

Then we received an anonymous statement from some anonymous person on behalf of the AMA. If the General Practitioners Society in Australia, which as everyone here knows does not share my political views, did anything in this country it was to stop that nonsense. At least the anonymous spokesman is now named. At least the anonymous spokesman now has a face. At least we have more sensible and open debate. That is as it should be and as it should continue. As I say, the Government will certainly accept the amendment as it will be amended eventually by Senator Haines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I make the point that we are not aiming to put anything into the legislation. We are aiming to have something that is in the legislation remain there. I suppose it is proper that I identify quite clearly for the Committee that I am a member of the Australian Medical Association and have been for many years. I would like that to be on the record.
—We'll forgive you.
—I thank Senator Grimes. I imagine that he may have been a member also at some time in his career. I think that should be on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 29, clause 49, after paragraph (a) insert the following paragraph:
'(b) by adding at the end of sub-section (2) the following words ''and such other organizations and associations as the Minister considers appropriate'' '.
I have moved this amendment for the reasons already stated and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the amendment moved by Senator Haines is sensible. The Opposition supports it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 50 to 56-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 57 (Prohibition of certain medical insurance).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This clause prohibits certain medical insurance activities. It is one of the matters to which the Opposition has objected. I wish to place that opposition on record. Our opposition remains. We will not carry the matter to a division.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 58 to 64-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 65 agreed to.
Clause 66 (Interpretation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clauses 66 and 67 contain amendments to the Health Insurance Act. They confer new functions upon the Health Insurance Commission. Our objections to these clauses were raised during the second reading debate. They are part of the package to which we are opposed. I wish to place that opposition on record.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 67.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 34, sub-clause 67 (1), at end of proposed new section 5, add the following new sub-section:

'(2) Nothing in sub-section (1) authorizes the Commission so to perform the functions referred to in that sub-section as to permit the issue of a Medicare card to a child in respect of whom the family allowance is paid without the authority of the child's parent or guardian, or of another person authorized by the child's parent or guardian to give such authority.'.

Last night, in my speech during the second reading debate, I gave notice that I would move a motion along these lines. Of course, that notice naturally gave the Government and the Opposition time to consider the ramifications of my proposal. Of course, the matter at issue is one about which there has been considerable Press speculation and about which, no doubt, honourable senators and members in the other place will have received correspondence from constituents. I considered what the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) said in replying to the second reading debate. He indicated that these matters had been canvassed in the Estimates committee. He reminded the Senate that Estimates Committee B had considered this matter. I have now amended the proposal which I intended to put forward last night to conform with the views of the officials at Estimates Committee B.

Honourable senators will recall that last night I argued that no Medicare card should be issued without the authority of the child's parent or guardian to a child who had not attained the age of 18. Quite clearly, in examining the Hansard record of Estimates Committee B, we learn that there are children who require to have cards made available to them. This includes children in institutions. In answer to a question about health care cards by Senator Walters during the hearings of Estimates Committee B, Mr MacMahon stated:
Children under the age of 16 are precluded from these cards--
that is, the health care cards-

if the parent is in receipt of family allowance for them. If the parent is not receiving family allowance for the child because he does not have the care, custody, control and maintenance of the child, that situation could be addressed by the issue of a card to the child if family allowance is not being paid for the child.

I propose that that which occurs under the existing system in respect of health care cards should be the basis for the distribution of the Medicare cards with the acknowledgment that, of course, health care cards are issued to particular people by the Department of Social Security and other qualifications are needed for those people who are in receipt of those health care cards. Health care cards in accordance with what the Minister stated during the Estimates Committee hearing will, of course, continue to be issued because, for example, pharmaceutical benefits are available to persons who are in receipt of health care cards. So they will still be on issue. I am not suggesting that only those children who are in receipt of health care cards should be in receipt of Medicare cards. I am putting to the Committee that the principle of the family allowance test, which is one of the tests applied before the issuing of the health care card, ought to be the test that applies in respect of the issuing of Medicare cards. I believe that that is a reasonable approach to this situation. It is one that should attract the support of the Government; I believe that it ought certainly to attract the support of the Opposition. It is a clean way of going about it. In my view it will overcome most of the objections and allay many of the fears that have been raised, both publicly and by constituents, about the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all aware that there is a group of young people who need health care cards in their own names. This group comes from that section of our youth who are called homeless youth. They are out on their own, without the backing of their families and with no support from their families. Some of these young people under 16 years of age have to stay at shelters, and unless they have access to a health care card they have no access to free health care. I was told at the hearings of Estimates Committee B last week that figures were not kept in this area. I think there was some misunderstanding about the matter. I think possibly Mr MacMahon misinterpreted my question. He said that the Department does not collect statistics which would answer my particular query. I took his answer to mean that no statistics at all were kept in this area, but I believe that there are. Until February 1983 5,248 health care cards had been issued for children under 16 years of age. The majority of these cards had been issued to institutions where the institution applied for health care cards for the children in its care.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there is another group of children who, as I have already said, are considered the homeless youth. They are entitled, in some instances, to special benefits. Out of those 5,248 young people under 16 years of age to whom cards have been issued, those who are getting special benefits number 1,339. They hold a health care card in their own name. When we were talking about this matter at Estimates Committee B, Senator Grimes said:
But I would like to emphasise also that there has been no change in policy, as far as I know, between this Government and previous governments, as to this matter.

That is not accurate. This Government's new Medicare proposition is that every citizen-no age is mentioned-is entitled to a card. Every household will be issued with an application form. The head of the household indicates who will have a card and in whose name it will be. This is not the end of the matter. The head of the household, the father, can set out the names of the members of his family that he wants to hold a card. He may well withhold, and I would presume he would, all his younger children, all his children under 18 years of age, perhaps, who are still being supported by him. As I say, that is not the end of the matter. Each one of those children may apply for a card of his or her own. No questions will be asked, none at all. Each child will be entitled to have a health care card of his or her own.

We know that under the Family Law Act parents are supposed to be responsible for their children up to the age of 18 years. We know that at the moment parents are told that they should know what their children are doing. They are held responsible for the behaviour and care of their children, and that is exactly as it should be. If this Government is willing to take that responsibility out of the hands of the parents for this group of children and put it into the hands of children of 13 and 14 years of age, there is something radically wrong with the Government. I do not want the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, to tell me that there is a group of children who need the card. We have gone into that. I am talking about two different groups of children. There is the group comprising the homeless youth and comprising the group in institutions who can be cared for most appropriately. There is the other group which is being supported by their parents who are receiving, as Senator Harradine has said, a family allowance. They are completely and utterly responsible for their children . Yet this Government is willing to take the responsibility out of the hands of the parents and allow those children to have a health care card without the knowledge of their parents, and allow those children to go their own way. I do not believe that the majority of Australian parents wish this to occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an outrageous suggestion.

—I am not suggesting that all children will do it. Nor am I suggesting that the Government is encouraging this practice. What I am saying is that the Government is making the opportunity available. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) in his second reading speech made it very obvious that this could happen, and we have been told that this proposal is necessary. I would like the Minister for Social Security to tell me why he considers it necessary to take the responsibility for children's health and their upbringing out of the parents ' hands.

—I find this a rather extraordinarily worded amendment since it talks about 'the issue of a Medicare card to a child in respect of whom the family allowance is paid without the authority of the child's parent or guardian, or of another person authorised by the child's parent or guardian to give such authority'. Unless I am very much mistaken, family allowance normally ceases when a child turns 16 years of age. However, in the case of full time dependent students, family allowance is paid to children up to the age of 24 years.
—Read the amendment.
—I will just finish this statement. I find it rather odd that a parent of a 23-year-old who happens to be a full time dependent student ought to be entitled to stop that child from getting a card.
—It says 'a child'.

—I know it says 'child'. I have just read it out. However, there is no definition of what a child is. I would very much like to know the accepted Australian or international definition of a child. Is it up to the age of 15 years, is it up to the age of 18 years, is it up to the age when they run away from home, is it up to the age when they stop being dependent, or what is the Australian definition of a child? Even supposing that the definition of a child is something which would mean that this clause is applicable only to people around the age of 14, 15 or 16 years, I am concerned that for some probably genuine reason people who are supporting this amendment are confusing caring for a child with absolute and utter dictatorial control over a child. There are families in which the parents have no real concern about the welfare of the child, and they may not include them on the family card. The only way the child will be given any adequate medical care is if he seeks it himself. I believe that supporting any sort of amendment in this area simply plays into the hands of irresponsible parents. Those parents who are responsible, who do care for their children, presumably will bring up their children in a loving, Christian family situation so that those children are aware of their social responsibilities.
—Caring and ethical, please.

—I accept Senator Baume's correction in its non-religious, non- sectarian sense. I am sure that in suggesting that he agrees with what I say: No parents bringing up a child in that manner need have any concern about the child sneaking out behind their backs, which apparently is the concern, and getting hold of a Medicare card. Those parents who do not bring up their children like that, having abrogated their responsibility, have no right to stop those children from attempting to protect themselves. I have a sneaking suspicion that at the back of this amendment is some desire not to allow children of the female species to go to a doctor for some sort of contraceptive advice. It never ceases to amaze me that those people who object to their girls preventing conception have no particular concern about what the heck their sons are doing in the meantime.

—I think it is proper to say on behalf of the Opposition that we will not be supporting the amendment. It is important that I explain why. I understand Senator Harradine's concern for the position and strength of the family in Australian society and I understand his concern that the influence of families may diminish. I say to the honourable senator that I have asked myself the question: What can be the possible consequences of agreeing to the amendment and perhaps denying the availability of the card to certain people? That is the question.
—I have asked myself that and I have come back to the conclusion that has been suggested in the Estimates committee.

—I just want to take this through with the honourable senator. Some people will work through their families to get whatever medical care is required, and to that extent the family influence will be preserved and the family structure and unity will be preserved. Certain other people will go without advice or care. I have received representations, and Senator Haines is quite right; the question that concerns many people is contraceptive advice for young women. In 1981 more than 100 girls in Australia aged 15 years had babies and more than 20,000 girls of teenage had babies; that is, at least that number of pregnancies went to term. However difficult it is in terms of our conception of what families should be about, if denying the health care card allowed that situation to continue or perhaps made it more difficult for some of those people to avoid getting advice, I think that would be undesirable. I do not like the fact that many people end up having abortions. I do not like the idea of unwanted pregnancies. I also do not like the idea of a society that is so permissive that sexual promiscuity becomes a feature of it. But I am not certain that denying the card to certain people who may wish to have it, and thereby perhaps denying them access to certain services, will be in the best interests of the society. I am also a bit uncertain as to what the significance of the definition of the word 'child' is. Would Senator Harradine say that a child, in a legal sense, is anyone under the age of 18 years?
—Under Commonwealth and State law, the interpretation of a minor-I will read it to you directly.
—Is it 18?
—Yes, it is.
—If it is 18, I really think that that is too old an age. It is simply too old and not in keeping with contemporary standards.
—It is certainly not 23, as Senator Haines was saying.

—No. Nevertheless, it is correct that the family allowance is payable in respect of certain people up to the age of 23 and there may be considerable argument about what the word 'child' means. We have a problem of cause and effect. Senator Harradine is concerned, I think rightly, about what the effect of issuing the card more widely might be. I am concerned, on the other hand, as to what some of the adverse effects of not issuing it might be. I cannot determine between the cause and effects of social behaviour. I find the whole question extremely difficult. It is one that is very sensitive in society and, with great sympathy for what Senator Harradine is trying to do, I must nevertheless indicate that the official Opposition will not be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We must look at this matter very carefully. I ask Senator Harradine in particular to look at it very carefully. I believe that he has a genuine concern, a concern I accept. I agree that Senator Walters has a genuine concern although I dislike the way she extends that concern to suggest that what is happening here is a result of some sinister plot by the Government to break up families and to take children out of the care of their families. Let me make several points. The first point is that the Medicare card does not entitle a holder to medical treatment. It is a device for facilitating the payment of medical benefits for the treatment that has been given.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the existing system, if a child goes to the doctor and the doctor bulk bills, the child, like anyone else, gets treatment but the parent does not know about that treatment. That is the existing system. Under the proposed system, which proceeds further, the absence of a Medicare card will not prevent that child from getting treatment; it will merely delay the settlement of payment. Giving the child a card does not entitle the child to demand treatment. The child can go and get treatment from a doctor, if the doctor will give the child that treatment. I remind Senator Harradine that in New South Wales the age of medical consent happens to be 14 years. The card itself is a means of identification and a means of speeding up the payment. It is no more than that. It is not like the health care card, which is necessary to establish one's right to treatment under the circumstances. So the absence of the Medicare card does not stop the person from having treatment; the presence of the card does not entitle the person to treatment. It is the doctor who must decide whether to treat the child, and Medicare, or the existence of a Medicare card or any other sort of card does not make any difference to that. So it is a matter between the doctor and the child and the doctor and the family. The card is a means of identification and a means of speeding up the claim.

So that is what the card is about. That is why people who are entitled to a service are in fact entitled to a card, but the card is not essential for them to get that service, nor is the card essential for the doctor to get the benefit under Medicare. Everyone under those circumstances is entitled to the card. Senator Harradine, Senator Walters and many people in the community do not like the situation which, perhaps as Senator Baume says, largely concerns contraception and a young woman of 14, 15 or 16 years being able to get the contraceptive pill. That is what it is all about. The Medicare card does not in fact make any difference to that. If they go to a doctor who is willing to give them the pill, he can do so and get his payment by bulk billing Medicare. The parents need not know anything about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor without the card.
—He can. The card is a means of identification. It speeds up the doctor's capacity to make the claim. But without the card-
—May I ask this question? Will the HIC pay the bulk bill claim ?

—Yes. What will happen is what happens now. I do not know exactly what information will be required under Medicare, but under Medibank the patient 's name, date of birth and address were all that were required for the claim to be processed. It is quite wrong to suggest that the card is absolutely essential . People will lose cards or will not have them. The gist of my argument is that we do not need this amendment. Senator Walters apparently suggests that the giving of these cards is a deliberate plot by the Government to break down the family. But by putting forward an amendment like this she creates the sorts of difficulties that Senator Haines pointed out, whatever one's definition of ' child' may be. I was told by one lawyer in the Senate that under the common law a person can be considered a child until the age of 21. That may or may not be so. I do not know because I am not a lawyer. If Senator Walters's amendment were adopted, students up to the age of 18 in this situation would not be able to have a card.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is aimed at stopping something which Senator Walters sees as destroying society-in essence, the child who wants to get the pill. Senator Walters thinks that we can interfere with or stop that by preventing the handing out of a Medicare card to a child under these circumstances. In fact, the side effects of doing that, as Senator Baume has said, may be to prevent that child from getting attention because there may be a perception that without the card he or she is not entitled to treatment. The side effects of withholding the card may be much more severe. I think it is the wrong way to go about a problem which I accept that Senator Walters perceives with all sincerity and which she wants to do something about.

As I said in the Senate the other day, I think that the publicity-the rather spectacular newspaper articles about the issuing of Medicare cards-was unfortunate. The issuing of a Medicare card will not force a doctor to treat a child of 14. It will not change the State laws regarding the age at which a child may be treated by a doctor. In New South Wales the age of medical consent is 14 and it varies from State to State. It will not affect State laws at all. It will not entitle anyone to medical treatment and, in fact, the absence of the card will not prevent anyone getting medical treatment. The card provides a means of identification and a means of speeding up claims and making the system more efficient. That is what it is about and it should not have any magical powers more than that attributed to it. Therefore, we oppose the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Grimes has told us that he is not sure what will happen with bulk billing under Medicare, but that under the present system only the patient's name, address and date of birth are required when bulk billing occurs. Can he assure us that under the new Medicare system the card, the number on the card or any reference to the card will not be required? Can he assure us that only name, address and date of birth will be required?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments on this issue. I think it has been fairly well covered but I wanted to suggest to people that they consider that young people between the ages of 13 and 14 and whenever they commence living independently do see doctors not only because they are females who wish to talk about contraception. Anybody who has worked with adolescent people will know that quite a few of them are very concerned about privacy. They do not necessarily want to talk to their parents to whom, in the ordinary course of living, they may be quite close. Many youngsters have other worries or anxieties including loneliness, depression or worries about what they will do when they grow up, to name just a few. Many of those, I might say, are young men. The suggestion that this is a secret plot to make contraception available to young girls merely misrepresents--
—You're building up a storm. I said nothing about that.

—I was not speaking directly to Senator Harradine, but if he cares to listen that is very good. I am suggesting from my experience that there are people who have actually sought my help and the help of other doctors in this area. They may be living independently from their parents, be out of affection with, or abandoned by, their families; but they may also be living at home in, to all intents and purposes, a going concern sort of family. They simply may not wish to discuss some of these matters with their parents. These are somewhat of the nature of furphies, because I think Senator Grimes has outlined the real issues. It is not merely a matter of who seeks treatment for what. I just wanted to make these comments so that we do not continue to consider youngsters between the ages of 13 and 21 who seek the help of doctors as being only female and only looking for contraception methods.

SPEECH.PARA: The other important point to make is that whether or not people have cards or apply for cards will not interfere in a relationship between parents and children. That relationship does not depend on parents being able to restrict access to cards. We are looking at the symptom and regarding it as the cause. Family breakdown, or dislocation between children and parents, will not be prevented by parents denying their children access to cards. I think it also needs to be said that most of the people who issue these cards are reasonable people who will follow a reasonable approach in distributing them. Kids will not front up at desks and say 'Give me a card', and get one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, they will.

—That is not how the world operates, Senator Walters. Most people are more mannerly. While the people issuing the cards may not necessarily get the Federal Police to check up on dates of birth, they will in most cases ask reasonable questions. But more importantly, some people would like to get a card because they may be away from home. They may not wish to ring up Mum and Dad and ask for their authority to get a card. The card is simply a mechanism whereby the whole process can be facilitated. I think it is important to stress again what Senator Grimes said. It is not some kind of secret plot. The card is a mechanism for facilitating medical payment.
—I asked a question of Senator Grimes. I wonder whether he could answer it.

—Of course the Health Insurance Commission will not want to encourage people to seek medical attention without their Medicare card, but in the future, as now, someone who does not have a card or who has lost it can still be processed. A person's Medicare number can be checked-on using the basic information of name, date of birth and address. I doubt whether the address would even be necessary. That is the system which exists now. It has existed in the past and under Medibank.

—Is the Minister saying that for purposes of bulk billing a card will be necessary unless there is some excuse, such as that the patient has lost it? Is he saying that in normal circumstances, a doctor who is to bulk bill will need the patient's name, address and date of birth, or the card?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The card is a means of facilitating claims generally, be they bulk billed or not. Of course, the vast majority of people and doctors will want people to have the card, because it makes the system more efficient. I am merely saying that there will be some situations in which people will not have their card.
—It gets the money in their pockets. That is the point.

—That is what really encourages them, Senator. I am not denying that. The point I am making is that the existence of a Medicare card does not entitle people to have treatment, nor does it prevent them from having treatment .
—Yes, it does if they want the money in their pocket quick.
—Do you think all doctors are as mean as that?
—No, I do not. I know some are.
—Order! There is too much cross talk in the chamber. Senator Grimes has the call.
—Why are you bringing in the Medicare legislation the way you are?

—But, with due respect, that is not the point the honourable senator brought up in presenting his amendment. I accept his genuine concern that the existence of the card in the hands of a young person will enable him to do something that he would not otherwise be able to do. That just is not so. Possession of the card does not ensure that the doctor will provide the treatment that one may or may not like and it does not inhibit the patient from getting it otherwise. Quite apart from the fact that people can get attention from a hospital, or an out-patient or other clinic, this card, which has been given mystical power in various newspaper articles and in questions from Senator Bjelke-Petersen and others in this place, is in fact an identification card. It will facilitate getting claims through.

SPEECH.PARA: We oppose the amendment because, first of all, we do not believe, as Senator Harradine believes or suspects, that the existence of the card in the hands of kids will make any difference at all. Secondly, we believe the side effects of restrictions like this will certainly be very much greater than any of the problems that Senator Harradine apparently perceives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister clarify what happens if parents apply for a family card for their children? Are they then entitled to get another card, at the same time?
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I substitute a second version of my amendment and accordingly move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 34, sub-clause 67 (1), at end of proposed new section 5, add the following new sub-section:

'(2) Nothing in sub-section (1) authorizes the Commission so to perform the functions referred to in that sub-section as to permit the issue of a Medicare card to a child who has not attained the age of 18 years and in respect of whom the family allowance is paid without the authority of the child's parent or guardian, or of a person authorized by the child's parent or guardian to give such authority.'.

There has been a little bit of debate about this matter, but I do not think it has clarified the situation at all. Extraneous matters have been raised. I will deal with one that was raised by Senator Haines. She seemed to suggest that if any young person between the ages of, say, 13 and 16-the age of confusion, of crisis of identity-succumbs to peer group pressure-

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Obviously Senator Crowley does not know what I am talking about, but anybody who has had anything to do with a good number of children will know-any parent ought to know-what I am talking about and that I am correct . Children in that age group who are suffering from an identity crisis-as many of them are-are susceptible to peer group pressure and to financial and other exploitation. Senator Haines seems to suggest that if they succumb to that peer group pressure or to exploitation, it is the problem and fault of the parents- because they have not done the right thing over time. I reject that suggestion completely. It is utter nonsense. In fact, it is the responsibility of this Parliament to ensure that the laws of our nation recognise the various phases, psychological and otherwise, that the human being goes through. It is for that reason that I raise this amendment here today. Nothing that has been said convinces me that given possession of the card by young people, an unscrupulous doctor will be prevented from exploiting them and by 'exploitation' I mean financial exploitation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Grimes has said that the only reason for the issue of the card is that it facilitates the claim being paid; that it does not entitle the person who possesses it to medical advice or treatment. But what he is not saying is that once people front up to clinics a number of doctors will immedately ask: 'Have you got your Medicare card?' If they have not and unless they have illnesses which need urgent attention, the doctors' advice will be: 'You had better see somebody about it'. Patients will then be able to go to another doctor, who will say: 'Yes, I will give you the advice'. Presumably that doctor will say: 'In order to ensure that I get the payment through quickly, here is a form from the Medicare organisation, the Health Insurance Commission. Fill out this form and I will send it along with the bill to the HIC and you will be issued with a card'. I ask the Minister whether that will occur. Will the medicos have forms from the HIC for patients to fill in, and will the doctors then send in those forms with their bulk bill? Presumably that will be the case. In effect, from the point of view of a doctor who wants quick payment for his services, possession of the card is all important. Therefore, indirectly, the delivery of the service depends on the possession of the card in that instance. If that is not the case, there is no need to worry about the card at all. Why have a card? Obviously, anybody who fronts up to a doctor, firstly, has been born and secondly is alive and presumably a citizen of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do we have Bankcard?
—We have Bankcard to get the services of a bank. That is what I am coming to. We will have a Medicare card to get the medical and hospital services which Medicare will provide.
—If someone does not have a card a doctor can make arrangements for that person to get one, whether it is through that person's parents or whether it is direct--
—That is exactly the point I am making.
—I am confused as to why it is important that it not be direct. You are saying it must be through the family.
—I am attempting to ensure that the family situation is not disturbed, particularly in a case of teenagers who are in a period when identity crises can arise.
—That is the essence of your amendment, isn't it?

—Yes, of course it is. I seek to ensure that those persons are not open to either financial exploitation or peer group pressure. If they are- which, of course, they will be-the families, who will have to pick up the pieces in the end anyhow, will know at the earliest possible stage of any problems that might arise, problems that are created by financial exploitation or peer group pressure. That seems to me to be an eminently reasonable proposition. We are all talking about the need to have the problem identified early in the piece so that people can consider it. And who best to consider it than the family?

SPEECH.PARA: It is suggested that there are people outside this situation who need to be issued with a Medicare card. I refer to people in institutions and people whose parents are not responsible for their care, custody, guardianship and so on. Of course, the test in that case is whether the parents receive the family allowance. I cannot see any difference between the test that has been applied to the issue of health care cards and the issue of Medicare cards. The Minister said that a person did not necessarily need a health care card to receive medical attention or advice. He also alleged that the possession of a Medicare card does not entitle a person to receive medical advice or services. Yet, health care cards are not issued to children. On page 140 of the Hansard report of Estimates Committee B, Mr MacMahon is quoted as saying:
Children under the age of 16 are precluded from these cards if the parent is in receipt of family allowance for them.

So, what is the difference? What is the difference between the application of that principle for the health care card and the application of the principle for the Medicare card if, as the Minister says, neither card entitles the holder to medical services or advice? I ask the Minister frankly whether he envisages the possibility that medicos will provide services only if the people in partciular cities in the age group we are talking about have a Medicare card because those doctors want for their services rapid payment which, according to the Minister, the Medicare card will facilitate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter question, of course there will be such doctors. There always have been such doctors. There will even be some doctors who, I dare say, will refuse to treat anyone who comes in with a Medicare card. Members of the General Practitioners Society have done that in the past in respect of pensioner medical cards. There is a distinction between the health care card and the Medicare card. Of course, no bit of paper or anything else entitles a person to walk into a doctor's surgery and demand treatment. I think we have to be clear about that. No payment is made to a doctor if a health care card is not presented. As I said payment can be made in the case of the Medicare card even though it may be delayed. We persist in our opposition to the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I accept the concerns of Senator Harradine, Senator Walters and others. But I make the point that that concern is part of a general concern that they have about their perception of what is happening in our society and what is happening to young people in our society. I believe that it is wrong to think that the introduction of Medicare and the Medicare card will exacerbate that situation. I believe that the harm that will be done to some people in society by what I think one must admit is a fairly hastily drawn up amendment of this type, without considering the ramifications of restricting the card in this way, does not justify the passage of this amendment. It is for that reason that the Government, as it did in the other place, expresses its opposition to this sort of amendment.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 68 to 70-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 71 (Prescribed functions).
