TALK.START.PARA: —I rise only to indicate that the Opposition opposes clause 71. It is part of the arrangements which put Medicare into place. The clause sets up the Health Insurance Commission. It provides that the Commission shall perform such functions as are prescribed by regulations. We believe that this is almost a Henry VIII clause. We have not talked a lot about this but the same objections we had to earlier clauses in the Bill apply to this clause. I indicate that the Opposition does not support the clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — This is the area in respect of which I presume Senator Haines, as the spokesman for the Australian Democrats, orginally agreed that her party would support the Opposition. On 13 July 1983, she put out a joint Press statement with our shadow Minister for Health, Mr Carlton, and Senator Harradine which in part read:

SPEECH.PARA: We do not accept that the centralisation of basic insurance under Medibank is a necessary part of the Government's Medicare proposals.

That statement still stands. This clause is not a necessary part of the Medicare proposals. It is possible to implement the philosophy or the ideology behind Medicare with the non-centralisation of its administration. Such an arrangement would enable all the funds to be able to conduct their business in the way they have. The jobs of 5,000 people will be saved and the administration of the system would be able to be kept much cheaper than would be the case under Medicare. I suppose this is the last possible occasion on which we can ask the Democrats to join us in allowing Medicare to go forward but in not permitting the centralisation of the administration area. I appeal to the Australian Democrats to adopt that course.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 72 agreed to.
Clause 73.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 36, clause 73, after proposed new sub-section 8J (2), insert the following sub-section:

'(3) Sections 48, 49, 49A and 50 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 apply in relation to directions under sub-section (1) as if in those sections references to regulations were references to directions, references to a regulation were references to a direction and references to a repeal were references to a revocation.'.

Clause 73 provides that the Commission is subject to the Minister's directions and that any direction received by the Commission will be included in the Commission's annual report. I will not go over all the arguments, but I simply say that this is one of those occasions when we believe that any such direction should be subject to parliamentary disallowance for the reasons which we set out last night in relation to other matters. It is entirely appropriate that this kind of direction come before the Parliament and that the Parliament have a chance to examine it. I commend the amendment.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause 73, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 74 agreed to.
Clauses 75 to 84-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 85 agreed to.
Clauses 86 and 87-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 88 to 100-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I desire to place on record again the opposition that we have to this group of clauses which are new provisions relating to matters such as diversification of activities of registered funds. It is part of the package by which we believe that the funds have been weakened. We advanced the arguments during the second reading debate. I wish to record our opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 101.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last two amendments which the Opposition wishes to move relate to clause 101 and clause 107. I circulated last night copies of an amendment to this clause. The amendment has been circulated in two forms. I indicate that I will be moving a pair of amendments which appear on our sheet as Nos 6 and 7. I will read them out to make sure that the Committee understands them. Amendment No. 6 refers to clause 101, line 41 and will leave out the word 'notice' and insert the word 'direction'. Amendment No. 7 relates to clause 107, line 20. At the end of the clause the following words are added: 'and substituting ''or served under sub-section 73BAC (2)''.'. I have varied the original form of the amendment on the advice of counsel. This will enable us more adequately to achieve what we were setting out to achieve with the amendment as we originally circulated it.
—You may speak to both of the amendments for clarity, but at the moment you should move the amendment to clause 101.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Page 53, clause 101, line 41, leave out 'notice', insert 'direction'.

I will speak to both amendments. The first is a fairly simple matter. The Minister for Health is able to issue certain revocations of existing approvals under this clause. We simply wish to provide that there be parliamentary scrutiny of any revocation. The revocations would in fact have the effect of stopping the activities of registered organisations. The redrafting has led to a situation where the revocations would not take effect until the Parliament had had a chance to look at them. That is simply because the revocations would have the effect of ending the business activities of the people involved. I commend the amendment. It is simply another case of having the Parliament oversight certain Executive decisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We accept the amendment. Although we think it may create some difficulties, it is acceptable.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 102 to 106-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 107 (Directions subject to Parliamentary disallowance).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Page 56, clause 107, line 20, at end of clause, add 'and substituting ''or served under sub-section 73BAC (2)''.'
This matter has already been referred to in Committee.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 108 to 131-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Postponed clause 38 (Agreements with States and Northern Territory for provision of hospital services).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: -Since the matter was last discussed in the chamber the letter to which the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) referred has been copied and made available to interested honourable senators. I have now also received a copy of a telex which went from the Premier of Tasmania to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the matter. It refers to the letter to which Senator Grimes has referred. I seek leave to table that telex so that the correspondence is complete. I have made it available to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The further complication is that in three minutes time there will be a meeting between the Tasmanian Minister for Health, Mr Cleary, and the Federal Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, to discuss the subject matter that has been referred to already in some considerable detail. I am assured that it is a matter of very real substance to the State of Tasmania. In the correspondence it is pointed out how there is a very significant difference between what Tasmania was led to believe as a result of previous meetings and what was provided for in the Federal Budget which was introduced last month. That makes a difference of $ 4.5m immediately. I hope that the Australian Democrats are taking a legitimate interest in this and in particular, being concerned about the interests of a State and the people of a State being protected in this chamber, they will support some deferral of this matter so that the discussions taking place almost at this moment can be made known to us.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that arrangements have been made between the Government and others about the passage of this Bill so that the amendments can go back to the House of Representatives. I point out that clause 38 of the Bill is not essential to the Bill in any event. It is something which simply seeks to remove section 30 of the existing Health Insurance Act. If the Government's case is correct, that is, that there is an agreement to vary the cost sharing agreement, it does not need to repeal section 30 of the principal Act. I hope that the Democrats and the Independent senator from Tasmania will support an action to defer clause 38 of this legislation until after a meeting has taken place between the two Ministers and a report of the meeting has been received. I invite the Minister for Social Security to respond to that suggestion.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Tasmania-Minister for Social Security) (12.00)-The simple fact of the matter is that what Senator Peter Rae is asking us to do is to delay legislation on matters of principle because, coincidentally, a meeting happens to be taking place between the Tasmanian Minister for Health and the Commonwealth Minister for Health (Dr Blewett).
—It is not a coincidence.
—It is to try to resolve the dispute.

—I know, but it is coincidentally taking place right now. The meeting might have been held next week or even in three weeks time but it happens to be taking place now. Let me clarify the situation. I believe the telex that Senator Peter Rae was kind enough to give me to read this morning-the telex which apparently according to him lays down the greatest concern of the Tasmanian Government-demonstrates either a great misconception on the part of the Tasmanian Government or that the Tasmanian Government is politicking in a silly way. Prior to the Health Ministers Conference on 15 June, that was before the Premiers Conference, the Commonwealth held a meeting of officers to provide financial details of the Medicare arrangements which were to be discussed at the Conference. Papers were circulated which outlined quite clearly the basis of the Medicare compensation grant. A document at that time clearly pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: States will continue to receive revenue from lagged payments at 1983 rates for an average of six weeks after February 1984.

In other words, compensation for revenue losses will therefore commence from 15 March 1984. The Tasmanian Government and Mr Cleary have used 1 February and taken five-twelfths when in fact Mr Cleary should be using 15 March. The Commonwealth has estimated that there will be some shift from private to public patient status in public hospitals. This, however, on the basis of experience will not occur immediately. For the Commonwealth to meet the cost of the full estimated shift it would have to pay Tasmania in advance for a factor that in fact may not even occur, and we are not allowed to do that in our budgetary estimates in this Parliament. We have to estimate as accurately as possible. A similar thing has happened in relation to the estimates in the Budget for the freight equalisation scheme. The Commonwealth has agreed to meet the actual shift on the basis of information which is to be provided by the State.

The difference that Senator Peter Rae and the Tasmanian Minister talk about arises because of the different date of calculation. There has been a misconception or a misreading of the documents that the Health Ministers' officials discussed or in fact someone is being mischievous. I just do not think that in this place we should delay an important package of legislation-a package which I might add it was agreed last night would be passed today-on the basis of a meeting which happens to be taking place this morning. It is a meeting about detail, not about principle. The Ministers at last are doing the right thing in discussing the details of the arrangements between the States. The principles were agreed to and have been agreed to for some months. I have had dealings with the Tasmanian Government over another issue. I know how it operates. I am not necessarily blaming it for operating that way; we all operate that way, I suppose, in some cases. But to come into this place and say, just because a meeting is being held at midday today, that the legislation should be held up I think is an improper use of this chamber of review. Therefore, the Government cannot agree to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: -The letter that was photostated for us, the reason for seeking a delay, made no mention at all of the letter of the Premier of Tasmania. As Senator Peter Rae has already indicated, the two Health Ministers are meeting at this moment. I do not believe for one moment that a delay of half an hour or an hour would make any difference to the legislation being passed today. I can see no problem in the Minister for Social Security agreeing to a delay of a couple of hours. The legislation would still reach the House of Representatives and would still be passed today. However, the Minister for Health in Tasmania is in Canberra seeking a meeting with the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, to try to make the Australian Democrats understand this situation. Senator Chipp has refused to see Mr Cleary. Senator Chipp said he has read the letters and he will not bother seeing Mr Cleary. Senator Grimes said that it is a coincidence that the Ministers are meeting today. That is not right; it is not a coincidence. Dr Blewett is going away. Mr Cleary particularly sought a meeting before Dr Blewett went away. There is no great coincidence about it. Mr Cleary is meeting with Dr Blewett on this specific issue.
—I said it is coincidental with this debate.

—Senator Grimes said that the meeting could have been held next week or the week after. It is a coincidence that this legislation is being passed today and the Ministers are meeting, prior to it being passed, to see whether they can come to some agreement. We should delay the legislation in this place a couple of hours until that meeting has concluded.

SPEECH.PARA: We have at the moment still in operation an agreement that was signed by a former Premier of Tasmania, Mr Neilson, and the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser . That agreement has not formally been concluded. It has not formally been torn up. It is an agreement by which the Tasmanian Government still abides. It still denies that there is any agreement to replace the one over those two signatures. In Tasmania at the moment an agreement is being reached between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Premier of Tasmania about compensation for the South West. Again, two signatures will be required. Is that piece of paper going to be as worthless as the other piece of paper which was signed by Mr Neilson and Mr Fraser appears to be? Is the Government going to say: 'In a couple of years time , if we do not like that agreement, we will alter it by the weight of our numbers. We will be able to change our agreement in that way'. Is that agreement going to be worthless too? How reliable is this Government if we cannot rely on it to abide by a document which was signed by a Premier and a Prime Minister? Until it is agreed that the current agreement should be no longer continued I am sure that the people of Australia consider that that agreement should still stand. The Premier's letter to Mr Hawke dated 15 September-not long ago-stated:
At the very least the Tasmanian Government would seek deferral of consideration of Clause 38-
That clause gets rid of the agreement-
of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill, and an early reply on the matters raised in our recent meeting in Hobart.
In this connection, I would point out that in the course of discussions with your Treasurer (Honourable P. J. Keating) at the Premiers' Conference-

He had discussions with the Treasurer (Mr Keating), not a conversation in the corridor, as Senator Grimes said. Senator Grimes ridiculed the Premier and said that he had been talking to the Treasurer in the corridor. The letter continued:
I indicated that I was not happy with the terms of the draft communique in view of Tasmania's current cost sharing arrangements and the fact that a number of matters still required clarification.
I suggested that it would be appropriate for the communique to be amended accordingly.
The Premier asked Mr Keating for the communique to be amended accordingly-

However, following the Treasurer's assurance that there would be ample time and opportunity for further discussion on the new Medicare proposals as they affected Tasmania, I did not raise the matter any further in Premiers' Conference.

The Premier took the word of the Treasurer in discussions that this proposal would not do away with the cost sharing agreement. Yet because it was not in writing, because there was no signature, the Government does not acknowledge that that conversation took place. Senator Grimes derides it by saying that they chatted in the corridors and that if that is the way the Premier of Tasmania does business it is no wonder Tasmania is as it is. That is a disgraceful attitude. Senator Grimes says that he knows the way in which the Tasmanian Government behaves and that it is just playing politics. That is not true. The Premier had conversations and discussions with the Treasurer. The Treasurer assured him that there would be ample time and opportunity. Now, of course, he does not even acknowledge that discussion. It is now 12 minutes past 12 o'clock. The meeting between the two Ministers for Health should be over within the hour. I ask the Minister for Social Security to delay this clause for an hour until the discussions are over and the position is clarified. I appeal to the Government to do that at least. It will not stop the legislation passing both Houses today. One hour will not make any difference. Surely the Government's honour is at stake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters talked about agreements, about arrangements and about breaking arrangements. Let me tell honourable senators about an agreement and an arrangement. At 11 o'clock last night in this chamber we had the capacity to pass this legislation and we did not pass it. The reason we did not pass it at 11 o'clock last night was that an agreement was made by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) that we would pass the legislation this morning. Senator Walters is not taking any notice of that agreement.
—Where is your leader?

—Where is the Opposition leader? The Opposition is filibustering in the way it has so often in the past. The reason I object to and oppose the delay in the passage of this legislation is that the argument that has been presented here by Senator Peter Rae, quite justifiably, from Mr Cleary's letter is demonstrably wrong. Mr Cleary is claiming that the State of Tasmania should receive a compensatory grant based on five-twelfths of the estimated payment for Tasmania in a full year from 1 February, when every other State realises that because of the six-week lag the payments should start on 15 March. If that is the only argument which the Opposition has to go on there is no justification for the Committee delaying this legislation. It should not be delayed because, coincidentally, there happens to be a meeting between the State Minister and the Federal Minister today. If we had done what we had intended to do last night, this legislation would have been through; it should have been through. Because of the interference of the Leader of the Opposition it did not go through. Now Senator Walters in particular is taking advantage of that and is willing to delay the passage of this legislation. On behalf of the Government, I am not willing to accept that attitude.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walters mentioned the fact that the Premier was somewhat concerned after the Premiers Conference because he had come to an arrangement, in a conversation with the Treasurer (Mr Keating), about fixing up details arising out of the communique and the health care program. I made the comment last night , I believe, that I found it extraordinary that the Premier of a State would sign a communique and then say he did not really mean to sign it, that he signed it only because of a conversation he had with the Treasurer who assured him that things would be fixed up later. That may or may not be so, but I still find it extraordinary. I do not deny that the conversation took place. We know that it took place because on 28 July the Commonwealth Government wrote to the State Premier and the State Government saying: 'We know there are things to discuss. Come up here, with or without your officials, and discuss them.' They did not do so. This is absolutely typical of the approach of the Tasmanian Premier not only on this matter but also on the negotiations on the dam compensation.

The only evidence which has been presented to the Committee to justify delaying this clause and the legislation is Mr Cleary's claim in the letter which Senator Peter Rae gave us earlier-I accept that he did it in all good faith-that $4m-odd is missing. I think that is demonstrably not so. On the basis of that little bit of evidence I do not believe the Committee should delay the legislation while two Ministers are talking. We do not know how long they will be talking. They may talk for four hours. In any case, the commitment was given last night. It might not mean anything to Senator Walters, but I am sure it means something to her Leader.

TALK.START.PARA: —She was not party to it.
—She was here. I saw Senator Chaney go and talk to her about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —There seems to be some misunderstanding. As I understand it, the proposal by Senator Peter Rae does not seek to hold up the legislation.
—He is not. She is.

—As I understand it, if Senator Rae's proposition is adopted, the legislation will not be held up. The legislation can go forward. The Government could then introduce a subsequent piece of legislation, when there is an agreement between the parties, to repeal the cost sharing agreement. The proposal in clause 38 smacks of retrospective legislation. The explanatory memorandum explains that the clause repeals clause 30 of the principal Act which authorises the Commonwealth to enter into agreements with a State. That agreement has been entered into. It was entered into between the then Premier of the State, Mr Neilson, and the then Federal Government. There were provisions in the agreement and in the principal Act, I think, which indicated how that agreement would be implemented and terminated. The measures for termination did not include unilateral legislation by the Commonwealth Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: It is fair for honourable senators from a particular State to try to understand the attitude of the government of that State and the attitude of the Commonwealth Government. I would be disturbed if unnecessary delays occurred on this question, but I am not convinced that the Parliament should take unilateral action to terminate an agreement made in accordance with the principal Act whereby the termination clause does not permit the Commonwealth Parliament to take unilateral action. I believe that we as a Parliament, particularly as an upper House, have a responsibilitiy to ensure that the rights of the States in these matters are upheld. If honourable senators from other States do not want to enter into this debate or do not want to vote on it, let only those senators from Tasmania vote on it and see what happens.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, I wish to clarify a point of procedure. It would not be possible for the Committee to postpone the consideration of clause 38 and pass the remainder of the Bill. Clause 38 would have to be deleted for that to be possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand Senator Harradine beating the local drum. I understand Senator Harradine's proposal that we should not do anything in this place until we know what is in the mind of the Tasmanian Government. I suggest that all one could do in those circumstances would be to bring the Premier and perhaps the Minister for Health up here every time the legislation came before this place. Let me explain what happened. At the Premiers Conference, the Treasurer, Paul Keating, said, in words that could hardly be clearer:

SPEECH.PARA: I emphasise that the Commonwealth's attitude towards the amount of any additional borrowing programs--
that is, the whole borrowing program-

it is prepared to support will also be heavily contingent on the States agreeing to the proposals for compensating the States for new health arrangements under Medicare on the basis put forward by the Minister for Health on 15 June, 1983 subject to the changes which we will later be proposing in Premiers Conference.

At the end of the Premiers Conference a communique was signed and agreed to by the Premier of Tasmania. I have quoted that communique here about 14 times. I have pointed out that the Commonwealth-State hospital agreements between Tasmania and South Australia would be terminated but that there were details to be worked out.

A health Ministers meeting was held on 14 July. The Tasmanian Minister for Health did not open his bib, did not say a thing, about those arrangements being unsatisfactory and that they were still negotiating. On 28 July the Federal Government wrote to the Premier of Tasmania and said that it knew there were details to be worked out. The Government asked the Tasmanian Government to send its officials up to talk about it. It did not. Today a telex is sent from the Tasmanian Minister for Health, Mr Cleary, to the Federal Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, complaining that what is really wrong is that Tasmania did not get enough because five-twelfths of the grant worked out, as from 1 February, would be $11m-I think it was-and in fact there was not an amount of $11m in the Budget . Because of the six weeks lag in compensation payments, the basis of the calculation had to be from 15 March. In fact, the actual cost of any shift from private to public patients in the hospitals-not the estimated cost-will eventually be met. The whole basis of that document is that calculation, and that calculation is wrong.

For heaven's sake, are this chamber and this Parliament to be stood over by every Premier and State Minister for Health who carries on in that way-who signs communiques he does not agree with when asked for details, does not come to Canberra and in fact provide them--

TALK.START.PARA: —And when he does they are wrong.

—And who eventually provides details, as Senator Tate says, that are wrong. They come up to Canberra on the day that the debate happens to be on and Opposition senators from Tasmania and elsewhere say: 'Look, the Ministers are meeting; let us hold up this legislation. Let us leave this clause here and send the rest of the Bill over to the House of Representatives.' That is impossible without defeating the clause. It is an irresponsible way for us to operate. Governments which conduct government to government relations in that way will find it impossible to operate. There is no question that Tasmania and South Australia have agreed that the Commonwealth-State hospital cost-sharing agreements will end under Medicare. Tasmanians will be gravely disadvantaged if they do not come under Medicare.

SPEECH.PARA: The Ministers are today debating details, not principles. This Bill is about principle. We should pass this legislation without obstruction, as was guaranteed, as was stated by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) last night. It will be an increasing problem in this place if the Leader of the Opposition makes statements like that and people like Senator Walters ride roughshod over them whenever they choose.

TALK.START.PARA: —To begin with, I am not filibustering. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) has just taken five minutes to speak. I have taken no more than a couple of minutes each time I have risen to my feet. If the Minister wants to filibuster and blame the Opposition, that is his problem. I say to the Minister that he had better quote accurately from the letters. On 14 July he said that the Tasmanian Minister did not open his mouth, that he was not concerned about it. Dr Blewett said at that stage that there would be need for officer to officer decisions with the two cost-sharing States and that he had written a letter to indicate this to South Australia and Tasmania. That is why there was no discussion about it. The Minister said then that there would be officer to officer discussions. Again, Senator Grimes said that, in response to the request of 28 July, the Tasmanian Government would not send officers up. Do honourable senators know what that request was? The request concluded by stating that Mr Cleary was to set in train arrangements for the Tasmanian Premier to write to the Prime Minister seeking a formal termination of the current hospital cost-sharing agreement from 31 January 1984 in accordance with section 23 of the States (Tax Sharing Grants) Act. Why would the Premier do that? Naturally, he would not. No agreement had been reached. It was not the case that officers would not come up here. Dr Blewett was asking the Premier to sign a termination. Senator Grimes ought to get his facts straight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — In an endeavour to bring the matter to finality, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That further consideration of clause 38 be postponed.

In doing so I quickly reiterate that there are matters of concern which have been outlined. I do not think it is entirely accurate for Senator Grimes to suggest that the matter is so simple. If it is so simple agreement should have been reached long ago. There are questions of increases in costs over the next nearly two years, as well as matters relating to $4.5m to which reference has been made which have to be determined. Clause 38 which I have moved be adjourned is really only for the purpose of repealing section 30 of the principal Act. I have referred already to that. The Health Legislation Amendment Bill could go ahead satisfactorily without that clause. I would be happy to listen to any suggestion that the Minister may make in relation to any way of achieving finality. We certainly do not wish to see broken any agreements that have been reached. That is why we are concerned about this matter. We believe that, if this were allowed to go ahead, it would involve a breach of an agreement which is actually in statute. The statute is section 22 of the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act which requires any termination of the agreement to be in writing under the hand of the Premier of Tasmania. That certainly is not the case in this instance. My motion is offered in the hope of resolving the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have nothing more to add. Senator Walters mentioned the fact that Dr Blewett spoke about the need for further discussions on 14 July. Of course he did. He spoke about it at every meeting they have had and been able to negotiate at. Senator Peter Rae added only one new factor, that the Tasmanian Minister wants to talk about cost increases in future years, et cetera, et cetera. That is the shopping list I was talking about. That is the shopping list that is outside the Medicare agreements . In fact, the actual costs of the shift from private to public hospitals will be met by the Government. Agreements for compensation payments will be met by the Commonwealth Government. I think really that it is absolutely outrageous that one State Minister and one State Premier who made an agreement at the Premiers Conference and have been fiddling around ever since should be able to come here and stand over their State senators in an effort to--
—Are you assuring us that there is no reason for concern about cost increases? Is that your assurance?
—There is no reason for concern at all about cost increases.
—They will be covered by the Commonwealth?

—There is an escalation factor in the agreement and there always has been. We have always negotiated that. If we are going to do this, I warn the Committee that it will give the green light to every State Premier and every State Minister, when legislation such as this comes up, to come here and stand over this Parliament and the Government and say: 'Sure, we agreed with something back in July but we are not quite happy with it now'. Because there may be an election coming up, or for all sorts of reasons, they may demand that their State senators delay legislation. It is an outrageous proposition and I urge the Committee to reject it.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That further consideration of clause 38 be postponed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I ask when the Bill to impose the Medicare levy will be called on.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the next Bill. The second reading of that Bill would have to be passed. Although there was a common second reading debate, the Bills are being passed and considered in Committee separately.

INTERJECT.PARA: Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 20 September 1983, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Grimes) why it is that the Government is not imposing a different levy in each State. The levy at the moment takes over from the health insurance contribution rates that were applicable in the various States. The State from which I come-and certainly this is also the case in Queensland-pays a far lower rate for basic hospital and medical table insurance than the larger States. Indeed, when one takes off the 30 per cent rebate, people in Tasmania pay $6.79 for basic hospital and medical cover, while people in New South Wales pay $9.80. That is a 30 per cent difference-a quite considerable difference. If the one per cent levy is uniform throughout Australia Tasmanian people will be greatly disadvantaged. As it is, doctors in Tasmania do not charge the same schedule fee as doctors in other States do. Last evening when this matter was being debated I had incorporated in Hansard a table showing some of the fees charged. For instance, a general practitioner's standard consultation fee is $12.40 in Tasmania, whereas in New South Wales it is $13.20. Referral to a specialist in Tasmania costs $31.50; in New South Wales the fee is $38. A visit to a consultant physician costs $60 in Tasmania and $66 in New South Wales. The fee for a confinement by a specialist in New South Wales is $255 and in Tasmania it is $192-the same as a general practitioner charges in New South Wales. A general practitioner in New South Wales charges $192 for a confinement, but in Tasmania the fee is $154. An appendicectomy costs $172 in New South Wales and $150 in Tasmania. There is a vast difference in the amount that patients have to pay. There is a 30 per cent difference in the contribution rate, and I ask the Government why it is that Tasmanians and certainly Queenslanders will be disadvantaged by a uniform levy of one per cent when already Tasmania pays 30 per cent less than New South Wales in contribution rates for the same services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In brief, the answer to Senator Walters is that section 51 (ii) of the Constitution of this country, which she is so keen to defend, refers to 'Taxation, but so as not to discriminate between States or parts of States'. Of course that is only partly the answer.
—It is not an answer at all.

—It is a perfectly valid answer. If Senator Walters is suggesting that we ignore section 51 of the Constitution and apply a different levy in each State, I suggest she talk to some of the people from the High Court of Australia whom she so frequently quotes. She should talk to Sir Harry Gibbs; she is always quoting him. Of course Senator Walters is right: Medical fees tend to be lower in Tasmania than in other States, and contributions to voluntary health funds tend to be lower there than they are in other States. There is something about swings and roundabouts. I suggest that the good senator look at the tax reimbursement to Tasmania per capita, for instance, and talk to some of her colleagues about the level of tax reimbursement to Tasmania compared to, say, Victoria which Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle represents or New South Wales which Senator Baume represents. She might get some arguments which would make Tasmania quite happy to accept the one per cent levy across the board, as long as it gets the tax reimbursements that it gets now. The simple answer is, firstly, that this is done because it is constitutional and, secondly, because it is a sensible way to do it in the Federation as we have it. Tasmania gets it back in other ways.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without requests; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX LAWS AMENDMENT (MEDICARE LEVY) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 20 September 1983, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) for some advice. On page 4 of the Income Tax Laws Amendment (Medicare Levy) Bill, under the heading 'Prescribed persons', a series of statements about the levy payable by certain personnel, including Defence Force personnel, is set out. A problem has been raised on which some clarification is needed. As I understand it, Defence Force personnel pay no levy . I understand that a Defence Force person with a wife who earns no income is to pay a contribution to the levy on behalf of his wife. Defence Force personnel think that if their wife is an income earner, she will be required to pay the levy herself. They are concerned that they also will still be required to pay the partial contribution in respect of their wife. So there are several questions. Are the concerns of the Defence Force personnel correct, in that if they have a working wife they will end up paying twice because of her contribution? I understand that the Defence Force personnel are prepared to make some contribution to the levy in respect of a dependent wife with no income, but they see no reason why they should pay any levy if the wife has her own income and is paying a full levy herself. It is really a question of detail. We are anxious to know what the facts are. I would be grateful for the Minister's advice.

—As Senator Baume says, a member of the defence forces who, as part of his conditions, is covered by the medical services in the defence forces, does not pay a levy on behalf of himself; nor does he pay a levy if he has dependants who are also covered by that agreement. If he has dependants who are not covered he pays a percentage of the levy, as Senator Baume says, to cover them. If his wife works, she, like everyone else who has a taxable income-if her income is over the threshold-pays the levy, and in those circumstances he also continues to pay that part levy. I think it is wrong to consider coverage under Medicare as just covering a period that a person spends in the Services. It covers a lifetime's contribution towards a health scheme, and the Government thinks it is reasonable that that situation apply and continue to apply.
—Are you saying, then, that in that circumstance there would be two payments in respect of that wife-one she makes herself and one made by her husband as a part payment?

—I think the situation is completely analogous to the one I brought up last night. A single income family and a two-income family both pay the levy on their incomes. In this case the serviceman would pay a proportion of the levy on his income, whether or not his wife is working. If one is to draw comparisons between incomes of Defence Force families and incomes of other families, it is sensible that that levy should apply across the incomes which are leviable. I think that is a reasonable way to put it. Therefore, that is the situation. I do not see it as analogous with that described by Senator Peter Baume.

—Given that response from the Minister, can he now explain what happens with the various ceilings that will apply in respect of a spouse? We have only been talking about wives, but I presume there are female defence service personnel who actually have husbands in the work force. What will happen with the upper income level, dependent children, and so forth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed by my advisers that the ceiling is arrived at by first calculating that ceiling under the normal rules and then reducing it by the amount for which the serviceman himself is covered.
—So in the event of a defence service family the top ceiling is lower than it is for a family outside the defence forces?
—Indeed, it is.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (TAX SHARING AND HEALTH GRANTS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 20 September 1983, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reiterate the objections that have been previously raised. It is obvious from the numbers that there is no point in my doing more than reiterate the objection to the fact that an agreement entered into is being overruled by legislative action of this Parliament on a unilateral basis. It is clear, though, that the Australian Democrats are not prepared to support us in protecting the interests of Tasmania from being run over by the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects the nonsensical statement by Senator Peter Rae. An agreement in fact was made at the Premiers Conference. The Premier of Tasmania with other Premiers signed it. The Minister for Health from Tasmania and the Commonwealth Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) have since been negotiating on the details of the matter . To suggest that this Government or this Parliament is trampling over the rights of the States might be good for a column in the Launceston Examiner tomorrow, but it does not stand up to any close scrutiny.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a third time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: -In this matter of public importance we are considering:

SPEECH.PARA: The adverse impact on employment of the Government's broken promises and the total confusion caused by this divided Government's public disarray over its manufacturing industry policy.

The election of the Government was, I believe, a reflection of a very widespread concern in Australia amongst electors for future employment opportunities. Seeing a position in which there was an increasing percentage of unemployment, electors opted for a change of government in the belief that it would be possible for the promises-I would describe them as rather wild and extravagant- made by the then Opposition to be fulfilled. In the words that were used by one of the Labor Party's State Premiers and adopted by others, the election campaign and the economic policy required by the people of Australia were about jobs, jobs, jobs.

The present Government promised that it would provide those jobs. During the election campaign it campaigned on the basis that it would adopt what I would describe as a Mitterrand approach-that is, it would adopt a policy in which it would, by fairly massive spending and by other fiscal stimulatory measures, expand the economy and ensure that jobs were created. It very promptly changed from the Mitterrand approach to what might be described as the Stone approach. It might also be described as the Thatcher or Reagan approach. There are those in the community who find it difficult to see how the economic policies being adopted by this Government differ from those of the previous Government.

I wish to point out a number of significant places wherein this Government's policies differ from those of the previous Government to the detriment of Australia. The National Economic Summit Conference was well summed up by an editorial in the Australian of Tuesday, 13 September, in which it was stated:
Without any doubt, the outcome of the summit was all about improving the living standards of those still left with jobs and not about making the maximum effort to help those without them.

That summarises the concern of the Opposition with the fact that this Government is continuing to adopt a policy under which it goes soft on wage demands and the wage pause which the former Government put into effect. It goes soft on those who already have jobs at the expense of those who have not. It was upon those who have not that the election campaign was centred, and because of them the election result was as it was. Therefore, it is a matter of public importance, it is a matter of great concern, that these various policies, which I will outline, are doing nothing for the creation of greater employment opportunities in Australia.

The most extraordinary good fortune has followed on the most extraordinary bad fortune. The good fortune is that the drought has broken. The bad fortune is that the former Government had to fight an election campaign at the height of the bad effects of the drought. Those effects were very extensive. They did not apply directly only to the rural sector. Besides affecting the rural sector, the drought had all sorts of flow-on effects, for example, on manufacturing industry . It adversely affected the whole of the economy and all rural Australia, not only those on the land but also those associated with rural towns, transport and the like. The drought has broken and that advantage has accrued to Australia. It is clear that the wage pause introduced by the former Government, with the support of all State Premiers and the Australian conciliation and arbitration system, has been successful. We then had the coincidence, after the breaking of the drought and the success of the wage pause, of the United States and world recovery taking place. With all of those advantages laid on a plate for the new Government, an opportunity for it to be able to take steps based upon the completely changed circumstances, one would have expected that the Budget introduced in August this year would have projected very significant increases in employment. Instead of that this Budget, which was introduced at the end of August 1983, to apply for the year 1983-84, projects a net half per cent decrease in employment in Australia. If honourable senators look further they will find that the projections in relation to manufacturing industry are even more dismal because even though the amount of bounty payments has not been changed a large number of areas of bounty payments for manufactured goods show a decrease estimated in the actual payout, which can mean only that it is projected that there will be a lower volume of production during the current year than there was during the bad year of 1982-83.

This Government, with all of those advantages to which I have referred-the wage pause, the breaking of the drought and the United States and world recovery taking place-had an opportunity to introduce a mini-Budget. What did it do in that mini-Budget? It made an attack on those in the community who have been thrifty, those who might invest and those who might be concerned about housing and what the upturn in investment there can provide and those who have reasonable entitlement to believe that they can expect a reward for effort. All of those people were hit in that mini-Budget. That mini-Budget did nothing to encourage investment or to create confidence or jobs.

That has been followed by the continuation of an extraordinary saga-the efforts of the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, to continue to make threats about the introduction of a capital gains tax at a time when most people would have believed that the last thing the Government wanted to do was to frighten off capital and investment. The Government should be endeavouring to encourage confidence for investment to take place so that one can anticipate that more jobs will be created as a result of that investment. We then find not only continuing threats as recently as yesterday with Senator Button saying that he will continue to argue for a capital gains tax and that in effect he does not mind if that means there will be some loss of confidence and investment but also, worse than that, the statements of the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, in which he provides Australia with a most dismal prospect in relation to employment in manufacturing industry. On 22 April last he said that the downturn in employment in manufacturing industry is permanent, structural and irreversible. It is quite clear that as far as he is concerned he does not think that anything can be done to recreate job opportnities in manufacturing industry. That can be categorised only as an extremely dismal attitude and in fact is being shown at this very moment to be incorrect because in quite a cross-section of sectors of manufacturing industry new jobs are being created and old jobs, which have been temporarily vacant, are being refilled.

On top of the mini-Budget, the Budget and the statements by Senator Button and Mr Jones about the prospects of job creation we find that the whole Budget is premised on the old socialist concept of providing the answer for employment by creating public sector jobs. In fact, the Budget failed dismally in providing stimulus for industrial investment to create new jobs. For industry generally the Budget is a dismal document of despair. It will reduce the encouragement and assistance to industry which has existed. This, together with the inflationary and interest rate pressures arising from the Budget's tax measures and the Government's wages policy, can lead Australian industry only further into an internationally uncompetitive position. In 1983-84 the Federal Government's provision for industry assistance and development will decline by 7 per cent in real terms. I hope Senator Tate will look at that and reply if there is any inaccuracy in it. I repeat: In 1983-84 the Federal Government's provision for industry assistance and development will decline by 7 per cent in real terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the source, Senator?

—That is done by calculating the Budget figures. Outlays to mining and manufacturing are forecast to decline by 2 per cent in real terms, with assistance to export industries decreasing by 17 per cent-hardly a sign of projected growth or of Government encouragement to industry. Budget provisions for assistance to industry provide further proof that this Government regards the downturn in Australia's manufacturing industries as, as I quoted from Mr Barry Jones a little while ago, permanent, irreversible and structural.
—What was the source of the analysis?

—It is an analysis from the Budget figures. These are the Budget figures. I hope that the Government has analysed what they mean. With those sorts of provisions made in the Budget one can understand if there is some degree of concern about the future. Let us look at what is happening amongst the leadership of the present Government. We find a leadership war taking place over the question of manufacturing industry and a manufacturing industry policy. The quotations from the statements made by various leaders are fairly well known and well documented. I will not take time to refer to them all in detail, but I will quote from what Mr Hayden said on 12 September at a book launch in Canberra:

SPEECH.PARA: The various forms of protection in the Australian economy are, in fact, embalming geriatric industries in the formaldehyde of protection.
He continued:
The problem is that over the longer term our arteries harden, our muscles do not respond when they ought to, our reflexes slow down.
In commenting on that, Senator Button said:
I simply take the view that Mr Hayden was expressing a long term view in this matter.

There has been well documented a series of comments back and forth between Senator Button, Mr Hayden and others and then Mr Lionel Bowen. I remind honourable senators that Mr Bowen is the Deputy Leader of this Government and that Mr Hayden is the former leader of the party in government. Mr Bowen said:
In matters of trade I am responsible. In matters of foreign policy the Minister for Foreign Affairs is responsible, and matters of economics belong to the Treasurer.

Mr Bowen made it very clear that he was, what I think could be fairly described as, an all out protectionist. Mr Hayden has made it very clear that he is virtually an all out free trader. Senator Button has pleaded for, I think as he said yesterday, a middle role. Mr Hawke has been somewhat firmer in supporting his former leader Mr Hayden. Mr Hawke said:
We do not think that any good purpose would be served by changing established medium-term programs to provide more protection.
For one thing, the problems faced by industries have many causes, and greater protection from import competition would do little to address more fundamental, long-term problems.
That was reported in the Australian Financial Review on 26 August 1983. He went on to say:
. . . Competitiveness cannot satisfactorily be restored by feather-bedding of inefficient or outdated processes or by a regressive drop in working conditions.

He does not say exactly to which industries he is referring. Let me refer to the fact that manufacturing industry in Australia is feeling rather bruised and battered. It has been commonplace in recent times to say that Australian manufacturing industry is inefficient, not up to date or competitive and not competent. I refute that. I think Australia has some of the most efficient manufacturing industries in the world and can demonstrate that. One could trot out a whole list of industries in Australia which compete world wide and knock the pants off their opposition. Others are uncompetitive. When one looks at that uncompetitiveness, almost without fail the cause is that their labour costs and labour on-costs in particular have costed them out of, either directly or because they are downstream from the addition of such costs, a competitive position.

One of the more strange interventions in the whole of this debate which has been taking place within the government leadership was the introduction of Mr Kerin, as the Primary Industry Minister who apparently felt that he was being left out of the fun and so he ought to buy in.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have not given me a run yet.

—Would Senator Grimes like to make a contribution as to where he stands between the Buttons, the Haydens, the Hawkes and the Bowens? If he does not wish to, I will get on with my speech. Let me refer to what Mr Kerin, as Primary Industry Minister, said. In a newspaper article he is reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I frankly can't understand the IAC recommendation on the harvester case. It is one I am personally opposed to.
I think it was quite a silly decision, particularly as we pay bounty on tractors rather than tariffs.
I fought it off once but I was in Papua New Guinea the day the decision was taken. However, I am fighting to get the bounty principle established.

He is talking there about a Cabinet decision of a government of which he is a member. He is disputing the decision-a rather strange breach of what is normally understood as Cabinet corporate responsibility. Be that as it may, we then find that the Caucus Industry Committee, not wishing to be left out on this, is quoted as having made considerable comment through its Chairman, Dr Theophanous. No doubt my colleagues will be able to refer to those in more detail. But members of that Committee have apparently come out as full blooded protectionists in the fight which is taking place. They accused Senator Button of ignoring ALP industry policy. They attempted to intervene directly in the Department of Industry and Commerce in relation to industry matters. They sought new assistance packages for the metals industry after Budget decisions had been made. Also, they are seeking to have the policy upon which the Government was elected changed. These actions are part of a long list of broken promises which again destroy the confidence of people in investment and the creation of jobs in Australia.

Let me run very quickly through some of the broken promises. They include: The petrol pricing policy, the retreaded tyres sales tax question, the taxation of lump sum superannuation payments, the retention of the home loan rebate, the Darwin-Alice Springs railway, the East Timor question, the income tax cuts that were promised and the uranium question. They are just a few of pages of promises already broken by a government which is not yet six months old. We have a government which has broken the fundamental economic policy promises that it made to the electorate as a basis for being elected. The Government said that it would create jobs, jobs, jobs by using a particular method. It has thrown that out the window. It has now broken a whole cross-section of other promises. It is now having an internal but very public war between various members of the leadership as to whether people in Australia involved in manufacturing industry or interested in investing in manufacturing industry can expect any or no protection as a matter of government policy.

It would not be any wonder if the people of Australia, if they had an opportunity to cast a vote at the moment, rejected this Government for its very failure to be able to come to grips with two major problems it has. The Government needs to restore confidence to provide for the investment that is necessary in manufacturing and other industries. In particular, manufacturing industry lost over 80,000 jobs in the 12 months to February last. More jobs were lost in the period immediately following but as a result of the wage pause there has been some improvement. Confidence in Australia, confidence particularly in manufacturing industry, is fragile. The public debate which has taken place within the Government's leadership will do nothing to restore that confidence. It is a matter of public importance that confidence be restored, and restored at the earliest possible opportunity. The Government must stop its public war and make a firm and clear statement as to where it is going and what people can expect in relation both to promises made previously and providing for a viable, efficient and competitive manufacturing industry in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects the matter of public importance raised by the Opposition, which asserts that there has been an adverse impact on employment as a result of the Government's 'broken promises and the total confusion caused by this divided Government's public disarray over its manufacturing industry policy'. If, of course, such a grave charge were true and could be sustained, this chamber would be well spending its time in debating it. After all, employment in the manufacturing sector is of the order of some 18 per cent of total employment in Australia and therefore this is properly a matter for debate and deliberation in this chamber. But I do not believe that the charge in the matter of public importance can be sustained. I believe that such a charge is particularly audacious, coming from the Opposition benches as it has, because over the years when honourable senators opposite were in government, employment in the manufacturing sector declined by over 100,000. If we look at the figures for August 1976 when the first Liberal-National Party Budget was introduced-the then Government's own Budget, as it were-we find that 1,281,600 Australians were employed in the manufacturing sector. But when the Liberal-National Party Government was unceremoniously replaced by the Labor Government in February 1983 there were 1,146,900 jobs in that sector. As I say, those figures show an overall decline in employment in the manufacturing sector.

SPEECH.PARA: The figures on overall decline in the number of jobs during a sustained period of seven years-this is not a matter of seven months-under the previous Government's administration and policies do not tell the whole picture either because they give no real impression of the havoc and distress in particular industries, plants, factories and communities that are dependent on manufacturing. They certainly give no feel for the momentum that was building up and was unleashed this year as a result of those seven years of neglect of industry policy-a problem with which we have had to deal. No one, surely, can seriously suggest that this year's adverse employment figures in the manufacturing sector can be sheeted home as the responsibility of this Government. We are not responsible for the accumulated effect of seven years of failure. After seven months, as I will illustrate, we are doing particularly well to get a coherent policy together. But there is no mea culpa from Senator Rae, no attempt even to apportion some of the blame fairly on the previous Government's administration of this area. All we have had is hostile propaganda against us.

It is difficult to take seriously talk of public disarray, given the manifest public disarray of the Liberal-National Party Opposition on almost every issue of importance to the future of Australia. Only in the last few days-and this is not as entirely irrelevant as it may seem to be, Mr Deputy President-in relation to the Sex Discrimination Bill, Claude Forell was led to say this in an article in the Melbourne Age:
Meanwhile, the newly-married Opposition leader, Mr Peacock, is floundering in the middle, trying to reconcile the liberal and conservative forces of opinion inside and outside his party.

That type of floundering is well exemplified in the Opposition's policies on the manufacturing sector as it is in other sectors. Indeed, the Opposition's performance led the Daily Telegraph of today to come to this general conclusion in its editorial:
Where does the Liberal Party stand in Australian politics today?
The editorial continued:
Today the Labor Party represents the middle ground of Australian politics.
It further stated:
Labor Governments can be seen as actively implementing the hard decisions.
Meanwhile, the opposition partners are showing division, indecision and opportunism.

I want to demonstrate to the chamber how the Labor Government is actively implementing the hard decisions in relation to manufacturing industry policy, because there are hard decisions to be made. I guess the whole chamber can agree on the goal, which is to modernise Australia's manufacturing industrial base so that not only will it produce wealth for Australia but also it will increase employment opportunities for Australians. As we know those two things do not always go together and I will comment on that a little later. Of course, it would be better if we could have a debate in this chamber which looked at some of the causes for the declining employment and activity in the Australian manufacturing sector. We could look at an article by Gregory and Pincus under the title 'Industry Assistance' which points out:

The principal source of decline of manufacturing production and employment has been the reduction in the growth-rate of domestic demand for manufactured products. By 1977-78 the aggregate domestic demand for manufactured products had yet to reach the 1973-74 peak.

It goes on to analyse the decline in demand in the late 1970s from which as a consequence much of the decline in the manufacturing sector resulted. An analysis of that information would be extremely productive and, indeed, the Legislative Research Service of the Parliamentary Library, I have discovered, has put out a paper on policies for manufacturing industry. It, too, looks at the question of the structure of demand and states:

It is difficult to determine to what extent the slow growth in demand for manufactures in the 1970s was associated with generally depressed economic activity, on the one hand, and faster growth in demand for services relative to manufactures on the other.

These are all points which we would have to consider and debate if we were to have a rational discussion in this chamber. But since the challenge has been thrown out that this Government has done nothing and is in confused disarray in relation to its manufacturing policy, I think the Senate ought to take note of what we have actually done and what, even in recent weeks, we have signified that we intend to do. When that is done-when I discharge my duty in that respect -it will be seen that the matter of public importance proposed for discussion has no substance.

Protection is not a panacea. We have nevertheless said that in the situation in which we find ourselves, in the current economic circumstances, although scheduled planned phased reductions in protection are to continue for those industries which are assisted and in relation to which those arrangements have been undertaken over the years, we will make no reduction in protection in other areas. That sort of assurance has been provided by this Government. On the other hand, the procedures in relation to temporary assistance and the anti-dumping procedures which are also of importance in protecting Australian industry against unfair competition have, it has been acknowledged, been streamlined in an efficient way. It is not an entirely satisfactory way but there never will be an absolutely timely way of enabling the Government and indeed the effective manufacturing industry in Australia to react to a threat of dumping or actual dumping on our market. Nevertheless, we have attempted to streamline those procedures. But to talk about all those sorts of measures in relation to protection and anti-dumping procedures and so on is-and I concede this-to still talk in negative terms.

One can go on. In certain sectors, in relation to major manufacturing sectors, we have taken definite steps. Of course, the steel industry plan announced on 11 August comes immediately to mind. We had some discussion of this in the chamber a month or so ago. It is quite clear that under that plan-and only because of that plan-BHP has been enabled to put funds into the capital works necessary for that industry to be sustained as a feature of Australia's manufacturing base. In that way also, the sustenance has been provided for whole communities, whole cities, dependent on the viability of the steel industry and, therefore, of course, the employment basis of those areas. The challenge was put out that our policies have created unemployment in this area of manufacturing. That is a very clear instance where, at a cost to the Australian community through the provision of protection measures which nevertheless did not fully meet the demands of BHP management, the employment base in those cities has been guaranteed but not in total as it stands now. There will be a decline; we acknowledge that. But at least some viability has been secured. In doing that, of course, there was considerable agreement with the trade union movements to increase productivity above the Australian average.

As I mentioned in my opening remarks, the creation of viable manufacturing industry does not necessarily mean the creation of ever escalating numbers of people employed in that industry. With increased productivity and growing capital intensity in those establishments it is quite clear that wealth and activity can be generated without necessarily creating further and greater employment. Therefore that again, to some extent, is a holding operation. But at least it has to be acknowledged-I believe the Opposition in a fair-minded way would acknowledge it-that we saw what had to be done. A steel industry plan was produced. I believe it was timely that it be done. Senator John Button is to be given credit for bringing it about. No other Australian government had ever done so.

To be positive, what the Australian people need, and I think rightly demand, of the national Government is the provision of such legislative and administrative measures and structures within which new industries can flourish and prosper in the manufacturing sector. Only yesterday my colleague, Senator Maguire, pointed out to the chamber that it is the new small businesses, particularly those utilising our skills of intelligence and enterprise, which will generate the gains in employment in this sector in Australia in the future. Not merely to hold current levels of employment as the previous measures I have mentioned might be seen to be trying to do, but actually to create employment, we need establish those new dynamic small industries, businesses and firms which have the enterprise, the high technology and the utilisation of Australia's highly educated and skilled population as their primary raw materials.

Positive industry development measures being undertaken by this Government will encourage higher levels of employment in such industries. I mention some of them . With regard to investment, we have said that this ought to be put in place. We have put in place improved systems of depreciation. These were outlined in June this year and, of course, the investment allowance was retained at 18 per cent. Very importantly, the Australian Industry Development Corporation will have its ability to provide finance in industrial restructuring and development greatly improved.

Only on Friday of last week, on 16 September, the additional financial support and the expansion in the powers of the Australian Industry Development Corporation were announced by the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button. Of course, this will enable the AIDC to invest in any industry in a much more efficient and productive manner than has been the case hitherto. We have increased the authorised capital for the AIDC from $100m to $150m. We have placed upon it an obligation to give priority to financing manufacturing industries. I think Senator Peter Rae would acknowledge that that improved financial base and the setting of clear priorities for and obligations on the AIDC can only help the development of new and improved technological industries and the general manufacturing industry in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the point was that, without confidence, it won't do it.

—But how do we get the confidence? We will not get the confidence, I agree, by merely having yet another Government injection of funds into some obscure quango. What one needs to generate confidence in the business community, I imagine, is the establishment at the head of such organisations as the AIDC of those with great corporate executive experience. In Sir Gordon Jackson, as Chairman of the AIDC, I believe the Government has such a person. In fact, Sir Gordon at the launching of this new phase of the AIDC's fortunes, on Friday, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Given this new encouragement by the Government and the charter and some extra support in financial affairs I am very confident the AIDC will serve the country very well.
He said that the new arrangements in relation to the reserves of the AIDC:
will release significant funds-like $67.5m-for the proper purposes of the corporation.

I have spent a little time on that aspect because, as I say, it is only as recently as Friday that that initiative was announced. A further very positive initiative, of course, has taken place in relation to the creation of a capital venture market for the encouragement of high technology industry in Australia. Honourable senators will know that this flows largely from the report of Sir Frank Espie, Chairman of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences, who indicated to the Government what it ought to be doing and what it ought to have been doing to achieve the sort of investment in high technology enterprises in Australia that we all desire. The Melbourne Herald, in its editorial of 2 May 1983, said:

Australia is losing ground in economic and job growth and is being overtaken by smaller and less naturally well-endowed nations, because of our lagging pace in the international pursuit of new technology. The position is not merely worrying but critical.
We have worried about it and we have taken the hard decisions which were needed to respond to that analysis.

TALK.START.PARA: —To be fair, we established the Espie Committee.

—The previous Government did establish it, but this Government has taken the decisions which, as I said, mean that in these difficult times for the financing of government programs we have agreed to forgo $20m a year in tax revenue in order to generate some $40m for investment in high risk industry ventures. If one had time, one could outline the establishment of the management and investment company licensing board scheme whereby the program will be administered. Under that scheme licensed management and investment companies will be able to claim a 100 per cent tax deduction in the year of the subscription.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that in the fields of manufacturing, computer software, consultant engineering services, scientific and technical services and data processing services, to name just a few, technology companies by their very nature-they operate at some risk, and certainly without the benefit of venture capital they cannot flourish-will now be heartened by this Government's action. As I have pointed out in relation to Senator Maguire's contribution yesterday, we believe that it is in relation to this newly expanding sector of the manufacturing industry in Australia that the new skills and innovations which are available in the Australian community will be brought together with capital in such a way that would generate productive new enterprises and employment for the Australian people; not that, of course, the manufacturing sector will be a huge employer of Australians in the future.

We cannot generalise absolutely. Indeed, I acknowledge that Senator Rae in his remarks said that in quite a cross-section of manufacturing industry some new jobs are being created and old jobs are being filled even now. I have pointed out that in relation to the old established industries in Australia we are taking measures. We have taken hard decisions to hold employment within those industries to the best of our ability. Of course, market forces cannot be constantly resisted. They will eventually erode employment even in some of those traditional industries which we are holding together at the moment. It is in relation to new industries that the initiatives of the Government are to have, I believe, in the years to come their greatest impact. Certainly, they show a determination to create in the manufacturing sector, as it ought to develop in Australia, a competitive base-export orientated where possible-such that we can confidently say that manufacturing industry in Australia will still have a place in our general economic growth and development.

Far from there being a divided and confused approach, I believe that the decisions I have outlined show that the Cabinet has indeed worked very well, in harmony with the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button). In our seven months in office, as opposed to the seven years' inadequate administration by the previous Government, we have begun to take those decisions which will ensure the continuance and strengthening of manufacturing industry in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance states:

SPEECH.PARA: The adverse impact on employment of the Government's broken promises and the total confusion caused by this divided Government's public disarray over its manufacturing industry policy.

On the matter of Australia's industry protection policies, we have been treated to a number of statements and policy decisions since the election of an Australian Labor Party government in March by various Ministers, including the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself, and a variety of statements from the trade union movement on the same subject. The problem for Australian industry which these statements and decisions have caused is that-this is quite clear from the public disagreement between the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) which surfaced recently-this Government does not have a single intelligible policy on which Australian industry can plan its future strategies. The Australian Labor Party, while new in its flirtation with business, needs to learn one important and fundamental principle of economic planning. Industry needs to be able to plan, with confidence, certainty and stability in the Government's policies.

I take up one small area of particular inconsistency, that of the developing country preferences. The Government has received three reports on the impact of the developing country preferences on local industry. Because the matters were examined by the Industries Assistance Commission on a case by case basis, the Commission's recommendations, of course, varied dependent upon the circumstances and the facts presented before it. The first related to power transformers of the kind used in the generation and distribution of electric power. In this instance, the developing country preference had applied to South Korea and Taiwan. The IAC recommended that, since the preference was not causing or threatening injury to Australian industry, it should continue. The Government rejected that recommendation and withdrew the developing country preference for transformers, as, of course, is its right.

The IAC produced a similar report on gelatine for which a developing country preference has applied to Brazil. It recommended, in similar terms, that the preference continue to apply. The Government also again decided to ignore that recommendation of the IAC, and it discontinued the preference, again as is its right. Finally-this is my third example-the IAC reported on sodium and potasium alkylzanthates, for which a developing country preference was being accorded to Yugoslavia and the People's Republic of China. In this case the IAC suggested that the preference was causing harm to a variety of Australian suppliers and should be withdrawn. Once again, the Government ignored the recommendations of the IAC and decided that the developing country preference should continue. In relation to the third case, Australia's only producer of alkylzanthates, Union Carbide Australia and New Zealand Ltd and three suppliers of raw materials to Union Carbide-namely, Stauffer Chemical Co.
