(Aust.) Pty Ltd, ICI Australia Ltd and CSR Ltd-all submitted that the developing country preference be removed. Their reason was that the production of alkylzanthates had declined markedly in 1981-82 and that in the first nine months of 1982-83 imports had increased from virtually nil to about 10 per cent of the local market which this year is projected to be of the order of 3,000 to 4,000 tonnes. The effect of this increased import penetration on Union Carbide has been significant. Employment has been reduced, and the company has changed from a seven-day roster to a 10 days on, four days off shift arrangement. As well, company profitability has declined dramatically according to confidential information which has been provided to the IAC by Union Carbide. That, of course, represents a further threat to the employment levels of that industry.

The point is not that the Government disagreed with the recommendations of the IAC but rather that on the one occasion that it was demonstrably clear that local industry was being disrupted, its profitability damaged and employment seriously jeopardised, the Government chose apparently to change course completely. How, in those circumstances, can business have confidence? How can it be expected to embark on new investment? How can it be expected to risk new labour intakes, particularly with the new and disastrous severance arrangements which apply to employees whose sevices are terminated? The situation in applying developing country preferences is illustrative of the overall confusion in the Government's policy towards industry protection. The Minister for Industry and Commerce, in his address to the National Economic Summit Conference, described the Government's role thus:
. . . to lay down the broad parameters which provide continuity and certainty.
The Minister went on to describe structural problems in Australian industries, some of which he said:

. . . are sheltered from international competition, or sometimes from any competition at all, seek or obtain profitability levels or asset gains which are unattainable in industries that have to compete internationally, or seek to obtain wages and conditions that set unrealistic community standards.

That in itself is a correct statement. Successive governments have allowed industries to get fat, inefficient and incompetent and have continued to cave in to unrealistic wage demands. They then turn to the taxpayers, through the Government, for further protection to overcome their own shortcomings. All of that is true. If that is the Government's attitude on the matter, the official line, there have been some remarkable variations. The Minister for Foreign Affairs referred recently to various forms of protection 'which are, in fact, embalming geriatric industries in a formaldehyde of protection'. On 13 September the Minister for Industry and Commerce described those comments as 'couched in colourful language', adding that the Government's policy was for no general reduction in protection in the present climate and a longer term restructuring of industry, of which reduction in protection would be part. This is a clear contradiction of the comments of the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Clearly, it was his intention to distance himself from his Foreign Minister's comments, which could only be interpreted as a call for the lowering of protection.

The next day the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) bought into the argument with the statement that Australia was one of the least protective countries in the world, and that protection was the only hope migrants had, for example, to find work in manufacturing, to which, he added, most migrants were forced to turn to find any employment at all. Obviously the Minister for Trade was setting out to put Mr Hayden right with his contradictory statement. Mr Hayden confirmed that by later saying that he had been chastised for his comments. The honourable member for Burke, Dr Theophanous, who is the Chairman of the Caucus Industry Committee, put in his bit for the Labor back bench with the comment that reductions in protection would have dire employment consequences for Australia- he did not say whether that would occur in the long term or the short term-which is the Government's feeble attempt to explain the clear differences in opinion amongst its Ministers on this matter. He simply stated the equation between jobs and protection which was supported also by the Australian Council of Trade Unions at its recent Congress. Our economy cannot afford the luxury of jealousies and rivalries between senior Ministers of Government seeking to settle old scores. It reminds me of the Whitlam years, when every Minister was a public authority on every other Minister's portfolio.

I turn for a moment to the ACTU. The ACTU has been pressuring the Government to adopt a more interventionist approach to the economy, in line with the prices and incomes accord. That accord states that comprehensive interventionist policies are necessary to restore employment, with the main thrust being in the area of manufacturing activity. It goes on to say that neither the current situation nor expected future trends justify reductions in protection. In other words, in the long term, contrary to the views of Senator Button, there should be continuity, interventionist policies and no reduction in protection.

In ratifying the South Pacific Forum communique, the Prime Minister said that he endorsed in principle the lowering of tariff barriers to promote regional trade-adding, of course, to the mayhem-notwithstanding the Government's decision , in respect of developing countries, and the fact that preferences for Taiwan, South Korea and Brazil had just been revoked.

In an answer which the Minister for Industry and Commerce gave to Senator Peter Rae on 24 May he highlighted the fact that manufacturing's share of total employment had declined from 27 per cent to 18 per cent in the last 15 years. Although he did not go so far as to accept this projection, he added that the view was held in quarters that it would decline to about 12 per cent by the turn of the century. So much for the Government's plans for restructuring business confidence within the community. These statements are in direct contrast to the prices and incomes accord and subsequent statements from the Government. It is no wonder that business in Australia is in total confusion. It is no wonder that industry is not investing and is continuing to retrench staff at an increasing rate.

The most recent economic outlook survey of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and the National Australia Bank shows no increased optimism in industry about the levels of investment for plant and equipment. This document was published in August 1983. In both the March and June quarters only 21 per cent of respondents anticipated an increase in investment. When we set that against the fact that since this Government came to office the number of participants in the labour force has fallen by 116,000 persons and the number of people who are actually employed has fallen by almost 40,000, it becomes clear that this confusion is having a very real effect on the lives of ordinary Australians. It becomes clear that, despite the veneer of the National Economic Summit Conference, consensus has given way to uncertainty and confusion, and that is being mirrored in the investment and employment profiles of Australian industry.

The Government has prided itself on its ability to bring down interest rates. This is the latest good news. The Government is shamefully taking credit for stagnation. All that demonstrates is that the banks are flush with money in the form of savings and capital accumulations from private individuals and companies which in turn anticipate further high inflation and which, therefore, are not investing to create opportunities in order to protect themselves from this Government's induced inflationary situation. This Government is so convinced that inflation will continue at its present high levels that it has indexed its excises so that it can reap the revenue benefits. It is convinced of that scenario because its own Budget policies have a severely constricting effect on business which runs directly counter to the expectations which the Australian Labor Party created during the election campaign. The former Leader of the Opposition in his policy speech said that a Labor government would follow policies aimed at 'widening of opportunities for borrowing by business, farmers and home buyers, and providing support for private sector investment'. The Treasury's assessment of the projected $8.5 billion deficit demonstrates what a cruel deception that promise has turned out to be. I refer to page 70 of Budget Paper No. 1. The Treasury warned:
The current fiscal stimulus--
of course, it was referring to the Budget deficit-
is large by any standards.

The effect is that, if there is an upturn in private sector investment at the same time as this increased pressure which is already being applied for funds to cover the deficit, interest rates and, by implication, inflation will once again rise dramatically. According to the Treasury, the Government has pinned its hopes on its ability to finance increased public sector requirements without affecting interest rates. The Budget statements say that this assumption rests largely on the projected weak private sector demand for capital, and warns:
Unless these possible consequences are contained, the potential advantages of a world upturn to Australia could then be lost and the prospect of sustained recovery further imperilled.

To boil that down into its simplest form, what Treasury is saying is that this Government's Budget strategy is underpinned by a belief in no improvement in the private sector. If the Government is wrong the effect will be to choke off any tendency for recovery in private sector activity. Once again, the confusion created by the Government in its policy statements and decisions, both before and since the election, will have contributed in no small measure to that situation. The Labor Party promised easier access to funds for the private sector, which is the main source of employment for Australians. Instead it has pursued budgetary policies that will ensure that any investment capital that might become available is either left redundant through uncertainty in the business sector or taken up by the Government seeking to fund its extravagant spending requirements.

Of course, business has other reasons to be disappointed that what the Government says is not what the Government does. For example-I will cite only one instance-the former Leader of the Opposition, in his policy speech, promised faithfully that the current accelerated depreciation allowance would be retained . For farmers investing in primary production plant, that promise was kept a mere two months until the economic statement of 19 May. The three-year depreciation period which had been put forward by the previous Government was scrapped because it was, in the words of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), 'beyond what is reasonable'. How much better it would have been, if the Government was seeking to create an environment in which industry could plan its investment strategies with safety and with certainty, to make that position clear from the outset. It is yet another example of the Government's lack of direction in industry policy, despite the impression that the prices and incomes accord somehow represents the guidelines for the actions of the Labor Party.

More importantly, from the recent experiences in the building industry, the iron ore industry in the Pilbara and the food processing industry, to name but a few, it is clear that the prices and incomes accord can do nothing to prevent the excessive demands for increased wages and shorter hours which largely underlie our present inflation. This Government is not addressing that situation . It is exacerbating the problems by failing to give industry a clear understanding of the direction of its policies. In that environment there is only one course which business can take, and the most recent employment figures demonstrate that quite clearly. So long as the Government fails to get its act together that situation can only continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the way this matter of public importance has been framed surprising. I find the subject chosen breathtaking. That the Opposition should wish to criticise this Government on employment lost in the manufacturing industry is simply incredible. I think it would have been better for the Opposition to wait for some time and hope that the electorate would have forgotten the Opposition's record in this area. It was a record of disaster over the seven years that it was in government. It resulted in record levels of unemployment. Month after month in my previous employment I monitored the economic indicators as they were published under the previous Government. They got worse and worse and in no area was the situation more severe than in manufacturing. The position became worse every month. It was the worst record of any government in this country in relation to secondary industry. The Opposition must be desperate even to contemplate debating this subject. The Opposition talk of broken promises was simply amazing. It would take all afternoon to read into the record the broken promises of the previous Government over its seven years in office.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a significant element, the so-called 'dries', in the previous Government. They believed in restrictive monetary policy and essentially in free trade. They typically came from the resource exporting States of Queensland and Western Australia. They seemed to have had a disproportionate impact on policy development under the previous Government which, had it been carried through to its fullest, could have resulted in major reductions in Australia's industrial base. It could have resulted in de-skilling. It is important to note that our secondary industries and our manufacturing industries are important repositories of skills. Those skills could have been lost had the so-called 'dries' carried the day completely. States like my State of South Australia and Senator Rae's State of Tasmania were placed at great risk by those policies. Both those States rely significantly on manufacturing employment and both saw large losses in manufacturing employment over recent years. My State was almost brought to its knees by the sheer reduction in manufacturing employment from about 1980.

The record of the previous Government in employment was so bad that no other government in the history of Australia can compare with it. For example, in the 12 months to May this year 143,000 jobs were lost nationally. Of that 143,000 jobs, 93,000 were lost in the manufacturing sector alone. So the vast majority of employment lost in this country over the last 12 months came from the very sector that Senator Rae is now proudly championing. Manufacturing employment lost 93,000 jobs in total over the last 12 months and dominated the decline in employment in Australia. In my State we saw the steel industry reduce employment ; we saw retrenchments in the motor vehicle industry; we saw retrenchments in white goods and we saw retrenchments in other home appliance industries. The list goes on and on. Basically, those retrenchments were the result of national economic policies. All of those industries were decimated as economic activity fell. The problems were compounded by imports increasing.

Whole sectors of the Adelaide metropolitan area were plunged into gloom as a result of the policies of the former Government in respect of manufacturing industry. There were severe local multiplier effects on service industries and loss of hope as unemployment rates in local areas soared towards 15 and 20 per cent. Nationally we saw a quarter of a million increase in unemployment over the last 12 months-from a 6.6 per cent rate in May last year to 10.3 per cent in May this year. That is an appalling record. It was the largest single increase in unemployment in this country in a year. We saw cost levels rising at very rapid rates. We had inflation at double digit levels. Our inflation rate was double that of our trading partners. No wonder manufacturing industries in this country were in such severe difficulty. Yet the Liberals repeatedly claimed to be competent economic managers. They went to the public repeatedly claiming that they could wave the magic wand and regulate the economy and create high levels of employment. They made those claims and those claims were proven to be patently false.

In Government, the Australian Labor Party has indicated its attitude to protection by its actions to date. We believe in assisting industry and preserving jobs. That sort of belief did not seem to get put into practice in the latter half of the 1970s. This Government will not contemplate scaling down protection in recession. We devalued the dollar soon after coming to office. It was a long overdue move. It gave added protection to the Australian manufacturing industry which had been under cost pressure because, as I pointed out earlier, our inflation rate under the former Government was double that of our trading partners. Import competing industries were suffering enormous difficulties. We saw a 30 per cent decline in job vacancies last financial year under the previous Government and a large increase in bankruptcies. Those sorts of trends should be stabilised by the policies initiated by the present Government.

We have announced in the Budget an expansionary program which will put some $2, 600m more into the economy than in the last financial year. There should be a 3 1/2 per cent growth in labour productivity which will add significantly to business profitability and give manufacturing industry a breathing space. We have announced significant increases in industrial research and development incentives from $52m last financial year to $71m this financial year. That is a 35 per cent boost in those outlays. We have increased grants for research and development projects. Australia lags behind in research and development. That is one of the key reasons that manufacturing industry in this country has experienced difficulties. Our research and development efforts have been very mediocre compared with the standards of the other industrialised countries. One of the causes of that problem is the high reliance in this country on foreign investment. The large corporations that have tended to dominate sectors of our industry have tended to do research in their parent countries. The research has not been done in Australia. The research that has been carried out here has been to scale down overseas technologies which have not been highly appropriate for our country.

The Labor Party has announced a plan to protect the steel industry. We are providing bounties this financial year amounting to $30m to protect the steel industry, with a ceiling under the program of $70m. That should help stabilise employment levels in the industry. It will certainly make protection more visible than under traditional measures. The great advantage of bounties is that they avoid costs being pushed on to the using industries-those industries producing fabricated products from steel.

The Government is encouraging the development of a venture capital market in Australia to provide capital for high risk areas such as advanced technology. The cost to revenue of this program should be of the order of $20m. As it involves taxation subsidies, the total extra funds available should be of the order of $40m for the development of venture capital markets. We have actually increased funds to the Australian Industry Development Corporation by $12 1/2m. That will enable the Corporation to lend more funds to industry. The major boost in housing outlays in the Budget will have flow-on effects to manufacturing industry. Of the 30,000 extra jobs to be created in Australia this financial year as a result of the housing package, a significant number will be in manufacturing industry. Those industries-such as the timber industries of South Australia-produce building materials and fittings. As new dwellings are completed, new appliances will be in demand. All of those industries will receive major boosts from the increased allocation of funds to housing. The Government has taken other measures to boost manufacturing industry. We have had discussions with timber exporters in New Zealand to hold down timber exports to Australia. Those exports were hitting timber milling industries severely and, through negotiations by this Government, there has been some resolution of the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., pursuant to sessional order the Senate will now proceed to deal with Questions without Notice.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister aware that, at a public rally at the Melbourne Town Hall on Tuesday, some 2,000 pensioners met to protest the new assets test and passed the following resolutions--
—Were you there?
—In spirit. The resolutions are as follows:

QUESTION.PARA: 1. That a Senate committee provide an in depth review of all matters relating to retirement income security, and

2. That until this committee tables its report, no legislation be passed by the Senate relating to changes in retirement tax or social security legislation, particularly asset and means testing legislation.

In view of the widespread opposition-of which this Melbourne meeting was characteristic-that has arisen from the constant confusion and anxiety that the Government persists in creating by its unco-ordinated changes to retirement income policy, will the Government take heed of these resolutions passed at the Melbourne meeting and, pending the Social Welfare Committee's report, defer the proposed legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I was aware of the meeting held on Tuesday. I had not had the motion referred to by Senator Jessop brought to my attention. But I would imagine that that is the sort of motion that would come from that meeting as it was organised by the Australian Retired Persons Association-an organisation closely allied to friendly societies, an organisation with six directors and also closely allied with Australian Retired Persons Association Services, an organisation which in recent years has accumulated some $70m worth of funds of retired people in this community, invested in its own friendly society, an organisation which, in its own words, does not represent the pensioners of this country but, to quote the gentleman who came to see me, 'represents a better class of people'.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Retired Persons Association is opposed to the introduction of an assets test, as one would expect it to be. The Association came into existence in order to circumvent the income test which was presided over by the previous Minister for Social Security, in order to promote contrived schemes whereby people with very large assets holdings were in fact able to receive full pensions and full fringe benefits to the disadvantage of those who are on small weekly superannuation payments or who have no assets at all. The organisation is in fact not supported by any other pensioner organisation in this country. If he wants a balanced view on the assets test, I suggest that Senator Jessop read the latest edition of the Australian Pensioner which takes a careful and cool look at it, not in the atmosphere in which I understand it was looked at during the meeting to which he referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer . Has the Minister seen page 38 of the latest edition of the London-based Standard Chartered Review, in which it is stated that the Hawke Government's economic policies are assisting in changing the trend in economic activity in Australia from one of rapid decline to one of modest growth? Will the Minister say whether any other well-respected international business journals have similarly expressed confidence in the Hawke Government's economic strategy?

—I was not aware of the particular reference in the London Standard Chartered Review which was quoted or paraphrased by Senator Foreman. I am not, of course, surprised that such an assessment would have been published in the London Standard Chartered Review or any other reputable economic comment journal in the world which chose to comment on the state of the Australian economy. It is of course a conclusion which anyone who has looked at the way this Government has acted since it has been in office must come to and in particular, of course, in contradistinction to the Government which it replaced--
—Discredited.

—Particularly in its dying days when the discredited former Prime Minister was running amok with the cheque book with the full support, of course, of the discredited former Treasurer and the discredited present Leader of the Liberal Party. They were running amok with the cheque book at a time when they knew that a $9.6 billion deficit was staring them in the face for the financial year which has now commenced. It is well appreciated in Australia and overseas that fiscal responsibility and fiscal control have been restored in Australia by the new Government, in marked contrast to the discredited Government which it has replaced. I am not at all surprised that the London Standard Chartered Review has written in those terms.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security whether he is aware that officers of his Department are advising people that in relation to farms the conditions of the old means test will apply and only the homestead and one acre' s curtilage will be exempt from the new tax. If this advice is correct, does the Minister recognise the inequities and hardship that it has the potential to create? Does the Minister agree that a retired couple on a farm will not, under the proposed test, be able to give the property to their son and that, if the son cannot afford to buy the farm, both sides will be penalised?

—No, I was not aware that officers of my Department were giving such advice to pensioners or to people about to retire. If they have done so, they are not correct. We are at the moment, as I have said many times in this place, finalising, in consultation with pensioner organisations, and I hope in the near future with the farmer organisations, this matter-which I have conceded is difficult-of people who retire on farms, particularly when that farm is run by someone else. It is not true to say that under the previous assets test only one acre's curtilage was taken into account. In fact, the amount of land was variable. It depended on where it was, what it was valued at and its type. These judgments were made by valuers. Farmers in those days were in a situation where they could not really appeal against such valuations. At least under the assets test, when it is introduced, they will be able to appeal through the system of administrative appeals that we have. The simple fact of the matter is that we have not yet finalised the legislation and the assets test will not come into effect until a year after the legislation has been introduced. We will arrive at a satisfactory solution to the problem of those who retire on farms. Any advice given to anybody about firm rulings in that area is wrong. I will make inquiries to see whether officers of my Department in some outlying areas have been giving that advice and, if so, will correct it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. A recent report of changes in processes for certification of mutton suggests that this may have a favourable effect on the exports to Muslim countries. What are the implications for the meat industry generally and for live sheep exports in particular?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that, as from 24 August, a new system of producing and certifying Australian export meat as suitable for Muslims-what is known as halal slaughter-has been developed in consultation with the Australian Muslim community, overseas customers and the meat processing industry. Incidentally, the new system is consistent with the recommendations of the inquiry conducted by the respected former member for Wakefield, Mr Bert Kelly, into the meat industry scandal-the Committee of Inquiry to Examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection Systems-which found among other things that the then Minister for Primary Industry had been negligent in his duties. The response of the then Prime Minister to his finding, I observe for the record, was to attack the integrity of Mr Kelly, whom he himself appointed and who, of course, as I said before, was a long-standing and highly respected member of the Liberal Party and the Federal Parliament. He was respected by both sides. Of course the response of the Prime Minister at the time, as was usual and customary, was to jump to the defence of the National Country Party regardless of how culpable National Country Party Ministers were.

ANSWER.PARA: On 19 September, the present Minister for Primary Industry announced details of the introduction and operation of the new system which will apply from January 1984. One of its major features is that it does not provide for a monopoly of certification by any particular Muslim body or Muslim representative within Australia. The predictable effects of the new system, insofar as they make Australian slaughtered meat more acceptable for those countries which have strict views about slaughtering procedures and the halal method being scrupulously followed, will be that it will assist in the sale of Australian carcass mutton and carcass lamb in Muslim countries, with consequent beneficial effects on employment in Australian abattoirs and the meat processing and packing industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, follows his answer yesterday to Senator Chipp on a similar subject. The Minister in his answer gave as justification for United States bases in Australia that they contribute to a deterrence policy. Does the Australian Government endorse a deterrence policy? Is the Government now aware that technological developments in nuclear weapons over the last decade have led to an abandonment of the deterrence policy by the United States and the adoption of a first strike nuclear war fighting strategy as outlined in United States Presidential Directive No. 59? Does the Government accept that by hosting fundamentally important United States bases it is endorsing a first strike nuclear war fighting policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The concept of effective deterrence requires that a nation retain forces sufficient to respond to any potential aggression in such a manner that costs to the aggressor will substantially exceed any possible gains the aggressor might hope to achieve, thereby deterring it from attacking in the first place. As the Minister for Foreign Affairs indicated in his Evatt Memorial Lecture recently, the Government supports the concept of stable mutual deterrence, understood in those terms. Of course the Government is aware that there have been substantial technological developments in nuclear weapons since the early 1960s. United States Government spokesmen, including President Reagan, have stated repeatedly over a number of years that United States defence policy is based on the maintenance of a strong deterrence to deter nuclear war, that the United States will not be the first to use aggression and that United States strategy is defensive. Although it must be acknowledged that from time to time there have been statements from some public figures in the United States to the contrary, it is also the case that the United States has indicated at the highest level that the idea of a winnable nuclear war has no place in its strategy. The President of the United States has said that a nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought. Of course Australia agrees with that statement. It is also to be acknowledged that the Soviet Union, for its part, has publicly undertaken that it will not be the first to use nuclear weapons.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the last part of the honourable senator's question, about endorsing a first strike nuclear war fighting capacity, hosting the joint facilities which were the subject of a question yesterday in no way indicates support by the Government for a first strike or nuclear war fighting strategy. As the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister have indicated on several occasions recently, hosting the joint facilities is in accord with Australia's support for the concept of deterrence. They also assist in the process of verification that makes arms control and reduction feasible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. It refers to the poor record of tertiary institutions in making courses available to many more socially disadvantaged people within the community. Can the Minister explain what action is planned to introduce greater social equity into the enrolment practices of universities and colleges?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the assertion in the honourable senator's question that universities and indeed other institutions of higher education have a poor record with regard to access by socially disadvantaged groups to them. It is a point which I have made on several occasions on campuses. I am pleased to say that recognition of the poor record of the past is widespread now. I am hopeful for a change in this situation. The Government has taken a number of steps which ought to broaden access by socially disadvantaged groups to tertiary institutions. In particular, in the education guidelines which I issued a couple of months ago, an extra $10m was made available for 3,000 new places in tertiary education institutions, and the Tertiary Education Commission has been invited to consult with tertiary institutions and report back to the Government on how those extra places can be used largely to assist the access of groups which have been previously disadvantaged.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition to this specific proposal, the Government has stressed in the guidelines the importance of tertiary institutions themselves examining their entrance policies and being prepared to take the necessary steps to broaden the socio-economic composition of their students. As we know, universities and colleges of advanced education are autonomous institutions and the Government cannot and does not wish to interfere directly in their entrance assessment procedures. However, I believe I have made it very clear to tertiary institutions throughout Australia that it is the Government's hope and expectation that universities themselves will review their assessment procedures and will make it possible for a much wider diversity of students to have the advantages of higher education.

In particular, of course, the Government has a special commitment to improved access to tertiary education by Aboriginal students. In pursuing that particular commitment, we have also made available 100 new scholarships for adult Aboriginal teacher trainees, with an allowance paid at a much higher level for them in recognition of the fact that adult Aboriginal teacher trainees, usually have dependants-children and a spouse-by the time they undertake teacher training. We hope that that 100 scholarships will be the first significant step towards our objective of achieving, by 1990, 1,000 trained Aboriginal teachers. Other areas in which the Government is concerned include improved access by women and by some ethnic groups, but I think that by now I have given at least a summary answer to the question asked by Senator Elstob.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I ask whether he recalls stating during the hearings of Estimates Committee B that a working party of officials from the Treasury, the Australian Taxation Office and the departments of Finance, Social Security, Prime Minister and Cabinet, and Veterans' Affairs had been established prior to 19 May 1983 to examine retirement income policy and that it produced a number of options, including some relating to asset testing? If so, how does he reconcile his statements with those of his colleague, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who told Estimates Committee F that such a working party did not exist prior to the 19 May economic statement and that officers of his Department did not participate in any such group? I ask the Minister: When was the working party established? What did it study? What did it recommend? When did it report? If the Minister or his colleague is mistaken, what other mistakes will they own up to in the making of their whole retirement income policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Messner asks a question in several parts. He asks whether I remember making a statement that a working party, as he describes it, was established before 19 May. I do not recall making that specific statement. I certainly do recall mentioning such a working party. I am unsure of the date on which that working party was established. What happened with our Government is the same as what happens with every other government. Prior to the Budget we examined the options of expenditure and revenue in all areas, including my Department and the general comprehensive area of retirement incomes and retirement policy. It was out of that examination that the changes we made to the policy on age pensions arose.

ANSWER.PARA: I remember very clearly saying to Senator Messner that I thought officers from certain departments were on that working party. I also recall that I was not sure at that time of the exact departments that were involved. I believe that my officers and I said that we would check. In answer to a second question, I think we included the Australian Taxation Office, which we had not included in the first group.

There was a working party. I cannot recall at the moment just who was involved in it, but many working parties were involved in the lead-up to the Budget. I cannot remember the exact date on which that working party was set up, but I will find out for the honourable senator. The working party produced a document for the Cabinet which, among many other documents, was studied by the Cabinet in preparing the Budget. They were Cabinet documents. I think I recall Senator Messner asking whether he could have those documents. I said that that was not a matter for me; that was a matter for Cabinet. That answer stays.

If Senator Messner is to get himself into a frenzy about whether a working party was established before or after 19 May and put great significance on the fact that I may have been five or ten days out as to the date of establishment of that working party, he can do so. I do not believe that the rest of the community is interested in his nitpicking. I suppose that is the best he can do in view of his Party's lack of policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister acknowledge that the working party about which we are talking was, in fact, established before the mini-Budget, which indicates that there was a comprehensive review of policy before that date and that subsequently some other bits were added on in such an ad hoc way that it is creating confusion in the community at present?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a comprehensive review of all policies in the Department of Social Security and in every other department since 11 March when we were sworn in as the Government. That review will continue. Many parties of officials and Ministers have been working on various aspects of policy. I apologise if I cannot give Senator Messner the exact day on which any of those committees started. I dare say that, if it is so important to him, we could find out. At no stage did we make policy in the way Senator Messner suggests. Our policies were made after careful consideration both by Ministers and by working parties. The options were carefully considered, individually and together.

ANSWER.PARA: The difference between this Government and the Government in which Senator Messner was a Minister is that we have policies and we carry them out. Senator Messner has admitted in this place that the Liberal and National parties, after seven years of government and after all the changes they made to the health scheme and the social security system, still do not have a comprehensive policy on retirement. They are not willing to do the work themselves; they wanted a Senate standing committee to do the work for them. That is the difference between this Government and the previous Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. In view of the debate in recent years about the need for more access to government information, can the Minister advise on the number of requests made so far to his Department under the Freedom of Information Act? How does this compare with other departments? How many requests have been granted so far?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Maguire has asked a question relating to the Freedom of Information Act. Honourable senators who were present will recall that that legislation had a fairly long and tortuous passage through the Senate. I pay tribute to the members of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs that finally produced this effective piece of legislation. I was so impressed by the need for that information that at each of the Returned Services League of Australia congresses at which I spoke over the last few months, I urged the ex-service bodies to make known to their members through their journals the value of the Act to veterans.

ANSWER.PARA: The consequences of that, I would imagine, are borne out by figures which my Department has provided for me and which indicate that, between the time the Act was proclaimed on 1 December 1982 and 31 August 1983, the agencies within my portfolio received 1,629 requests, which represent 21 per cent of all requests to all government agencies. In fact, it represents precisely one more than the number of requests made to the Department of Social Security. The Australian Taxation Office received 1,611 requests. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs received 664 requests. The figures for all other government departments are substantially lower.

Of the 1,629 requests that my Department received, 1,473, or 91 per cent, were finalised without any delay. Information has been provided for a further 2 per cent. I think my predecessor would agree that we get many requests for information about veterans' applications for disability pensions. Since the passage of the Act, obviously many former members of the Services are availing themselves of their right to look at their files and get information.

The average time taken to respond, I am advised by my Department, has been 20 days. The legislation which we passed imposed a 60-day limit. Therefore, we have more than met our obligations in that respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security and refers to the proposed assets test and the position of holiday homes-a matter of great concern to many retired people and people approaching retirement. Can the Minister confirm that his Department is currently considering exempting a certain amount-not a percentage-of the value of a holiday home from the new test ? Is the figure currently under active consideration $15,000? By what criteria of fairness and equity does the Minister believe that this will match the exemptions of holiday homes on wheels, namely caravans, and holiday homes on water, namely boats, which may be of unlimited value and still be fully exempt from the proposed assets test?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My Department and the Government, as I have said several times in this place since the Budget, are considering all sorts of options on the exemption of holiday homes. In fact, on the night of the Budget we announced that we were negotiating in all these areas. We have made no secrets about it. I have not heard of the figure of $15,000, and I am not aware of anyone in my Department suggesting such a figure. It certainly has not been suggested to me.

ANSWER.PARA: The sorts of proposals that have been put to the Department by pensioner organisations and, I might add, by the Australian Democrats, but not by the nitpickers in the Liberal and National parties, include: First, that we might exempt holiday homes up to a certain level; secondly, that we might exempt a package composed of the value of holiday homes and caravans in a sort of recreation package; and other options of that type. We are willing to discuss the matter with those who are interested and those who are willing to put up constructive proposals. When decisions have been made after those consultations, which I think is a reasonable way to go about things, we will present the legislation to the Parliament. Senator Hamer and his colleagues, if they have no desire to take any part in discussions now, can take part in the discussions in this place during the legislative stages and nit pick all they like.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to the Alice Springs-Darwin rail link. Has the Minister anything to add to the responses he has already given to earlier questions? What is the present situation regarding the inquiry which is to be held this financial year?

—I appreciate the interest of honourable senators, particularly those opposite, because in the last few months I have been asked at least six or seven questions about the railway between Alice Springs and Darwin. Obviously, there is a great deal of interest in this chamber in the project. I indicated yesterday, I think, to Senator Foreman that negotiations were proceeding between the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory and the South Australian Premier. I am now advised by the Minister for Transport that the terms of reference for the inquiry have been agreed to by the Chief Minister, the Premier and the Commonwealth Government. The only point of contention that remains between their views and those of the Commonwealth is on the question of defence. Quite logically and properly I believe, the Commonwealth has taken the view that that is its responsibility and not a matter to be elevated to one of the principal factors in respect of the inquiry which the Government has announced will take place into the general needs of transport and communication in the Northern Territory. As late as yesterday the Prime Minister wrote to the Chief Minister confirming that if this inquiry which has been announced by the Commonwealth demonstrates that the railway will generate greater net benefits to Australia as a whole than upgrading the road-I indicated this to honourable senators opposite in reply to a question a couple of weeks ago-the Commonwealth will construct and fully fund the railway. In other words, if the inquiry shows that the railway will be beneficial to Australia the Commonwealth will accept total responsibility for it. The inquiry is designed to establish whether that is a fact. If that is established the needs of the Northern Territory obviously will be met by the Australian Government.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Is it a fact that in June of this year the then Special Minister of State, Mr Young, directed that Commonwealth departments and agencies seeking police assistance on what are called politically sensitive matters must route their requests through his office? Who is the Minister now responsible for this direction or has it been allowed to lapse? Did this direction have any purpose other than the obvious political one of hiding government embarrassments? Is not this direction a direct political interference by the Minister in the discretion of the Commissioner of Police and the Attorney-General's own discretion? What was wrong with the old system? Can the Attorney-General say whether he has given any consideration to the legality of the direction and, if so, with what result?

—I have no knowledge at all of the matters-if indeed they exist-to which Senator Lewis refers. Accordingly, I have not directed any attention, in my capacity as Attorney-General, to the legality of the course of action that he describes. I will refer the matter to the Special Minister of State and seek a reply for the honourable senator and add anything that may be required in the light of that reply.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of a recent Press report in the Age suggesting that important changes have been made in the senior personnel of the Indonesian administration in East Timor? Does this action, together with reports of reprisals in East Timor, suggest a further escalation of Indonesian military activity in this troubled country? In view of continued speculation as to when the United Nations will deal with the question of East Timor, can the Minister inform the Senate of the likely timing of this most important discussion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first part of the question, the Government has been aware of the Dutch national radio reports alleging that a state of emergency has been declared in East Timor and that the Governor, Mario Carrascalao, has been removed from power. There have also been separate reports that the military commander in East Timor, Colonel Purwanto, has been replaced. I have also seen reports in the Age carrying statements attributed to the Indonesian Embassy in Canberra. The Department of Foreign Affairs has checked these reports with the Embassy, which has advised that Governor Carrascalao remains in office but that Colonel Purwanto has been transferred to another position outside East Timor. The Government has no information from its own sources to confirm or deny those reports. The Government is naturally concerned about the build-up of Indonesian forces in East Timor and has made its concern known, at the highest levels, to the Indonesian Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government believes that, despite Fretilin's breaking of the unofficial ceasefire which had been in operation in East Timor since March, the process of peaceful contact should be resumed and given a chance to succeed. We are concerned at reports of reprisals in East Timor and we do urge and have urged the Indonesian authorities to show maximum restraint. This call is in keeping with the Government's strong support for human rights both in our region and internationally.

As to the second part of the question concerning the likely date of United Nations debate on this matter, I am able to advise the Senate that yesterday the General Committee of the United Nations, which determines the agenda for the General Assembly, agreed without dissent to defer the item on the question of East Timor until the next session of the General Assembly in 1984. I add that Australia is not a member of the General Committee and had no role in that decision. The decision to defer consideration of East Timor accords with the note that was issued by the United Nations Secretary-General on 19 August, in which he stated that in view of recent developments regarding East Timor he did not consider it opportune at this time to submit a substantive report to the General Assembly on his efforts to contribute to a comprehensive settlement of the problem. He proposed instead to submit a report next year, when the matter will presumably come on for debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Treasurer. Are the Treasurer and the Minister aware that considerable success in controlling the white collar crime of arson has been achieved in the United States following the enactment of an arson reporting immunity Bill? In view of this success will the Minister hold talks with the States and the insurance industry in order that similar legislation may be implemented in Australia to assist in combating this serious and fast growing crime?

—I am afraid that I am not able to respond in any detailed way to the question that Senator Archer has asked. I have no personal knowledge of the matter. I will refer it to the Treasurer for an answer as soon as possible.

—Has the Minister for Social Security seen an article in the Melbourne Sun of 20 September stating that cuts in the Federal Budget for home care services could force the elderly and disabled from their homes? Can the Minister say whether there is any truth in this report, and what steps is he taking to maintain the home care services and to prevent any dislocation of elderly and disabled people from their homes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my attention was drawn to the article in the Melbourne Sun in which it was reported that a representative of the Victorian Domiciliary Services Funding Group had said that expenditure in the Budget had cut domiciliary assistance considerably and that people would be put out of their homes. I think I should point out to the Senate that home care services in fact are funded under the States Grants (Home Care) Act. The Federal Government reimburses up to one-half of the State governments' expenditure in this area; so the Federal Government expenditure is triggered by, and is dependent on, State government expenditure. Domiciliary meals assistance is provided under the Delivered Meals Subsidy Act.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the States Grants (Home Care) Act initiatives for new services in fact come from local government and local organisations through the State governments . The State governments process the applications. The relevant State government departments assess whether the applications provide a useful and sensible service. On approval the payment is made by my department, the Department of Social Security, on a reimbursement basis to those State departments. So the level of Commonwealth expenditure is directly related to the level of expenditure in the States. For example, in 1982-83 the Commonwealth Budget estimate for this area was $15.85m but the actual expenditure was $17.69m, the difference being due to the fact that the States spent beyond the anticipated budget in 1982-83. In 1983-84 $19.13m is allocated for home care services and $2 .4m for welfare officers. Almost $5.9m and $1.2m have in fact been allocated to Victoria.

In the Budget the Government foreshadowed development of detailed proposals of community care in 1983-84 and work on this is progressing. As has been the case in the past, work in this area is dependent on activities in the States by State and local government bodies. It may well be that again this year expenditure will increase as it did last year. There is no chance at all that any budgetary estimate by this Government would have the dire effects predicted by the Victorian domiciliary services funding group. I presume that the group has either misread the Budget documents, that it does not understand how estimates are made in the budgetary process in this Parliament or it may have been misled by a statement of some person opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware that the Nicholas Clarke inquiry into the needs of the film archives in Australia which was commissioned by the National Library of Australia was apparently completed despite the fact that it had no input from the film industry generally? Is the Minister aware that some $15,000 was spent on this rather one-sided inquiry although no less than four detailed independent reports had previously been prepared and, I understand, rejected by the National Library because those reports recommended independence of the film archive? Can the Minister say why it was necessary for $15,000 to be spent on the Nicholas Clarke report, given the existence of other reports? Will the Government act promptly to follow the lead of other countries by establishing an independent national film archive, adequately funded and staffed with technicians qualified to restore and maintain Australia's unique and rapidly deteriorating film collection, much of which consists of chemically unstable nitrate films?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some information on the matters raised by Senator Haines has been provided to me by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment who says that he has seen a Press report on this matter and has received the recommendations of the Australian Film Institute. The implication there, I think, is that he has seen the independent Nicholas Clarke report. He says that the National Library of Australia has established an advisory committee on the national film archive and has also commissioned an independent study of the developmental needs of the archive. The reports of the committee and the study will be considered by the Council of the National Library shortly. The Minister says that these reports have not been officially released but he is aware of the views of the film industry and would not wish to comment on those views until he has received and considered advice from the Council of the National Library. So clearly the matter is under very active consideration by Mr Cohen.

ANSWER.PARA: I would like to add to the information that he has provided. The Government is very concerned about the preservation of our national film culture. We have for many years drawn attention to the deteriorating state of many of the films which are currently being held in the National Library film archive and have been in fairly continual consultation with various parts of the film industry to find the best solution to this problem. Clearly, the Minister has not arrived at that solution. But I can assure Senator Haines and other honourable senators that it is the intention of the Government to take whatever steps are necessary to preserve our marvellous film heritage for posterity.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PUBLIC BENEVOLENT INSTITUTIONS: SALES TAX EXEMPTIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which I address to the Minister representing the Treasurer, concerns the granting of sales tax exemptions for goods bought for use by public benevolent institutions. The Commissioner of Taxation has ruled, on the basis of High Court decisions, that an organisation is not a public benevolent institution unless it has as its dominant objective, both in constituting documents and in practice, the relief of poverty, sickness, suffering, distress, misfortune, destitution or helplessness. His interpretation is that these criteria rule out counselling and referral centres such as citizens advice bureaux. Since such centres do, in fact, relieve suffering, distress and helplessness and assist people to obtain relief from poverty, destitution and sickness, it would seem the ruling-
—Order! Will the honourable senator ask her question?
—I am explaining-
—Well, it is Question Time.
—The point I am trying to make is that this ruling is based on an outmoded view that 'relief' means the direct provision of material relief.
—The honourable senator has made her point. Will she now ask her question?
—My question is: Will the Government take action to remove this anomaly which denies sales tax exemption for essential equipment for vital community services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not able to say whether the Commissioner's discretionary ruling which has been given in this case includes or excludes citizens advice bureaux. I will refer that to the Treasurer and try to get an answer. If it does exclude the citizens advice bureaux, I will ask the Treasurer for any comments he might care to make on the Government's view on including an organisation such as a citizens advice bureau, something that would probably require a legislative amendment. It ought to be said that this is one of the areas in which considerable discretion is allowed the Commissioner in the interpretation of the Act. The Government is not able to direct the Commissioner to include or exclude particular organisations without specific amendments to the Act.

ANSWER.PARA: I expect that the general reason the Commissioner has taken the action he has in this area would be the fact that the so-called charitable deductions which had from time to time been allowed in the Income Tax Assessment Act had been widely abused by tax dodgers who would set up phoney schemes aimed not at helping charities at all but at evading their taxation liabilities. While in general I think there would be little disagreement with the action that the Commissioner has taken in tightening up the sorts of institutions for which deductions can be claimed, there is always, I suppose, some room at the margin to argue whether a particular organisation ought to be or ought not to be included. But, in general, there can be no doubt that these provisions had been widely abused and that tax dodgers had robbed their fellow taxpayers over a long period of many millions of dollars in revenue that ought to have been paid by them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister representing the Treasurer relates to some other reductions in government revenue which have actually been effected by the Government itself. I refer the Minister to the Government's latest Budget backdown involving last night's 43 per cent cut in the rate of excise on grape spirit. I ask the Minister: Does he know what the total loss to revenue will be from all the Budget reductions so far, taking into account the reduction in the Budget proposal for excise on fuel oil, heating oil and power and lighting kerosene at a cost to revenue of about $69m this year, or $145m in a full year, along with reductions in the rate of sales tax on swimming pools from 20 per cent to 7 1/2 per cent and the extension of sales tax exemption for piping and tubing used in buildings, fixtures, structures and other works? Does the Government know what will be the total loss to revenue so far from these changes to its Budget? Will these Budget backdowns in any way threaten the Government's strategy for economic recovery?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Estimates can be made of all the items to which Senator Chaney referred. Indeed for one of the items he gave what I believe was the official estimate of $69m. I do not know whether estimates have been made for all of the items to which he referred but from my recollection of discussions, I think the total estimated revenue forgone would be in the vicinity of $80m. With regard to the excise--
—Will you check that and let me know whether it is right?

—I will get the more accurate figures from the Treasurer. With regard to the excise on grape spirit to which he referred, one of the uncertainties in making estimates of revenue when there has been any change in taxation is the elasticity of demand for that product and also the degree to which some other taxable product may be substituted for the product on which the tax rate has been changed. There are wide differences of opinion about the elasticity of demand for the products ultimately produced from grape spirit. It has been suggested-a suggestion about which I have some reservations-that the same amount of excise will be collected from a $1.50 per litre of alcohol rate on grape spirit as from a $2.61 rate. Obviously that expectation assumes a very high elasticity of demand for grape spirit. The degree to which other alcoholic beverages which may or may not be taxable are substituted for the products ultimately made from grape spirit because of price changes up or down is another matter which has an effect on revenue.

ANSWER.PARA: In total, however, changes of that magnitude will not affect the Government's Budget strategy. In particular, I note that the most recent expectations of gross domestic product growth throughout the financial year have been revised upwards due largely to a much greater recovery in farm incomes than had been expected, the revenue effects of which, it is true, will be substantially deferred into the next year because of provisional taxpaying arrangements. That upward revision in economic growth, even though it is heavily concentrated in the farm sector, could quite easily offset the revenue losses arising from the changes to which Senator Chaney has referred.

Finally, I would like to make a comment on grape spirit excise. Some very wild assertions have certainly been made about the effect of the grape spirit excise at a level of $1.50 or $2.61, one of the most ill-informed of which appears in today's Australian in an article by John Stanford in which it is asserted that the imposition of excise at a rate of $2.61 per litre of alcohol will destroy the traditional quality wine producing districts, through what he called a heavy and short-sighted tax on added fortifying spirit. This, he said, 'could wipe out this historic region and a long tradition of quality wine making. The famous sweet dessert wines are expensive to make and require long ageing in casks.' Apparently the author of that article is unaware that until 1970 an excise on grape spirit of $2 a litre--

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr President. This is a very interesting answer which I think could usefully be made as a statement. But the senator has long since dealt with the questions which I raised and is now giving a general dissertation on one of the items which I mentioned as costing something to the government revenue.
—I thought it rather related to the question asked by the honourable senator.

—The relationship was that I mentioned that as one of the losses to revenue. I went on to ask about the total cost of those losses and the possible effect on Budget strategy. We are now getting a very long dissertation on the grounds for a particular reduction. I suggest it has nothing to do with the question.
—I think the Minister's answer has related to the honourable senator's question but I ask the Minister to be short in the rest of his reply.

—I was about to finish. The answer is relevant to the question because it concerns the effect of price changes on the elasticity of demand for products and therefore the effect on consumption of price changes. It ought to be noted that up until 1970 an excise of $2 a litre applied on grape spirit used for fortifying purposes, which if updated to present values would be in the vicinity of $8 a litre. I make the point that these historic wineries obviously survived for many decades with a very much higher levy of excise on fortifying spirit than had been originally proposed by the Government, or is now being proposed by it. It is important for a proper understanding of these matters and the effects on consumption of price changes to have such important historical facts put on the record and understood.

—As the Attorney- General has recently set up a task force to review the Racial Discrimination Act of 1975, could he indicate what steps will be taken to ensure that the views of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Island people are heard? Will the task force visit isolated communities and will it examine Press reports which are racist in their content?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The task force to which the honourable senator refers is essentially an in-house departmental group of officers seconded full time for this purpose, acting together with consultant experts in civil liberties law. It is not a fact-finding enterprise and as such it would be inappropriate, particularly within the time scales within which we are operating, to embark upon the kind of full-scale investigations to which the senator refers. However, the task force is operating in very close consultation with the Human Rights Commission, a successor organisation to the Office of the Commissioner for Community Relations, and as such there is a very large store of material available to it, as to the conditions both on the ground in Aboriginal communities and in other places where Aborigines face difficulties around Australia, together with a considerable stock of experience as to the limitations and weaknesses in the existing Racial Discrimination Act so far as enforcement mechanisms are concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not believe that we will embark upon the task of legislative reform here with anything less than full enough knowledge of the problems to get it right. The other aspects of the task force inquiry will extend to difficult policy questions like how one deals with race hatred propaganda, whether it is appropriate to relate that subject in whole or in some way to criminal offences, or whether it is better for something like a concept of group defamation to apply. It will also deal with the larger question of the interrelationship between the Racial Discrimination Act and the machinery for its enforcement with the Human Rights Commission and with the proposed new national Bill of Rights which we are hoping to introduce in the latter part of this year. I take very much on board what the honourable senator has said about the nature of the problems which must be addressed. I can assure her that they are being addressed and I hope a very satisfactory legislative solution will be the result.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON AUSTRALIA'S SECURITY AND INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the recent acknowledgment by the Prime Minister that he has issued, I think, three writs against various persons and bodies arising out of his activities concerning the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. Is the Prime Minister aware of the serious public concern that he is using legal remedies for monetary gain and to stifle legitimate public criticism of his actions at a time when he has ready access to the media and to Parliament to respond to such criticisms? Is this action not inconsistent with the Government's claim to make available and support a vigorous use of government information by the Australian public?

—The question is directed to the state of awareness of the Prime Minister about particular matters. I will convey the question to the Prime Minister and seek an early answer for Senator Missen. Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on notice.
—Since the time allotted for Question Time has not expired, I ask the Leader of the Government to allow Question Time to continue until a full hour has been taken.

—I am happy to allow further questions. I remind the Leader of the Opposition that on two occasions now I have allowed Question Time to go over an hour by up to 10 minutes. If he wants that right to be forgone in the future, I will oblige him. He can have another question if he wants it.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Can the Minister add anything further to his answer to my question last week in relation to the pipeline duty of the Victorian Government that was ruled illegal by the High Court of Australia? Can the Minister suggest what remedies may be open to the Victorian Government to solve this problem?
—I cannot pretend to give a profoundly detailed answer on this question, Senator.
—Read this morning's paper.

—I am informed by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle that it is all in this morning's paper but I did not regard that as profoundly detailed. I understand that the Victorian Government has reached agreement with Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd regarding repayment of all of the monies which were the subject of the judgment of the High Court. So far as the Commonwealth Government is concerned, because of the windfall gain, if one likes, which accrued to BHP as a result of that judgment and the consequent taxation windfall which would have flowed to the Commonwealth Government, this Government has made a concession to the Victorian Government in terms of repayment of the additional taxation which the Commonwealth Government gains as a result of that process. I am unable to elaborate any further on that. I add, by way of final comment, that negotiations regarding this matter took place with the Victorian Government over a substantial period. I think it is fair to say that both governments were pleased with the successful result of those negotiations.
