Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable senators, I present copies of the statements which Ministers have provided to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) concerning their private interests. The Prime Minister's own return is, of course, also included. I seek leave to make a statement regarding that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statements of private interests which I have presented to the Senate represent a landmark in the development of this Parliament and in the provision of information to the public about the Ministers to whom that public has entrusted the government of this country. Never before in the history of this Parliament have Ministers disclosed publicly the private interests which they hold. It is right and proper that they should do so. The public-the electors of this country-are entitled to have confidence in the integrity of their elected representatives, to know that Ministers of the Government will perform their duties without fear or favour, to be reassured that a Minister's private interests-whatever they may be-do not conflict with his or her public duties in holding the high office of a Minister in the Federal Government. With those beliefs in mind the Australian Labor Party has long held the view that public disclosure of the private interests of Ministers-and of others, to whom I shall refer later-is appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to some of the details of the system of declaration of private interests which the Government has decided upon. In respect of Ministers, there are two statements of private interests. The first is a statement in general terms of the interests held by a Minister and those of his or her immediate family-that is, spouse and dependent children-of which he, or she, is aware. It is required to be provided on an annual basis, with any significant changes in the meantime also disclosed to the Prime Minister, and will cover the following matters: Shareholdings in public and private companies, family and business trusts and nominee companies, real estate and directorships in private companies . I should make it clear that Ministers are required to resign any directorships in public companies and directorships of private companies unless, for example, such companies operate a family farm, business or investments and the retention of the directorship is not likely to conflict with the public duty of the Minister.

I mention other matters covered which include partnerships, liabilities, other than short-term credit arrangements, bonds, debentures and like investments, savings or investment accounts and other assets, including collections but excluding household and personal effects, each valued at over $5,000. All these matters will be included in the statement of interest. When we refer to assets valued at over $5,000, that refers to a collection valued at more than that sum, other than a collection used for household purposes. These will be declared as will other substantial sources of income. In relation to this aspect, I should say that Ministers of this Government may not derive any income through personal exertion other than as a Minister and a member of this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like speeches, you mean?
—Order!
—Do you agree with this?

—Yes. Other items which must be declared include gifts valued at more than $250 received from official sources or in excess of $100 from non- official sources, in accordance with agreed guidelines and sponsored travel or hospitality, other than 'guest of government' hospitality. We must bear in mind there are long-standing restrictions on Ministers in that respect. The final category is any other interests, such as membership of organisations, where a conflict of interest with public duties could foreseeably arise.

SPEECH.PARA: I have mentioned some of the particular restrictions which are placed on Ministers. So that all members of the Senate, and the public, are aware of the full extent of those restrictions I shall mention other requirements. Ministers, upon appointment as Ministers, must cease to engage in any professional practice or in the daily work of any business; nor, as I have mentioned, can they derive any income through personal exertion other than as a Minister or a member of this Parliament. Ministers have to divest themselves of shares or similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities. Ministers have to make a declaration at meetings of the Cabinet or its committees of any matter which may give rise to a conflict of interests. And, should any particular conflict of interest arise in the course of Ministers' administration of their Departments, the Prime Minister has to be informed so that a decision can be made on how the particular matter is to be progressed.

From the statements I have presented, honourable senators will see that money amounts of individual Ministers' interests-whether income, assets or liabilities -have not been included. It is the Government's belief that public disclosure of that information would be an undue invasion of the privacy of Ministers and of their families. Ministers, however, have declared those amounts to the Prime Minister in a private and confidential statement. This is the second of the statements to which I referred earlier which will also be required to be provided on an annual basis.

I turn now to provisions which might be applied to honourable senators and honourable members generally. I remarked earlier on the right of the public to have confidence in the integrity of its elected representatives. While that confidence demands particularly high standards in Ministers it also demands certain standards of each and every member of the Senate and each and every member of the House of Representatives. The Government therefore proposes that all honourable senators and honourable members should disclose by way of a public register their own private interests, and those interests of their families of which they are aware. The details to be disclosed would be no more than are in the Ministers' statements which I have presented today. In one important respect they would be much less: There would be no requirement to disclose money values at all.

The Government also proposes that the Standing Orders be amended to require all honourable senators to declare a relevant interest if they participate in a debate or vote in a division in the Senate. Standing Orders already make certain provisions in respect of committee membership where an honourable senator has a personal interest in the subject matter before the committee. It is the Government's intention that the precise method of implementation of the provisions to apply to honourable senators and honourable members be examined by the Standing Orders committees of the respective Houses, meeting as necessary as a joint committee to ensure that the provisions are as far as possible consistent between the two Houses.

In addition, it is intended that the Standing Orders Committee be asked to report upon whether, as proposed in the Bowen report on Public Duty and Private Interest, a code of conduct should apply to all honourable senators and honourable members and, if so, what form it should take and how it should be implemented. The Committee will also be asked to look at the other recommendations of the Bowen report-apart from those relating to the Constitution-affecting honourable senators and honourable members. I shall be presenting a notice of motion today giving further details and proposing referral to the Standing Orders Committee for consideration and report. One question is whether the registration system should be compulsory or voluntary. If the Senate ultimately decides upon the latter and an honourable senator refuses to provide a statement I am sure that people-especially the electors concerned-will be able to make their own judgment about that senator.

Mr President, some may argue that any system of registration of private interests should be confined to the public's elected representatives. We believe , however, that the public is entitled to have confidence in the integrity of the wider machinery of government; in the integrity of public administration generally. Therefore, the Government has decided that senior public servants, statutory office holders, senior staff of statutory authorities, and all ministerial staff will be required to furnish a statement of their private interests similar to the public statement required of Ministers-that is, containing details of the interests I mentioned earlier, but not as to their money amounts. The statements will not be public but, in the case of public servants and members and staff of statutory authorities, will be available to the relevant Minister and to the head of the department or authority concerned. In the case of ministerial staff the statements will be available to the relevant Minister, to the Special Minister of State, and to the Prime Minister. The Public Service Board or, in the case of statutory authorities, the responsible Minister, will be informing the people concerned of the requirements in the near future. The Department of the Special Minister of State will be contacting ministerial staff to the extent that their present statements do not cover the requirements I have announced today.

On such an important matter as this, I could not conclude without a reference to those who work in this building and whose task it is to report upon our activities via the media. They enjoy particular privileges and rights of access- including to the galleries of this chamber-which many other people do not. They are there, however, not only to report upon words spoken in his House but to express views and opinions on the actions and decisions of the Government as a whole, individual members, and occasionally, the Opposition. The Government therefore believes that it would be consistent with its overall approach to this matter if the Australian Journalists Association and the Federal Parliamentary Press Gallery were invited to develop a similar system of disclosure of the private interests of journalists of those media organisations accredited to or using the facilities of the Parliament, and all members of the media who have quarters in or work from Parliament House. My colleague the Special Minister of State will be pursuing these aspects in the near future.

Mr President, the Government's decisions on his matter are the culmination of the work of many people over many years. The parliamentary committee which reported in 1975, chaired by the then honourable member for Phillip, Joe Riordan , made a most significant contribution to a proper system of registration of private interests. One cannot overlook, also, the comprehensive report of the Committee of Inquiry into Public Duty and Private Interest, chaired by Sir Nigel Bowen.

The arrangements I have announced today represent a new extension in parliamentary democracy. The electors of this country have a right to be confident that those whom they send to represent them in his Parliament will do so in all matters without fear or favour. A large part of that confidence rests in the public knowledge that the private interests of the elected member-whether a Minister, a Government back bencher or an Opposition member-will not influence , nor will they be likely to influence, the discharge of his or her public duties in whatever capacity he or she may serve in this Parliament.
I seek leave to give notice of a motion.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes that Ministers have provided statements of their private interests, and those of their families of which they are aware, and that copies of those returns have been presented to the Parliament as a matter of public record;
(b) is of the opinion that all Senators should provide similar statements of their private interests, including those of their families of which they are aware, covering the following matters:
(i) shareholdings in public and private companies (including holding companies) indicating the name of the company or companies,
(ii) family and business trusts and nominee companies-
(a) in which a beneficial interest is held, indicating the name of the trust, the nature of its operation and beneficial interest; and
(b) in which the person or immediate family is a trustee, indicating the name of the trust, the nature of its operation and the beneficiary of the trust,
(iii) real estate, indicating the location (suburb or area only) and the purpose for which it is owned,
(iv) directorships in private companies, indicating the name of the company, its activities and the total amounts of its assets and liabilities,
(v) partnerships, indicating the nature of the interest, the activities of the partnership and the total amounts of its assets and liabilities,
(vi) liabilities (excluding short term credit arrangements) indicating the nature of the liability and the creditor concerned,
(vii) the nature of any bonds, debentures and like investments,
(viii) saving or investment accounts, indicating their nature and the name of the bank or other institutions concerned,
(ix) the nature of any other assets (including collections, but excluding household and personal effects) each valued at over $5,000,
(x) the nature of any other substantial sources of income,
(xi) gifts valued at more than $250 received from official sources, or at more than $100 where received from other than official sources,
(xii) any sponsored travel or hospitality received, and
(xiii) any other interests, such as membership of organisations, where a conflict of interest with a Senator's public duties could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise,
(c) agrees that a public register of Senators' statements of their private interests referred to in paragraph (b) should be established;
(d) agrees that Senators should provide such statements on an annual basis and that amended statements should be provided if alterations in circumstances occur ;

(e) agrees that notwithstanding the lodgment of statements by Senators and their incorporation in a public register individual Senators should declare any relevant interest if they participate in a debate in the Senate or vote in a division in the Senate; and
(f) requests the Standing Orders Committee to consider and report upon:
(i) what changes to the Standing Orders may be required to give effect to the matters contained in paragraphs (b) to (e), and

(ii) the desirability of adopting other provisions relating to Members of Parliament contained in the Report of the Committee of Inquiry into Public Duty and Private Interest (except constitutional matters, but including, in particular, a Code of Conduct).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I understand, from my discussion with the Leader of the Government in the Senate ( Senator Button) and from the fact that he has given notice of a motion, that there will be an opportunity, when we return to this place the week after next, to debate the very important statement which he has put down on behalf of the Government. At this stage I do not want to say anything which commits the Opposition to the terms of the statement; nor do I wish to say anything which dissociates us from it. All I wish to say at this stage is that the statement does indicate the complexity of this issue. In a sense, the complexities can be encapsulated by the question: Where does one draw the line? This statement does try to come to grips with that question in a number of ways. With respect to Ministers, for example, it tries to come to grips, of necessity and perfectly, with the question: What of the interests of Ministers' families? I think that for all Ministers there is this question of the extent to which their public life impinges upon the privacy and the separate identity and lives of their families. Yet to ignore the interests of families altogether would, of course, be to leave a potentially large gap. Quite significant and difficult questions have received some airing in Australia in the context of the concerns of a spouse of a current Minister. That is the sort of issue which does give rise to a very real difficulty in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government concluded that the line was not to be drawn at Ministers. It moved on to members of parliament. The Government then concluded that the line was not to be drawn there and was to move on to certain public servants and so on. Then the line was further examined, and we found it caught up with the gentlemen who inhabit the galleries upstairs and who comment upon the Parliament and its activities. In each of those points where one considers where to draw a line and what decision to take, there are genuine difficulties and complexities. It is true also that honest men do not need rules, and dishonest men generally find ways around them. Again that is the sort of problem which faces the Government and, of course, faces all of us who have to examine this area and determine what sorts of working rules will be adopted.

The previous Government had a requirement of disclosure from Ministers, which was a more private form of disclosure in that it went to the Prime Minister. On this occasion a limited amount of information has been made available. Certainly more has been made available by Government Ministers than would have been available on any sort of public register. I think the Opposition will welcome the 10 days or so which we have been given to consider the very significant issues which were raised by this statement, the significant issues which have been canvassed in the Bowen report and, indeed, in reports of the Parliament and in debates in this Parliament.

On behalf of the Opposition I say that there will be many in the Opposition parties who see this as being a matter of complexity involving conflicting principles between public duties and the rights and privacy of those who are related to us and so on. I welcome the opportunity which is to be provided in the next period of sittings to give some considered views on this very important matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Australian Democrats congratulate the Government and commend it for its action, which we regard as overdue and courageous. The Government can count on our supporting the thrust of what it is trying to do. As the Leader of of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) said, we welcome the 10 days which we have been given to think about the matter and to study the report of the Bowen Committee of Inquiry into Public Duty and Private Interest. At first blush we note that the report does not require a disclosure of money values at all. It may be that that is the only way of doing it. We will certainly be looking at that because it takes a lot of sting out of the thrust of this matter if senators do not have to disclose money values. There is then the problem of defining 'family'. On page 3 of the guidelines a family is defined as a spouse and dependent children. That is a very narrow definition in today's circumstances, given the legal status of de facto relationships, just to name one of the many.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems possible for honourable members and honourable senators and, indeed, Ministers, to divest themselves of embarrassing assets or debts by transferring them to close and trusted friends. Furthermore, non-dependent children who are still members of the family could be used to hide embarrassing assets and debts. These are the sorts of problems that we will be looking at, as no doubt the Opposition will be, over the next 10 days. In closing, I warmly congratulate and commend the Government for this initiative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a statement concerning sitting hours of the Senate for the next three- week sitting period. I will be very brief because I think what I have to say is already fairly common knowledge. This year, for the Government, has been a somewhat truncated year in terms of the Government's capacity to advance its legislative program, having regard to the election and the subsequent period. The whole year has been compressed somewhat. The Government has a heavy legislative program which it desires to complete at a reasonable time this year without delaying honourable senators too close to the Christmas celebrations at the end of this period of sittings. For that reason it has been decided that, in the next three-week sitting period, the Senate should sit on the first Friday and on the third Friday. That will mean that the Senate will sit for four days in those weeks. It is suggested that the Senate commence at 9 a.m. on those Fridays and conclude in time to allow senators to escape by plane to their respective parts of the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had correspondence and discussions with the Leader of the Opposition ( Senator Chaney) and the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Chipp) and correspondence with Senator Harradine about this matter. The Opposition and the Democrats have indicated their willingness to agree to this procedure subject to certain qualifications which Senator Chaney set out in a letter to me today. I have replied by letter to those qualifications and I fully respect them. It is our intention to sit on those two Fridays, that we have a Question Time of a duration yet to be decided, and then proceed to the normal legislative program. I am grateful to the leaders of the other parties for their agreement to this matter because I think it will be to the benefit of all honourable senators later in the year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I do not wish to delay the Senate unduly on this matter, but, on behalf of the Opposition , I wish to make a couple of points so that our position is quite clear. I agree that our position is broadly as has been set out by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). Of course, there has been some concern within the Opposition parties about the extension of the sitting days beyond the program which was laid down by the Government at the commencement of the Budget session. That program involved sitting hours which provided more hours per week than the traditional sitting pattern. We have accepted that. We have already publicly indicated our concern at the lack of synchronisation between the chambers and the difficulties that gives rise to. I do not wish to deal with those matters again. The Opposition continues to be concerned about the sitting pattern generally. I think it would be no breach of confidence with the Leader of the Government to say that we are jointly undertaking some examination to see whether more satisfactory arrangements can be made for next year.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the wish of the Opposition to see the orderly transaction of business in this place. I think the Parliament is meant to be a serious place of deliberation. The pressures which are often placed upon us, not least at the end of session, reduce both the efficacy and the dignity of the proceedings. For that reason I think there is a good deal to be said for providing, at this stage , in a year which is unusual and difficult, some additional sitting times, notwithstanding the inconvenience that that might give rise to. The general reservation expressed by the Opposition and on which we have received accommodation from the Government and from the Australian Democrats is that we have been anxious to avoid any suggestion that other than normal parliamentary procedures and so on should be applicable to additional sitting days. We think it is important that the traditional means open to non-government senators and, indeed, to private senators generally should be open to us whenever the Parliament is sitting. At the same time, I have indicated to the Leader of the Government that, in the spirit of our wishing to see the sensible processing of legislation, and all other things being equal, we would want to see additional time used for the purpose for which we are having the additional sittings.

I see this as what I would like to think of as a step towards a more sensible approach to the ordering of business. I hope it is a step towards getting times, days and periods of sittings which will be sensible, workable and which will add to the efficient functioning of this Parliament. I have expressed the view that Parliament could do with a few improvements. I think they can be achieved only on a multi-party basis. I do not think a Government or an Opposition alone can make the Parliament a more effective one. I welcome the opportunity to try to work with all in this chamber to achieve a better legislative program and hence a more effective Government and Opposition for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I should like to support the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, in his remarks and to compliment him and Senator Button on the way in which the negotiation to come to this arrangement took place. I am persuaded that we can solve all the procedural and other problems in this place and the administration of business if there is that sort of consultation.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention briefly in passing the incident at 11 o'clock last night. A mini- crisis developed. There were consultations between Senator Chaney and me. There was a suggestion that the debate on the Medicare legislation might be extended. There was clearly no filibuster from the Opposition side. It was a sincere debate. There seemed to be no good reason why we should have sat later last night. After consultation with Senator Chaney, who consulted his members, it was made clear that there would be no undue problem in getting the legislation in good time today. That has taken place. That is the kind of spirit which I believe should exist in this place and if it does I can see no reason for any problems later in the session. As Senator Button has said, there is an extraordinarily long list of business to go through.

I take the opportunity again of expressing our concern at what happened in May in the Senate. It will be remembered that the House of Representatives rose, I think, two weeks before the Senate. Propositions were put to us by Senate Ministers-when I say 'us' I mean those of us on this side of the chamber-that, if we amended the legislation, which was urgent, it would mean bringing back the House of Representatives. No one likes or wants to do that but I have given notice, as has Senator Chaney on behalf of the Liberal Party, that we will not hesitate to do that in the latter part of this year. As far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, if there is legislation which needs to be passed but which in our view needs amending, we will not have any hesitation in moving those amendments.

I believe that sitting on these Fridays will, to a great extent, obviate the necessity for doing that. But I do suggest to the Government that it keep a careful eye on the procedures and get those contentious Bills that it wants to get through in 1983 completed early in the piece and not fondle the hope that if it saves them up for the last week or two, those of us on this side of the chamber will weaken and say 'Okay, we will let them through', or that we will be sorry for the Government. That will not happen. Senator Chaney has said it will not happen and I remind the Government of that in a kindly way while congratulating it on this move.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I came into the chamber after this debate commenced and I do not know what is proposed. But I am impressed by the goodwill that has been expressed by all sides of this chamber. I take this opportunity in that spirit of goodwill to say that what has been proposed may facilitate the work of the Senate as a whole and also the work of the committees of the Senate. For that reason, I hope that the confrontation between the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and the Senate is suitably resolved and that in the future when leave is sought for the Committee to sit for a particular reason, leave will be granted.
—There are limits to my affability and goodwill.
—Yes, of course. I thought the affability and goodwill might prevail when I make my next request.
—The Democrats are the only friends that you have got.
—As a matter of fact, I would agree with that. I find it difficult to accept that the real support in this matter which concerns me comes from the Australian Democrats.
—You have friends on this side too.

—Of course. Nevertheless, I hope that the goodwill which has been expressed will extend beyond the Senate as a whole and to the needs of the various committees. I am at a disadvantage because I do not really know what the proposal is before the House. But I would suggest that when committees do seek leave-
—To sit for two Fridays out of the three for the last three sessions.

—Great; I do not want to destroy the goodwill that has been expressed. I will confine my remarks to what I have already said. But might I indicate that I am in a bind as far as the Senate is concerned. I have confronted the Senate with a proposition in relation to which it may need to look at the advice that we have received. I think we can avoid that if we can have some anticipation that next time we seek leave for the Committee to meet that leave will be granted. I think the goodwill that has been expressed seems to indicate that that will be the case. It will not be the case?
—I am just shaking my head ruminatively.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button)-by leave-agreed to:
That the Sessional Orders, as amended continue to apply from Tuesday, 4 October 1983, on a trial basis.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Question Time today, I was speaking in opposition to the matter of public importance brought forward by the Opposition on manufacturing industry policy. I had pointed out that the Government had taken decisive steps to reduce timber imports into Australia from New Zealand, steps which have resulted in voluntary price and quantity reductions in timber imports and stated that those measures certainly were helping to protect jobs in Australia. The Government has announced a review of anti-dumping legislation. That review began in April. A discussion paper was issued in June and in July there were meetings with interested parties. That review is nearing finalisation. There is also a review occurring of developing country preferences under the tariff system. That review has been called by the Government in response to criticisms that such preferences could be undermining local industry. In general, the Government's policy on manufacturing industry is to facilitate the modernisation of our industrial base. The policy is to provide a predictable framework for industry planning, industry investment and production decisions. The Government's priority is promotion of high technology industry and those industries which have significant growth potential. They are the areas in which Australia can generate jobs in significant quantities in future. I believe that only by getting the manufacturing sector of Australia on its feet will a general economic recovery occur. Only by boosting manufacturing can we more fully utilise the skills of our labour force and only by boosting manufacturing can inroads be made into the significant jobless totals that we have in Australia at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a fascinating debate. We have before the Senate a matter of public importance which lays the blame for the current problems in the economy and with unemployment at the feet of this Government and its broken promises. It lays the blame for the total confusion of our manufacturing industry policy also at the feet of this Government. Of course , the matter of public importance is put down by an honourable senator of the previous Government which suffered from identical problems.

SPEECH.PARA: There is division within this Government on the protection issue. I think it is fair to say that the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, a former Treasurer , who is perceived by some to have some economic knowledge, has attacked the levels of protection for Australian manufacturing industry. On the other hand, the Minister for Trade, Mr Bowen, put the alternative view that protection levels in Australia are relatively low. That is a division within the Cabinet which is blatant and obvious to the world. It is not a new division within a Cabinet, nor is it a new division within the ranks of a government. It was a feature, in fact, of the wets versus dries debate in the Liberal-National Party coalition Government and it was also a cause of dispute between the Liberals and the National Party, which party, as we all know, favours lower protection.

The Government and the Opposition parties continue in this debate to create this uncertainty, as they have since Federation. The problem is that the major parties do reflect the divisions in the whole spectrum of Australian society on this issue. I suggest that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) and the representative of the Opposition have a look at the one political party which is not divided on this issue, which does not have a split down the middle and which has a policy which would be the saviour of this country if the other parties were to adopt it. We have an unequivocal policy and that is because we do not have to pander to competing industry and union interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whom do you pander to?

—Only to 15 million Australians. They are the people we protect; we do not have vested funding interests to protect. The issue is not resolved by raising it again, as the coalition has done today, so that the Opposition can pretend it is not divided. We believe that all parties need to agree that protection needs to be phased out. We do not think that there is any argument there. The argument is: When are we going to start phasing it out? We need long term indicative planning on tariff policies, not more ad hockery such as we have had over the last several decades. We need that not just as a Government, as a Parliament, but because industry has to know the future tariff policies of this Government. In the long term, it would reduce and hopefully eliminate the division and confusion which exists today, because guidelines giving long term indicative planning on tariff policy would lead industry and businesses to retrain their staff. There would be justification for investing in re-education. It would lead to the restructuring of organisations, given a five to 10 year lead time, which would shift the emphasis towards sunrise industries from those industries which can now quite correctly be categorised as sunset industries. In fact, the sun should have set on some of those industries long since but they are still being supported by this Government and the people of this country. The third benefit of indicating the direction of the policy of phasing out tariffs would be that it would provide right across the nation the ability to communicate, through government to industry and to employees who again would get a feeling of security. They would know what was ahead and would not dread every Budget day that their industry might be the one that this time would get caught up in the big tariff debate.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the other part of this matter of public importance, I think it is fair to suggest-everybody from all political parties has said it-that the current rates of unemployment are a product of the world recession, are currently a product of the ongoing effects of the droughts and are a product of the failure of eight years of fiscal restraint aimed at achieving either an ' inflation reducing objective' or an 'employment objective'. I believe that the Fraser Government has to take a large part of the responsibility for the current problem. I do not mean that it is solely responsible but I do not think it can duck behind a matter of public importance, as is the Opposition's intention in this debate, and pretend that the sole responsibility lies at the feet of the current Government. The Fraser Government pursued the policy for fighting inflation first and in fact most people perceived that as its only economic goal . It used unemployment as a tool of economic policy without being concerned about the effects of unemployment on the people of this country.

Of course, as we all know, the Fraser Government's record on wages, economic growth, inflation and unemployment, have proven the fallacy of that policy. After eight years the people of Australia, fed up with that policy, with that economic approach, responded to the promises made by Labor-the promise of fighting unemployment directly, the promise of economic expansion to generate jobs and the promise of income relief, especially to low income earners, who were promised tax cuts, and to social security recipients-in order to stimulate consumption and to revitalise economic activity. That was the pre-election promise, but it is a promise that has not been kept. That is the tragedy of this current financial year for many Australians who helped to elect this Government on that promise.

Promises have already been broken. It is obvious that promises will not be kept because this Government has now pursued, albeit in a milder form, the failed Fraser recipe. The impact of this receipt on unemployment is already documented; it is in the Government's own Budget Papers. They anticipate that unemployment will rise again in this current financial year. I put that to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) yesterday and I was greeted with great derision by him despite that fact that there are highly respected economists in this country who believe that the Government could have kept its promises. I put it to this Government that it was possible to keep most of its promises, despite the huge deficit that it had inherited. The Government set up a straw man and continued to fear to go above that $8 1/2 billion deficit target. That was the target the Government set for itself-a target that it constantly preached to the people of Australia could not be exceeded, or dire consequences would result.

I would like to remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that not every Minister , not every member of the Australian Labor Party Caucus can live comfortably with the abandonment of that pre-election Labor plan for recovery. There are some very red faces, and one sees them each time the Leader of the Government or one of the Ministers in this House tries to defend the economic policy of this Government and suggest that there is no merit in following the plan that was laid out before them by the Australian Democrats to stimulate the economy, not continue with the go-slow, conservative approach of the previous Government. We need to ask why our pragmatic Prime Minister deserted his party's pre-election pledges, because a larger deficit is justified now-not next year, now. Just as it was justified before the election when Labor won votes on it, so it is justifiable right now. The money was there and it is still there. It is lying idle in bank deposits, which are at record levels. It is a sign of economic despair by the investors of this country. This Government needs to be providing work by having that money spent on a revitalised, rejuvenated economy. This Government has the power, had the power and should have used the power to provide the trigger to get this country up and going again because our economy can take the kind of expansion that such an economic approach would have given. We are working at 20 to 30 per cent below capacity, in both industry and labour. We need the stimulus that this Government could have given to the economy. Coincidentally, the economic line of the Democrats lines up very closely with the Labor Party's pre-election line. It is currently being pursued by the Victorian Labor Government which this week brought down a Budget which is expansionary and aimed at stimulating the economy in that State. The Victorian Government has made an attempt to create economic growth and jobs because it has the courage to implement the Labor Party policies which this Government, in this Parliament, failed to do.

Evidence of the similarity between this Government and the previous Government is the 1983-84 Budget which is predicated on further increases in employment and the hope that the economy will improve in the long term. Unemployment will then be reduced. That is not good enough. We have to provide that stimulus ourselves. It is up to the Government to provide it, not just to hope that it will come from overseas or even from local economic upturn as a result of good farming years or good mining years or whatever. We have to do it ourselves. This Government was given that challenge. In the long term this Government thinks that we will come out of this recession.

We waited eight years for Mr Fraser's long term recovery. Do we have to wait another eight years for Mr Hawke's long term recovery? I am reminded of Keynes's expression that in the long run we are all dead. I guess that applies to a lot of people who are waiting for a second eight-year term for the economic recovery of this country. We should aim at resolving and alleviating our problem today not tomorrow. We all know that today's biggest economic problem in this nation is unemployment. There is no relief in sight. The Labor Party promised responsible government. Instead, Labor has produced a mildly modified version of the Fraser style of responsibility. Sadly, the economic conservatives are still determining the fate of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance submitted by Senator Peter Rae which we are now considering is:

SPEECH.PARA: The adverse impact on employment of the Government's broken promises and the total confusion caused by this divided Government's public disarray over its manufacturing industry policy.

Others who have spoken before me have dealt with some of the broken Labor promises, but I turn in particular to the problems of our manufacturing industry . It would be a foolish person who did not admit that for many years, there have been increasing problems in that area which we as a nation have to face. We have to see that this Government moves in a consistent, coherent and sensible direction. That, I think, is extremely doubtful. Before looking at this aspect, I would like to consider some of the problems of manufacturing industry in this country.

The first problem, of course, is that we have a small market. It is an inescapable fact that we have a small home market. We have problems with exports because of our abysmal relations on the waterfront and our consequential very high overseas shipping costs. We have a further problem because of the impact of the Navigation Act. Because of the monopoly of Australian flag ships on the Australian coast, interstate and intrastate shipping costs are absurdly high. The costs of this are borne by industry. We have high labour costs. One point that is sometimes overlooked is that not only are direct wage costs a matter of concern, but also on-costs are a matter of concern. I refer to the extra costs of holiday pay loadings, workers compensation, annual leave and so forth. The estimate is that, by the end of this decade, the on-costs will be 50 per cent of the wage costs. This is an expense that our competitors generally do not have to bear. It is one to which attention must be directed.

Another problem is that we do not have a good reputation for reliability. This perhaps impacts more in the area of mining. It is extraordinary to see how people looking at us from outside this country regard us. They think that we must be insane. We have wonderful natural assets and potential markets of enormous value; yet we destroy or damage them through wildcat industrial action. The impact is more dramatic in the minerals area, but also it affects manufactured exports. But perhaps the most important problem of all-a combination of all these factors-is that the profits of industry have fallen to dangerously low levels. This is the worst problem because out of profits come investments, out of investments comes growth, and out of growth come jobs. Without profits we will not get any of these things.

The Government must take urgent action to improve profitability. For doctrinal reasons, I suppose, it has not really addressed the problem. If we want to increase efficiency in the manufacturing industry, increase jobs, and improve the economic health of this country, it is urgent that we improve profitability. That is a hard thing for this Government to say, but I am sure that any economic rationalists-if there are any in the Government-would have to admit that that is the key to our recovery. Because of all these factors, I do not think the drift will be reversed. I agree with some of the statements made by Government Ministers. The percentage of our work force employed in manufacturing industry has been declining for many years and will continue to decline. Thirty years ago 27 per cent of the work force were employed in manufacturing industry. The percentage is now about 18 per cent. It will decrease more and more. We must take account of that and take measures to assist the shifting of the work force into areas such as tertiary industry, which I will come to in a moment.

We do not have only disadvantages. We have some very substantial advantages in this country as far as the manufacturing industry is concerned. The first advantage that we have, or should have, is low power costs. In my State of Victoria, the advantage of the lower power costs has been fritted away by the inability of the State Government to make up its mind and come to a sensible decision about the Alcoa refinery at Portland. The extraordinary behaviour, particularly of the Builders Labourers Federation, over the building of the Loy Yang power station can have serious effects on the cost of power in Victoria and , therefore, on the community as a whole and manufacturing industry in particular. Nevertheless, by international standards we have a big advantage in our availability of power.

We have good access to local raw materials but that is damaged, as I said earlier, by the problems of our coastal shipping. Nevertheless, we have a potential advantage in this area. We have a couple of other advantages that are not often commented upon, but which I think are significant. We have a stable form of government. If we look at the problems that beset the manufacturing industry in, for example, Argentina where the government is notoriously unstable , we see that the attractions of a stable government system such as we have here -a non-corrupt government system-are very great. We are an attractive area for investment for that reason.

We also have something which is really very uncommon around the world. People criticise the Public Service, but ours is a Public Service of unquestionable integrity. That is another great advantage for the industrial development of this country. Another impending advantage that will remove one of our disadvantages-our small market-in some areas is the development and introduction of many more robots. Their use removes the enormous disadvantage of constant repetitive work. A robot, instead of making 10,000 items all the same, which is the way we had to get efficiency in mass production, can equally well make 10, 000 different things in rapid succession. This will change one of our disadvantages and give us the potential to make our manufacturing industry more efficient.

We do have-and it would be foolish to deny it-immediate problems. Last year the drought put a lot of people out of work. The world recession knocked out many of our commodity export industries. The main thing which caused our present employment problems and one which the Government does not seem to have faced up to yet and which put three-quarters of a million extra workers on the scrap-heap -perhaps that is an exaggeration, maybe half a million; it depends on how many have withdrawn from the work force-was excess wage demands. That was what priced all our industries out of the market.

What is the Labor Government doing about this situation? One thing any government must aim for is certainty and predictability. If a government wants a good manufacturing industry it cannot change the rules suddenly and unilaterally . It may get away with doing it once, but it will frighten off the people who should be investing in the future. They need to know. They have a hard enough job estimating the market. They need to know that the government rules under which they are operating will not be arbitrarily changed. One area where government policy impacts very greatly on manufacturing industries is protection . That is where it is so dangerous to have one Minister, such as Mr Hayden, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, putting in what appears to be an extreme free trade argument and talking about geriatric industries pickled in formaldehyde or whatever his expression was--

TALK.START.PARA: —Embalmed in formaldehyde.

—Yes-and other Ministers saying flatly that they disagreed with him or that he was talking in such long distance terms that the words were meaningless. There were disputes between Senator Button and Mr Bowen as to who was taking the right line. All of this creates uncertainty. The problems of protection are not easily solved. To get a structure that suits our needs and makes our industry efficient is important, but great damage is done by contradiction and uncertainty between Ministers. Although the Government talked a lot before the election it has done nothing effective yet to improve the situation of dumping, and it has done nothing effective yet about developing country preferences. Countries like South Korea and Taiwan can bring goods into this country in competition with our own industries and at great damage to them. The Government has done nothing at all as far as I am aware about an area of complete economic absurdity-that is, the State preference system whereby the Government seems to think that Australia is not an economic unit and that something built in Victoria, South Australia or wherever has to have a preference in regard to government purchase by that State. I find it hard to imagine anything more economically anarchic or economically absurd than that. The one State-the most serious State- holding up a sensible resolution and the elimination of these absurd pre-Federation State barriers, which the State governments are busily setting up, is New South Wales. The Labor Government of New South Wales is the most reactionary and absurd in this area. The Federal Government has done nothing effective there.

SPEECH.PARA: I said earlier that the rise in wages beyond the capacity of industry to pay has caused so much unemployment, so much hardship and so much social dislocation in this country. What did the Labor Government do? I think the most irresponsible submission to an arbitration commission I have ever seen was made by this Government in the recent national wage case. It argued that incapacity to pay in particular industries should be ignored. The submission by the counsel for the Government was that the Government was aware that some companies had difficulty paying wage rises. The lawyer went on:
. . . in any economic circumstances marginal firms or industries will experience economic difficulties.
These are the lawyer's words. Only a lawyer would use them, I think:
This is part of the normal process of growth and readjustment of the economy.

First the Government cripples a company by official action, then blames market forces for its crash. That was the most absurd economic argument ever put by a supposedly responsible government. It was destroying industries by official action and saying that market forces were doing it. It was no such thing. It is enormously damaging having this sort of argument put and not developing our wage system into an economically sensible structure. The consequence of this behaviour-a wage rise that the community cannot afford, forced on industries which cannot afford to pay it-can be only more unemployment. So much for the jobs, jobs, jobs campaign of the last election and the National Economic Summit Conference.

As I said earlier, the Government has done nothing about the on-costs, the workers compensation, the holiday pay loading, all the imposts which put workers out of a job because these imposts make their employers non-competitive. The Government cannot or will not face up to this fact. Interest rates are of great importance to manufacturing industry and therefore to jobs. The deficit, by most standards, is too high at $8.5 billion. The only way that will not send interest rates through the roof is if there is no private sector investment. Of course this is why the Government is predicting a rise in jobless in the coming year.

There are other areas which certainly need looking at. Penalty rates is one area that the Government has not yet dared to touch. The Government accepts that there will be no growth in employment in primary industry. It accepts that there will be a decline in employment in the manufacturing industry. Therefore employment must be created in the tertiary sector. The Government does not look seriously at or do anything about one great barrier to employment in these areas , the existence of absurd penalty rates.

There is also an alarming tendency for the Government to think that it is going to direct new investment. It sometimes uses the Japanese model. In Japan there is free movement between government, industry and parliament. Here we have separate sectors. For government and public servants to start making economic decisions, for which they bear no real responsibility, is extremely dangerous. Public servants chose a horse to present to the Queen. I think it was called Australia Fair. I think it raced once and came last. That is the sort of industry we will get if selection is made by public servants and governments. I am sure the Labor Government is well-intentioned with its sunrise industries. I hope it keeps its hands off the selection of those industries because if it does start selecting them they will all be a bunch of Australia Fair racehorses.

One of the problems in the disarray caused by the Labor Government, which I mentioned earlier, is that we seem to have four different Ministers-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Bowen and Senator Button-all saying different things. Someone once said that it is difficult enough listening to economists talking about economics, but it becomes absurd when lawyers talk economics. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that three out of those four Ministers are lawyers, and the economics they talk is nonsense. We want a coherent and sensible direction for this country and we are not getting it from the present Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who are the four lawyers?
—Three out of four-Senator Button, Mr Hawke and Mr Bowen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was astounded by two statements that Senator Jack Evans made. The first one was that the National Party of Australia was a free trade party. I do not want to go as far back as protection all round and the Bruce-Page era of the 1920s. Much more recently than that the record clearly shows that the former Country Party Leader , Mr McEwen, was the architect of policies which ultimately embalmed Australian industry. Indeed it often seemed as though the objective of the Country Party, if it had one, was that every industry should ultimately become dependent upon government patronage for its survival-patronage, of course, dispensed by Country Party Ministers. That tradition is carried on to this day by his direct successor, Mr Anthony, and by others such as Mr Bjelke-Petersen.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point he made, when he referred correctly to differences of opinion within other parties on the question of protection, was that there are no differences of opinion within the Australian Democrats. I do not know whether there are any differences in their opinions, but there are certainly massive differences in the things that they say in public. For example, on 29 November last year the then Democrat Senator Siddons was reported as saying to a meeting of shareholders:
. . . that import quotas should be temporarily introduced to give 'our shattered industries time to restructure and to give us time to provide sufficient job opportunities for full employment.'

On 28 July 1981 Democrat Senator Macklin, in a Press statement, strongly criticised the Federal Government's failure to reduce import tariffs. So the divisions or, as Senator Evans correctly said, differences of opinion within other parties on the appropriate protection policies to follow certainly exist among the Democrats as well.

The true position, of course, is that individual options vary within all the political parties and policies vary between the parties. The general policy of this Government on the question, however, is quite clear, and that is that existing systems, including those which provide for gradual winding down of levels of protection, will be continued but that there will be no new reductions in protection while unemployment remains at or near its present unacceptably high levels. The previous Government's record on unemployment is, of course, a disgrace. That Government presided for six years over a permanent recession with the minor exception of the blip in 1980 and, in a final ignominious burst, decreased the number of people in employment by 130,000 in its final year.

There are divisions-continuing bitter divisions-between and within the Liberal and National parties on a number of vital policies. For example, the shadow Treasurer-I think he still holds that position-the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the discredited former Treasurer, Mr Howard, on the vital question of a wages policy, believes that market forces alone should determine the level of wages. The spokesman on that subject within the Liberal Party, Mr Macphee, believes in a centralised wage fixating system. On the Sex Discrimination Bill, of course, we have Mr Macphee saying there is no place in the Liberal Party for people who do not support at least that sort of legislation. Whether that was a ruse to get rid of Senator Walters is a matter on which I do not wish to speculate. But that is clearly a view which is utterly rejected by arch conservatives of the Liberal Party. I was about to add something which may be marginally unparliamentary. It is probably flattering to describe Senator Walters as an arch conservative. On the question of electoral reform, we have, of course, the bitter split between the Liberal and National parties with Mr Anthony supporting the proposals for an enlarged Parliament and Mr Peacock opposing them. This dispute was ultimately resolved by a conscience vote.

The Government's position on protection is clear. What is the Liberal Party's policy on protection or anything else? If one looks to the most recent Deakin Lecture for some philosophical or intellectual guidance one will be disappointed . That lecture, delivered by the present leader of the Liberal Party, could charitably be described as 'moist'. More accurately probably it could be described as 'squishy' as indeed, I suppose, could the statements, major and minor, on almost any conceivable issue which come from the present Liberal Party leader.

The Government has been in office for just over six months. It has moved quickly on unemployment. The community employment program is in operation for those who cannot be employed in the foreseeable future, those who have suffered most from the recession. There has been a substantial increase in unemployment benefit for the single unemployed. In this financial year $733m extra is being spent on employment and training-an increase of 110 per cent on the previous year. Industry policies are in place. Senator Button did not quite maintain his 100 days undertaking to have a steel industry policy in place. I think it took 115 or 130 days.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it was not 150. It was something less than that.
—I think you will find it was in fact 150.
—One hundred and fifty, was it?
—Yes.

—I stand corrected. The 100 days objective was not met. But the new Government, within five months of taking office, had in place a firm policy for the steel industry which has been, under the circumstances of competing interests, extraordinarily well received. Moves have been made to provide venture capital to sunrise industries and to broaden the capital base and extend the gearing ratio of the Australian Industry Development Corporation. In general , of course, and above all else, the key to the Government's economic strategy is a prices and incomes policy.

SPEECH.PARA: An examination of the record of the 1970s, which globally was the worst economic decade since the 1930s, shows quite clearly that the common denominator in each of the five or six countries, mostly in Europe but also Japan, which throughout that difficult decade maintained low rates of inflation, high rates of economic growth and low rates of unemployment, was the existence, whether formally recognised in government policy or not, of an effective prices and incomes policy. The evidence from around the world shows that that is the key to success and that is the key to this Government's economic strategy and the ultimate restoration of full employment. It is not realistic, indeed it is not possible, in a short time to reduce the double digit levels of unemployment to levels which are acceptable and which were regarded as normal through most of the 1950s and the 1960s. We would be prepared to listen to any constructive suggestions which the Opposition parties might care to make on economic management. We regret that so few, if any, such suggestions have been presented either in this debate or in any other discussion in the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The discussion is now concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) deplores the abandonment by the Hawke Government of the Fraser Government's $640 million five year bicentennial water resources program;
(b) stresses the vital importance to Australia's future of the maximum conservation of our limited water resources;

(c) emphasises that the main projects in the program had been indicated by the States as having high priority, advanced planning and preparedness, short lead times for commencement and relatively short construction times;

(d) stresses that many of the projects would create both immediacy of useful employment in the construction period and significant long-term new job opportunities in new industries dependent on water;
(e) focuses attention upon the importance in New South Wales of the following projects:
(i) Split Rock Dam,
(ii) Glenbawn Dam-Stage 2,
(iii) Mid-Murray Storage (Euston),
(iv) Menindee Lakes Storage,
(v) the proposed Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation feasibility study for the construction of a major Upper Murray storage, and
(vi) the proposed feasibility study for the diversion of the Clarence River inland; and

(f) regrets that the Hawke Government has given no indication that it will continue to support the existing National Water Resources Program which is a Federal-State dollar-for-dollar sharing program of great significance to all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sir John Carrick, I understand you wish to suggest that notices of motion Nos 22 to 27 be handled in a cognate debate?
—Yes, I seek leave to do so.
—There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

—This motion is directed towards the failure of the Hawke Government to continue or to maintain the most exciting developments in water resources put forward over the years, and even more recently by the Fraser Government. The motion is in a number of parts. Essentially, it deplores the abandonment by the Hawke Government of the Fraser Government's $640m five-year bicentennial water resources program. It stresses the vital importance for Australia's future of the maximum conservation of all our limited water resources. It emphasises that the main projects in the program had been indicated by the States as having high priority, advance planning and preparedness, short lead time for commencement and relatively short construction times. It stresses that many of the projects would create both immediacy of useful employment in the construction period and significant long term new job opportunities in new industries dependent on water. It focuses attention, particularly in my State, on a number of projects which the Government has not taken up. It regrets that the Hawke Government has done nothing to foreshadow the continuation beyond the end of its five years of the national water resources program.

SPEECH.PARA: It is well known that Australia is the most arid continent on earth and that our average annual rainfall is some 16 inches compared with an average world annual rainfall of some 26 inches. It is well known that if we are to develop our other abundant resources we must develop water. What happened over the period of the Fraser Government term of office was that that Government had set out to establish a series of very important water projects and water functions. Firstly, it set up a five-year program of national water resources-a dollar for dollar program with the States-which in this year had moved into its fifth year. The Fraser Government had said that it would fund the fifth year and then would fund for the following four years up to the bicentennial year, 1988 with a commitment of $210m-a very substantial amount. That meant that the States could plan ahead for the next five years, on a dollar for dollar basis, a whole host of quite significant programs that we had been developing together in the past four years. It did not mean that the States could simply look a year ahead but that they could plan in-depth.

The Hawke Government has simply funded the fifth year of the program and has given no indication of what it will do for the future. The alibi it is hiding behind is that it is studying a report that the Fraser Government commissioned. I want to demolish that because the Fraser Government, among the many things it did, set up a very specialised and expert committee to look at the perspective of water resources to the year 2000. It produced a focal report. That committee reported to the Government last April. If any honourable senators wish to have confirmation of that, they can look at the report of the relevant Estimates committee at which the responsible Minister indicated that the report had been in the hands of the Government for some five months. It was within the competence of the Government, well before putting the Budget together, to indicate that it had studied the report and that it was earmarking money. It is no defence. The fact that there is no money in the Budget for any projects beyond this single year indicates that the Government had the time to do something but refused to do it.

That bicentennial program of the Fraser Government was an initiative involving some $640m for five years. It comprised three elements: It comprised $210m over five years for the national water resources program that I alluded to earlier; it comprised some $85m for the Burdekin Dam and $350m at the rate of $70m a year over five years. One of the most extravagant attempts at propaganda by the Hawke Labor Government in recent weeks, both in this chamber and elsewhere, has been its attempts to seek to represent the Burdekin Dam as one of its initiatives. The Government has sought to suggest that, because there is money in the current Budget for the dam, it started it off. I draw the attention of the Senate to the Estimates committee and to the report of the senior officer who indicated quite clearly that under the Fraser Government an arrangement had been made to fund the dam, with a specific funding of some $85m in 1981 dollar terms and that in fact in the previous Budget a sum of $6.5m had been placed by the Fraser Government.

Let me say that any attempt by the Hawke Government during the Queensland elections to suggest that the Burdekin Dam is its creation is utter nonsense. The arrangements for that were well in place. But it was considered by the Fraser Government that there ought to be a new supplementary program and that that supplementary program should consist of $350m, being $70m each year for five years, and that the works should be significant works. The criteria were that the works should be significant works and be so regarded by the States, as well as the Commonwealth; that they should be almost ready to start now so that we could get them under way; that all the general development planning had been done and that they would be labour intensive and therefore would contribute to employment. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the schedule of that program.
Leave granted.

It will show the names and locations of the projects, their size, what the projects are intended to do and the lead times before the start. In each case it will be seen that the criteria have been satisfied. For example, the Split Rock Dam located at Manilla has a lead time of four months and a construction time of five years. One can see that the criteria had been satisfied-that these were vital projects, that they had short lead times and had labour intensive characteristics so as to employ people. The Hawke Government and its Ministers have been saying that they have not proceeded with these projects because the Fraser Government had not given enough time for the consideration of the matters. They said that there were many matters that were of greater importance than these items. They indicated that there had not been consultations with the States. It is of very great significance to look at this matter and to knock over the dollies. I have already sought leave to incorporate a table in Hansard. I will also seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the statements issued by myself and each of the representative State Ministers for water resources, following negotiations between myself as Commonwealth Minister and each State Minister on this supplementary program.
