SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT'S$640 MILLION WATER RESOURCES DEVELOPMENT INITIATIVE-NEW SOUTH WALES

The Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick, and the recently appointed New South Wales Minister for Water Resources, Mr Paul Whelan, met today to discuss New South Wales participation in the Commonwealth's Bicentennial Water Resources Program involving $640m over five years.

The Ministers discussed the Commonwealth's supplementary program to be fully funded by the Commonwealth. Of this New South Wales could receive about $75m over five years-about 20 per cent of available funds for: the construction of Split Rock Dam, north of Tamworth, to augment supplies in the Namoi Valley; and Stage two of Glenbawn Dam on the Hunter River to augment supplies in the Hunter Valley for industrial, thermal power generation and agricultural purposes.

The proposed full scale feasibility study for diverting surplus flows of the Clarence River to the inland across the Great Dividing Range was discussed. The study, to be fully funded by the Commonwealth, will cover engineering, economic, agronomic and environmental aspects of the most promising possibilities and could cost up to $4m over two years. Details for undertaking this study will be announced later.

The current National Water Resources Program is now to be extended for a further four years after its completion in 1983-84, on a dollar for dollar basis with the State. On current planning, a further $27m should be spent over the next five years under the Program on salinity control and drainage works in the Murray Valley. In addition, about $18m will be spent to continue the State's floodplain management program.

The current very low levels in storages in New South Wales clearly demonstrate the vulnerability of water supplies to drought situations, and the two dams now proposed for construction under the Bicentennial Water Resources Program should ensure improved security of supplies in these two important regions of the State .

The Ministers also discussed works proposed for the River Murray Commission under the Bicentennial Water Resources Program which include enlargement of Maindee Lakes near Broken Hill and a study of new Upper Murray storage, upstream of Albury. The works now proposed, and a new Upper Murray storage, will better equip the Commission to handle its water quality responsibilities, and all three States along the River Murray stand to benefit from this timely Commonwealth initiative.
Sir John said that not only would the construction and manufacturing industries benefit from the new Bicentennial Water Resources Program, but numerous jobs will be created in local areas.
COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT'S$640 MILLION BICENTENNIAL WATER RESOURCES PROGRAM- IMPLICATIONS FOR QUEENSLAND

The Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick, and the Queensland Minister for Water Resources, Mr John Goleby, today discussed Queensland aspects of the Government's recently announced five-year $640m Bicentennial Water Resources Program. This includes a new program supplementary to the current National Water Resources Program.

The Ministers agreed in principle the Queensland projects proposed for inclusion in the Commonwealth funded supplementary Program: a weir on the Macintyre River in the Border Rivers system which will help regulate releases from Glenlyon Dam, a new weir on the Dawson River in Central Queensland which will be used for urban, mining and agricultural purposes, and a grant towards the completion of Awoonga Dam on the Boyne River to augment supplies for urban and industrial development in Gladstone. Increased funding of $6m over three years will also be available to upgrade the capacity of Gin-Gin main channel on the Bundaberg Irrigation Project. On current indications, Queensland should receive about $30m under the Supplementary Program for these projects.

The full-scale feasibility study of the Bradfield Scheme to divert waters of the Burdekin, Herbert and Tully rivers in North Queensland across the Great Dividing Range for agricultural and other uses was also discussed. The study, to be fully funded by the Commonwealth, will cover engineering, economic, agronomic and environmental aspects and will probably cost about $5m over three years. Details are to be announced later on arrangements for the study.

The extension of the National Water Resources Program-for a further four years after the current $200m commitment has been completed in 1983-84 was also agreed in principle. This will enable Queensland to plan ahead for projects already approved under the Program. Over the next five years about $50m will be spent under the shared funding program on the Bundaberg Irrigation Project, $27m on the Eton Irrigation Project and about $8m for Stage 2 of Leslie Dam. In addition , about $18m will be provided for floodplain management studies, planning and works.

The Commonwealth Government has played a major role in the development of water resources in Queensland, providing funds for Maraboon Dam (near Emerald), Monduran Dam (Bundaberg), Kinchant Dam (Mackay) and, more recently, for a start on one of the most ambitious water resource developments now under construction in Australia-the Burdekin Falls Dam near Townsville. Over $100 million is likely to be provided by the time the dam is completed.
COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT'S$640 MILLION WATER RESOURCES DEVELOPMENT INITIATIVE- IMPLICATIONS FOR VICTORIA

The Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick, and the Victorian Minister for Water Resources, Mr David White, commented today on their discussions regarding Victorian participation in the Commonwealth's five- year $640 million water development initiative.

The Ministers agreed that the extension of the National Water Resources Program , due for completion in 1983-84, for a further four years on a dollar for dollar cost-sharing basis, will enable Victoria to plan ahead for projects currently approved under this Program. On current projections, about $22 million will be spent under the Program for salinity and drainage works in the Murray Valley and about $12 million for floodplain management studies and works throughout the State over this period.

The second part of the new initiative, the Bicentennial Water Development Program, which the Ministers agreed in principle, will include for Victoria: the construction of Stage 3 of Lake Merrimu, west of Melbourne; piping of northern sections of the open-channel Wimmera-Mallee stock and domestic water supply system to reduce evaporation and seepage losses, as well as reducing maintenance of the channel, parts of which are now clogged with drift-sand; and Mitchell River Dam in East Gippsland which will reduce pressures on groundwater resources and improve water supplies to Bairnsdale and the Gippsland Lakes area in respect of both quantity and quality.

In respect of the Mitchell River Dam, Mr White indicated that the State had other projects to which it attached higher priority, but the Commonwealth believed that the Mitchell Dam was appropriate for inclusion in the Bicentennial Water Development Program.

The Ministers said the preliminary estimates indicate that Victoria's direct share of the Bicentennial Water Development Program could be about $70 million- 20% of the available funds, as well as benefits from the River Murray projects. These include storage augmentation projects for the mid-Murray and a feasibility study of a new upper Murray storage.
The Ministers discussed other projects which might be included in the National Water Resources Program or the Bicentennial Program. These will be considered at a later stage.
It was recognised that a formal agreement will be necessary to ensure that projects, once commenced, will be funded to conclusion.

The Ministers said that the new initiative will provide a very timely boost to water resources development in the State, and also create employment in the construction and manufacturing industry and in the local areas concerned.
COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT'S$640 MILLION WATER RESOURCES DEVELOPMENT INITIATIVE- SOUTH AUSTRALIA

The Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick, and the South Australian Minister for Water Resources, Mr Jack Slater, today commented on the outcome of their talks concerning South Australia's participation in the Commonwealth Government's recently announced $640 million water resources program.

The Ministers discussed the extension of the jointly funded National Water Resources Program for a further four years after its completion in 1983-84 and the Bicentennial Water Resources Program over the next five years which will be fully funded by the Commonwealth.

The new arrangements will allow over $100 million to be spent on water filtration projects in Adelaide and the Northern Towns over the next five years. Funds will come from Commonwealth grants under the new Commonwealth initiative, and joint Commonwealth/State funding under the extended National Water Resources Program.

The Ministers agreed in principle that under the Bicentennial Water Resources Program, South Australia should receive about $45 million, some 13% of the total available funds. These funds will be used to accelerate the Adelaide and Iron Triangle water filtration schemes and for salinity control works in the Murray Valley between locks 2 and 3.

South Australians, in particular, will be very interested in works proposed for the River Murray Commission under the Bicentennial Water Resources Program-a mid -Murray storage to improve regulation of supplies from the Hume and Dartmouth storages, enlargement of Menindee Lakes storage and a study of a new Upper Murray storage upstream from Albury. All these initiatives should improve the security of supply to South Australia and significantly improve water quality for urban and agricultural uses.
COMMONWEALTH'S BICENTENNIAL WATER PROGRAM FOR WESTERN AUSTRALIA

The Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick and the Minister for Works and Water Resources, the Hon. Andrew Mensaros, said today that Western Australia would benefit substantially from major water projects to be funded through the extension of the jointly financed National Water Resources Program and the Commonwealth funded Supplementary Water Resources Program.

The Ministers said 'the extension of the current national Water Resources Program for a further 4 years after its completion in 1983-84 will permit planning to go ahead on a firm basis for projects already approved for funding in Western Australia. Included in this program would be about $16m for the Harding Dam'.

Projects discussed by the two Ministers and agreed in principle for inclusion in the Commonwealth's new 5 years $350 million Supplementary Water Resources Program were Harris Dam to improve the quality of water supplies in the Collie Catchment, Harvey Dam to augment supplies in the Harvey area and the rehabilitation of Goldfields Pipeline. A summary of these projects costing in the order of $50 million is attached.
Mr Mensaros said he was very appreciative that about 15% of the supplementary program will be spent in Western Australia.
The Ministers said that 'as well as improving water storages and water quality some hundreds of new jobs would be generated in Western Australia through these projects'.

The Ministers said that 'after discussions had taken place between the Commonwealth and other State water resources Ministers early next week, and firmer cost estimates established, the Supplementary Water Resources Program would be finalised'.

The Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick, and the Tasmanian Minister for Water Resources, Mr John Beswick, commented today on their discussions regarding the Goverment's recently announced $640m water resources development initiative.

The Ministers said the new initiative involves, firstly, the extension of the National Water Resources Program for a further four years after its completion in 1983/84. This will enable Tasmania to plan ahead for the next five years on projects already approved under the Program, which include flood mitigation works at Launceston and water quality improvement in the Westbury and Deloraine areas.

The second part ot the Government's initiative, the establishment of the Bicentennial Water Development Program, will also be of considerable importance to Tasmanians in drier areas in the south of the State. The Ministers agreed in principle that Craigbourne Dam on the Coal River will be included in the Program at a cost of about $6.5m. When completed this dam would become one of the key elements of the south-east water development plan now being examined by the Tasmanian Government and due for report in April.
MINISTERIAL TALKS ON GOVERNMENT'S $640 MILLION BICENTENNIAL WATER RESOURCES PROGRAM

The Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Sir John Carrick said today that he was very pleased with the outcome of his talks with State Water Resources Ministers over the last week regarding their participation in the Government's Bicentennial Water Resources Program.

Sir John said that the program involved the extension of the current National Water Resources Program for a further four years after its completion in 1983-84 , and the establishment of a supplementary program involving the expenditure of $350m over the five-year period.

'I am very pleased with the assurances I have received from the State Ministers that State expenditures on water resources will be maintained over this period, and that the States will continue to participate in the jointly-funded National Water Resources Program,' Sir John said.

There has also been agreement in principle on the projects to be included in the $350m supplementary program. New South Wales will receive about $75m for agreed projects representing 22 per cent of available funds, Victoria $70m 20 per cent, Queensland $40m 12 per cent, South Australia $45m 13 per cent, Western Australia $50m 14 per cent, and Tasmania $7m 2 per cent. The balance of funds will be used for special feasibility studies and River Murray projects.

The New South Wales and Queensland Ministers pledged their full support for the major feasibility studies which will now be carried out under the Bicentennial Program on the potential for diverting surplus flows in coastal rivers to the inland across the Great Dividing Range. Further, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia indicated their full approval for works proposed for the River Murray Commission over the five year period to improve water quality in the river, and to improve regulation of releases from storages. A study will also be set in train on a new Upper Murray storage.
Discussions will now take place at officer level to firm up cost estimates of specific projects included in the supplementary program and to finalise a timetable of expenditures over the five years.

Sir John said that the States had warmly welcomed the Commonwealth's initiative particularly in view of the vulnerability of water supplies throughout Australia as has become clearly evident during the current severe drought.
Brisbane, 8 February 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be seen that the significance and pattern of these works was readily and eagerly agreed to by the States. The States acknowledged that the works were significant, and that they could get under way quickly, that they could be completed in the five-year period and that they were labour intensive. It will be seen that only two or three matters in the whole list were queried. The Victorian Minister made a suggestion that a dam on the Mitchell River was not given a high priority by the Cain Government. Let me simply say this: The Mitchell River dam had been given high priority by the previous Hamer and Thompson Governments. It was regarded by those former governments as worthy of a high priority on the lists which they submitted. The Cain Government lowered its priority. The fact of the matter is-much has been made about the Mitchell River dam situation-that the dam is needed to supply precious water to Bairnsdale and the surrounding holiday areas. That area was vastly affected by the drought last year.

SPEECH.PARA: Much has been made of the Bradfield scheme-indeed the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) ridiculed it. If there were more people with the practical visions of the Dr Bradfields in this country, Australia would be the better for it. It certainly is worse off for the knockers of Dr Bradfield and his visions. Whether or not the Bradfield scheme is real is not for the knockers , or even the visionaries, to say. Hard headed assessments have to be made. What could be more hard headed than to say to the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, the Corporation that built the Snowy Mountains scheme of which we are immensely proud: 'The Corporation has immense, world-wide experience in building dams and is consulted by people throughout the world about the feasibility of projects. It should go ahead and make a survey about whether it is a dream or a reality to turn back the Clarence River'. We have the knockers but how can any Minister, no matter what his experience, make a judgment on these matters because he has read or heard something? After all, does anyone deny the ability of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation to go ahead and do these things?

What has happened is typical. The Hawke Labor Government and its Ministers decided to rubbish a series of matters which, in themselves, were not major at all. I will go through them in a moment or two and point out the major matters. One would have thought that in a period of drought the Government would have looked towards the Murray River, particularly in view of the fact that the River Murray Waters Bill is before this Parliament, and set in train a feasibility study of the upper Murray storage. But no, this idea was ridiculed by the Minister, who said that nothing had been done, that no thought had been given to the matter and that this matter lacked priority. Indeed, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation had been doing this for the past 30 years. Information regarding the upper Murray storage area has been available during the existence of the Corporation. Nobody can hide behind the idea that these projects were too hastily conceived. Let me make this point quite clearly: Not one of the items on this program was put there by ministerial decision. Every one of them came about as a result of departmental consultation with the States. No political decisions came into this at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —You must have blisters on your tongue.

—I, as the former Minister, say so. Let the brain-fever birds opposite go on with their chatter. I say that quite clearly. What is more, there was consultation with each of the States. I have incorporated in Hansard the statements that were issued following the meetings with the water resources Ministers of each of the States. In fact, there was agreement on all these matters. As I said, it is enormously easy to hide behind alibis. The Government' s alibi is that it is going to do a complete survey of water and hide behind the report on prospective projects. The fact of the matter is, as I have said, that the Minister for Resources and Energy indicated the other day that he has had that report for five months. That was long enough for him at least to have made a statement and an allocation in the Budget. Did the Government need to spend five months finding out whether a feasibility study into the upper Murray storage area needed to be undertaken-a matter that would involve perhaps $1m? Does the Government need to hide behind this? Does it not know that New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia face an enormous water resource problem because of the salination and the drying of the Murray River? Need another five months be spent on this? All this information was known. The Government had available to it people of immense quality. The Government is not acting in a rational way in saying: 'We are going to wait and think'. It is like the woodpeckers and the white ants they destroy.

SPEECH.PARA: Each of the six States is represented on a ministerial council, the National Water Resources Council. Amongst the many tasks performed by that Council was to look at how the best water research could be achieved in Australia. It looked at an Australian Labor Party suggestion to set up an institute of freshwater studies. The Council decided that that was not what it wanted because it would not meet its requirements. Labor States and Liberal States, both at the official level and at the ministerial level, said that what they wanted was a national water resources council. The Fraser Government set up the National Water Resources Council, comprising people of impeccable qualifications. Indeed, as I recall the Council was chaired by the person who also chaired the study into prospective water resources to the year 2000. People with very high qualifications in engineering and water engineering were on that Council.

What has the Hawke Labor Government decided to do in relation to this matter? Has it decided to go ahead with that? The Hawke Labor Government claims that it is a party of consensus; it says that it gets together with the States and other people; that it pursues what is agreed upon. In fact, the Government will demolish this Council. It has suspended its operations and has announced that it is setting up a pilot scheme for an institute of freshwater studies. Is this consensus, when in fact the six State Ministers said that they did not want a pilot scheme, they wanted the Council. The Government is demolishing organisations such as this one by one. The National Water Resources Council has to go because the Government is setting up a political instrument, despite the fact that it is against all reason, all consensus. The projects in the national water resources program must remain tottering. It is not known whether they will be extended again.

Does anyone say that the Government, in putting together its Budget, did not have time to make a decision whether a dollar for dollar matching grant program which had been eminently successful over the previous four years should not go into the years ahead? Do honourable senators remember the arguments of the Labor Party on the Split Rock Dam? The very Australian Labor Party which criticised us for not supplying enough money has stopped the funding of this dam. The very State Labor Government that said it could not proceed on a dollar for dollar basis is now going it alone. One by one, the pieces of propaganda that have been put up are falling over. Let me make these things quite clear. This Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —You pathetic creature. Fraser and the National Party cooked it up between them. They put it on you and you did not have any say in it.

—One of the only resources that the Minister for Resources and Energy has is a larrikin streak which he thinks he can substitute for reasoned argument and logic. He is becoming the clown, the buffoon, of this Senate. It is high time that somebody reminded the Senate that this is so. In his days in Opposition, he called out the most outrageous reflections on various Ministers and members of the Senate. He revels in the dirt. That is all that he can come forward with.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the Government and the Minister which did these things. First of all, the Government suspended the National Water Resources Council, against the judgment of every State in Australia. It has refused to indicate any future for the national water resources program regarding dollar for dollar funding. It has said that it will not go ahead with the supplementary bicentennial scheme on these grounds: The scheme was ill thought out; it was of a low priority; there had not been enough consultation; and it intended to get the perspective report. The Government has had the perspective report for five months. I remind the Senate and the Minister that the whole of this schedule was submitted to the chairman of the committee on the national perspective of water resources and placed before the people of Australia. That gentleman and that body confirm that scheme had been studied. I point out that it was not a political decision at all . It was an administrative decision. The decisions were made between the States and the Commonwealth entirely on priorities. Discussions were had by myself as Commonwealth Minister with each of the State Ministers. The statements which were issued arising out of each of those meettings are now incorporated in Hansard.

I now turn to the Minister's statements that many proposals were of more importance and that these were of lesser priority. I suppose the Murray River scheme is of lesser priority. Let us tell the people of South Australia that the Upper Murray storage scheme and the desalination of the Murray project are wrong . Let us tell the people of Adelaide and the Iron Triangle that their water supply filtration plants both to Adelaide and the Iron Triangle are of low priority. Let the Minister tell us what is a greater priority to South Australia than those two projects as from the Upper Murray storage to the whole of the Murray system. Let the Minister tell us, if the Split Rock Dam and the Glenbawn Dam in New South Wales are not a high priority, why it is that the Wran Government regards the Glenbawn Dam, with its water supply to the Hunter River, as a vital priority to its development? The fact is that if one goes through this list one will find that each contains matters of prime consideration to the States concerned. I refer to the proposals for South Australia and the Wimmera- Mallee pipeline in Victoria, which is the very lifeblood of the place itself. In Western Australia, a series of dams is being developed. One can see this wherever one turns. There is the Craigbourne Dam, which has immense implications to south-eastern Tasmania.

We have been given an opportunity to put aside the propaganda of this Government. Let nobody again suggest that the Hawke Government is the government that set up the funding and the planning of the Burdekin Dam in Queensland. The Minister heard his own officials say that this had been put in place, that the funding had been arranged-in fact the budgeting had been done in the previous year-and that all those arrangements had been made with, of course, one exception-the signing of the agreement, but that in itself is a common practice. So let that dolly fall. Let the next dolly fall that these were matters neither of intense consultation nor of high priority.

Let the Minister point to the pipelines-let him name them-in South Australia which are of low priority. Let him tell us that the Upper Murray storage project is a low priority. Let him tell us those which are of greater priority. After all, he has the facilities to tell us these things. We would like to hear it now . Let him tell us what he would do. As with the uranium situation at the moment, the Minister is hiding behind a major conflict between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and himself. The Minister is on record in a Senator Estimates committee Hansard as saying that there is no authority, of which he knows as a Cabinet Minister, for Western Mining Corporation Ltd to proceed with the Roxby Downs project on the assumption that it can go ahead and mine and market uranium. He is hiding behind that kind of situation. Now he is hiding behind a series of situations, one being that the Government is waiting for the perspective report.

The Minister has had the report for four or five months. He has had sufficient time to have looked at the principles of the report. He has had sufficient time to have decided whether the Murray River ought to have been developed. He has had sufficient time to have decided whether the Adelaide pipeline or the Iron Triangle pipeline should have been developed. There has not been a pettifogging thing to start and pitch on whether the Bradfield scheme is good or bad. Of the $350m for this supplementary program, less than $10m is allocated for prospective studies-for studies of the Clarence River, the Bradfield scheme and the Upper Murray. In any case, why has the Government not started a study on the Upper Murray? All the evidence is available to it. That is the simple situation.

I return to the motion; that is, that a $640m program, put in place and interlocked with the States-the evidence is now in Hansard-has been set aside by the Government. The Government's claims as to why it has been set aside are fraudulent in the extreme. The Government's claims that there was no consultation and that these were not high priority matters are absolutely wrong. The Government's claims that there ought to have been consultation with the committee on perspective are wrong, because there was consultation. The Minister may have the advantage of looking at Hansard-as indeed he can look at the records-at any time and find the statements that emerged from State to State. Only one State-that is, New South Wales-argued about the funding. It argued about the Split Rock Dam. It did not argue about Glenbawn because that State had never intended to build Split Rock. It had always opposed it. We gave it matching grants but all the time it made alibis that it would not use the grants because they had to be guaranteed into the future. Every other State took the matching grants and got on with the work. The fact of the matter is that the Wran Government never wanted to build Split Rock Dam and so it started creating alibis in that regard.

I know of no program that is of more importance to Australia than the bicentennial water resources program. I know of no program that was on a more sound basis for development. I know of no issue in Australia that has more urgency to it. If Australia is to meet any emerging movement out of the recession in this world of ours, it will need water, particularly in its industrial areas. It will need water to help development. The talk of Roxby Downs depends entirely on whether we can get the filtration plants to the Iron Triangle. One of the saddest elements in the Hawke Government's short record is its demolition of this program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my notice of motion No. 23 of which I gave notice on 1 June 1983 and speak in support of notices of motion No. 22 by Senator Sir John Carrick, No. 24 by Senator Hill, No. 25 by Senator Crichton- Browne, No. 26 by Senator Collard and No. 27 by Senator Archer. All these notices of motion relate to the disgraceful dismissal by the Hawke Government of the bicentennial water resources program announced on 25 January this year by the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser. This program involved an expenditure of $ 640m over the next five years. The ingredients of this program included an amount of about $210m for the completion of the existing five-year program for national water resources, which is in its fourth year, and the extension of that program for another four years. They included also finance for the Burdekin Dam totalling about $80m, and a new five-year supplementary program especially proposed for the bicentennial celebrations in 1988 for each of the six States involving projects of high priority and early commencement amounting to some $ 350m. The aims of these programs were to provide water for new industries and agriculture and to provide employment at a time when employment projects, with a definite advantage to the capital cities, of this nation and projects looking to our infrastructure were needed. Everyone in Australia acknowledged the dependence of this nation on water.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course this program was not some sort of a gimmick got up for an election, as alleged by Senator Walsh. It was, in fact, a carefully thought-out program. It had specific objects. They included: To improve efficiency of supplies from existing storages; to improve security of supplies to existing users; to improve availablilty of supplies for industrial development; and to improve quality of water supplies, particularly in South Australia, where water quality problems, of course, come from the other States.

The important thing about this-and the reason why Senator Walsh's allegation that this was some sort of election gimmick is absolute nonsense-is that the list was prepared by officers of the Department of National Development and Energy. Senator Sir John Carrick, who was the Minister at the time, has given the Senate his assurance that there was no political interference in that list. Furthermore, there was consultation between those officers and the Chairman of the Perspective Study of Water Needs to the Year 2000, Major-General Green, and consultation with all State water Ministers. Senator Sir John Carrick tabled documents which relate to those agreements and consultations.

Mr Deputy President, as a Victorian you would know of the problems in Victoria in connection with the Mitchell River Dam near Bairnsdale. Your Party and my Party, the Liberal Party in Victoria, has always seen the need to have a dam on the Mitchell River near Bairnsdale for the desperate need of the people of Gippsland. The funds for that dam were to be committed under this proposal. That proposal was given high priority and was considered a matter of urgency by the former Liberal Government of Victoria. However, the Cain Labor Government of Victoria decided, once again, to treat the rural people of our State in its usual dismissive manner. It decided not to go ahead with this dam but to expend the funds on some other water supply project which would benefit the people of the metropolis. The result was that there was criticism of this proposal by the Victorian Government. Let there be no doubt that Bairnsdale an the area surrounding Bairnsdale are desperately in need of water. That was proven recently in the drought when Bairnsdale was subjected to a very heavy rationing of water. I think that Bairnsdale was down to a consumption level of not more than 50 per cent of the normal daily rate.
Apart from that criticism by Victoria, all of the other projects were approved. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a list of the special projects for Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —That list disloses that the first project on the program was stage 3 of Lake Merrimu at Bacchus Marsh. That project was to increase storage capacity from 15,000 million litres of water to 74,000 million litres of water for outer metropolitan areas and irrigation of market gardens. There was a need to have a lead time of three months. The estimated construction time was three years. So if that had been started this year the people of the outer metropolitan areas of Melbourne would have been receiving the benefit of this enormous increase in storage capacity of Lake Merrimu by about 1986. Instead, the whole thing has been put aside, not to be proceeded with. Apparently it has been abandoned by the Hawke Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Where will the people of the outer metropolitan areas of Melbourne obtain their water supplies when a project of such vital importance to the people of Victoria can be stamped on by this Government and in a most irresponsible manner by Senator Walsh who dismissed the whole thing out of hand as some sort of election gimmick? Of course, Senator Walsh has fallen flat on his face in regard to this matter because, in due course, his Government will adopt the policy of the former Liberal-National Government in relation to Lake Merrimu stage 3. The Hawke Government will end up adopting this policy but, of course, much later than if it had gone ahead with the proposal as it was planned by the Fraser Government.

Of course that is only one example of the Hawke Government adopting Liberal- National Party Government policies. Of course, Senator Walsh who keeps referring to so-called discredited Treasurers, in fact is party to a government which is adopting the policies of that so-called discredited Treasurer. He has referred to a so-called discredited government. In fact, Senator Walsh is party to a government which is adopting the policies of that so-called discredited government. In due course, Senator Walsh, as the Minister for Resources and Energy, will end up adopting these policies of Senator Sir John Carrick when he was Minister for National Development and Energy.

The second project proposed for Victoria was the piping of the Wimmera-Mallee water supply scheme stage one, covering Horsham, Ouyen and Swan Hill. That project is to convert the existing open channel stock and domestic supply to a piped supply. It is estimated that that would save about 90,000 million litres per annum which is lost by evaporation and seepage due to this channel being open. The lead time was six months, and the estimated completion time five to 10 years. The Mitchell River Dam project will provide an extra 15,000 million litres of water to augment the ground water supply used for vegetable production and urban supplies for Bairnsdale and the extensive holiday resorts on Gippsland Lakes. The three months lead time, the five years completion-all of that time has now been put aside as the Hawke Government abandons the scheme, and abandons it for what? It abandons all of these proposals for no valid reason at all because Senator Walsh thinks that they were some sort of an election gimmick. What sort of government is prepared to abandon projects of such enourmous importance to the people of Victoria and indeed, the other projects of such enourmous importance to the whole of the nation because Walsh has a bit of a thing about Senator Sir John Carrick and, with his usual intemperate language, indeed foul language, dismisses these proposals out of hand? But he will pay for it in due course. When he gets around to adopting these proposals, he will be too late. The people of this country will have come to realise what a terrible Minister he has proven to be and what a terrible shame, a disgrace, he has been in adopting these sorts of dismissal proceedings for no valid reason at all.

Let me turn now to these projects and examine what they were. They all stand the test of high priority. They were in fact recommended by Labor's own Ministers. They were undertaken on the basis of departmental arrangements and deep consideration. There were significant employment works involved in them. On their completion, one could anticipate that there would be new industries and extended employment arising out of the additional water supply. All of these things have gone by the board. Let us not forget the proposed Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation feasibility study for the construction of the major upper Murray storage. Everyone in eastern Australia realises the absolute desperate need to solve the problems of the Murray River. This study would have been a start on the solution to that problem. But no, thanks to Senator Walsh and his attitude towards anything to do with the former Government and the former Minister of his Department, it has all been dismissed. It has all been pushed out of the window for no valid reason at all. And how is he doing this? He is doing it by alleging that he is waiting for the report. I quote from page 190 of the Budget Paper No. 1:

The recommendations of the recently completed report, the 'Perspective on Australia's Water Resources to the Year 2000', have been discussed with the State water resources Ministers in the Australian Water Resources Council (AWRC) . The scope and nature of Australian Government assistance for water resource programs beyond 1983-84 will have regard to the outcome of these discussions.

The Government has had that report for some four or five months. It has had these discussions. It brought down the Budget in August and still there is no decision. The whole thing has been deferred so that it will, in due course, have regard to the outcome of these discussions. But of course we can see from the Budget Papers that in fact at this stage this Government has abandoned all of these programs. It has abandoned $640m worth of programs that would benefit this nation, programs which would have created jobs, programs which on completion would have provided facilities for further jobs, further development. Water resource projects desperately needed by this country have all been abandoned for nothing, abandoned by this Minister in a fit of pique, for no valid reason at all. They have been deferred until such time as the demands of the people of Australia to this Government finally get through and finally the Cabinet, probably, and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will have to stand over this Minister and demand that these works be completed. I strongly support the motion moved in my name and the motions moved in the names of other senators, and I urge the Senate to adopt these motions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the motion in my name and, really, the series of motions deploring the abandonment by the Hawke Government of the Fraser Government's $640m five-year bicentennial water resources program and also expressing the regret that the Hawke Government has given no indication that it will continue to support the existing national water resources program, a regret that, as I think has been indicated by my colleagues , has now reached the stage where we have very serious doubts as to whether the program will proceed. I do not wish to cover the ground that has already been covered so adequately by my colleagues but rather to put the South Australian perspective in relation to this series of motions.

SPEECH.PARA: South Australia's dependence on the River Murray, I think, is simply not adequately appreciated by the population at large. It can be evidenced by the fact that 49 per cent of the state's total irrigation, stock, domestic and industrial water consumption depends on that river. Even more dramatic is the figure that some 80 per cent of Adelaide's water needs are also met by the River Murray. It is no wonder, therefore, that South Australians view their future well-being as intrinsically tied to the security of water supplied from that river. In recent years that security has been threatened, not only by devastating drought but also by the unacceptable quality of water supplied from the river. Irrigation practices upstream and resulting high water tables have increased the river's salt load through South Australia. The impact on agricultural industries dependent on the Murray for their water supply has been most dramatic. South Australia has therefore been at the forefront in supporting initiatives which have aimed at improving the management and development of our nation's major river system.

Presently before the Senate, I remind honourable senators, is the River Murray Waters Agreement, which marks a milestone in the development of effective management of the River Murray system and for which my colleague Senator Sir John Carrick can take considerable credit. The River Murray Commission is now empowered to consider and make recommendations on water quality. The Agreement, in a sense, signals a recognition of the adverse effects of high salinity levels on South Australian water supplies. Moreover, the agreement marks the conclusion of strenuous efforts made by Sir John Carrick, as I mentioned, and the previous Government to ensure that our greatest river system is provided with support necessary for its continued survival. I mention that only in passing as just one illustration of the previous Government's commitment to the conservation of Australia's water resources.

Another example which has been mentioned is the establishment in August last year of the National Water Research Council, a body charged with the task of improving the co-ordination of water research within Commonwealth research agencies. Under the former Government, water resource management, conservation and development therefore remained high priority national objectives. The national water resources program and the bicentennial water resources program were significant programs geared towards achieving these objectives. They were not, as the Opposition would like people to believe and as I think has been effectively demolished already in this debate, programs merely plucked out of the air.

The national water resources program, as has been indicated, has received no assurance of funding beyond this year. It has been in operation since 1977-78 and since that time has provided funding on a dollar for dollar basis to all State governments for projects considered of high priority. The program now appears to be gutted, with no alternatives yet proposed by this Government. As we have heard, the report upon which the Government claimed to be waiting has been in its hands since April of this year but still there is no indication as to what the future holds.

I reminded the Senate that under the national water resources program South Australia has received funding for significant programs. Over $35m since the year 1977-78 has been provided by the Commonwealth for water assessment projects , filtration schemes for Adelaide and the northern towns of Port Pirie, Port Augusta and Whyalla, Murray River salinity and drainage works and flood mitigation projects along the River Torrens. All these projects are still in train. A significant boost to the development of these programs was provided by the former Government when it announced in January that the national water resources program would be extended for four years to 1987-88. This announcement provided State governments with an opportunity to undertake forward planning decisions in the knowledge that an average of $40m a year would be available for programs already under way-something that seems so obviously necessary in long term water resource programs, particularly those that have already been instituted and are part completed. I regret to say that this forward planning has now been taken away by the precipitous decisions of this Government.

All South Australian projects, other than the Adelaide and Iron Triangle filtration schemes, have suffered as a result of this year's Budget. Funding for water resource assessment has been cut back, although I am pleased to say the cutback has not yet led to the dropping of any assessment programs. However, the three main programs on ground water assessment, surface water assessment and computer modelling of the River Murray resources investigation have all been scaled down. Funding for River Murray salinity and drainage work has been cut by $405m and the River Torrens flood mitigation program, which received a 100 per cent funding increase in the 1982-83 Budget, has this year been increased by a mere 6 per cent-not even enough to keep up with the Government's highly optimistic inflation forecast.

South Australia now faces the uncertainty created by a government with no clear planning intentions for comprehensive water resource development. This contrasts so dramatically with the philosophy of the previous Government, which not only sought to secure the continuation of the national water resources program but also had the imagination and the initiative to propose the supplementary bicentennial water resources program. The announcement of the commitment of an additional $350m for water resource projects brought with it greater hope that South Australia would obtain a more secure and higher quality water supply. Under this scheme a further $70m in direct funding was to be provided each year for five years. The program was one of vision. That vision has not been shared by this Government and South Australia, like the other States, will be disadvantaged. For South Australians particularly, the bicentennial scheme offered hope that additional storage capacity on the Murray could be built. A significant project under the scheme, since jettisoned by the Government, was the comprehensive engineering, economic and environmental study of a new upper Murray dam. The development of this dam, along with funding for increased storage capacities to be provided at Euston and on the Menindee Lakes and improvements in the regulation of water release from the Hume and Dartmouth dams , would have had a positive effect on maintaining a sufficient flow of water down the Murray while at the same time improving water quality. I stress both objectives-quantity and quality.

The three projects I have mentioned were to be part of the bicentennial water resources program. Their significant investment potential, along with that of the other projects in other States, has now been lost. When the Government comes to realise the value of these programs, their cost obviously will be far in excess of $70m per annum. The bicentennial water resources program provided for the completion of water projects over a very short period. The value of that is to be stressed. These projects contain substanital opportunity for employment generation. That opportunity has been missed. They provided an imaginative addition to Australia's capital infrastructure. That opportunity has now been missed. The bicentennial water resources program provided the Government with an opportunity to build on the initiatives provided by the former Government. It has missed that opportunity as well. Above all, the Government has shown that it lacks the courage and foresight of its predecessors. Australia and South Australia in particular, now face a less secure future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Sir John Carrick has not been so enthusiastic since the days when he used to talk up the resources boom in general and Rundle shares in particular-
—You know that is wrong.
—He got them up to a capitalised market value of $1,200m. Last time I looked the figure was $300m. He fiddled with the National Energy Advisory Committee report to boot.

—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. That must be an offensive and insulting remark to a senator and I draw your attention to it. To allege that someone fiddled with a report, which in this case is absolutely wrong, is to be offensive to a member of this chamber and I ask you to ask the Minister to withdraw it.

—I withdraw that, Mr Acting Deputy President. What Senator Sir John Carrick did, precisely, was put out a Press statement accompanying the NEAC report on the prospectivity of the Rundle project. In that Press statement, which purported to be a summary of what was in the report, he changed both the estimated time schedule in which it could come on production and whether it was a probability or a possibility. If the honourable senator objects to me describing that as fiddling with a NEAC report then I am quite happy to withdraw it, but that is what he did. As I said, I have not seen him so enthusiastic since the days when he used to talk up the resources boom and Rundle shares.

SPEECH.PARA: The sordid reality behind the romanticism and flamboyant rhetoric is that this proposal, which was retrospectively named the bicentennial water resources program-it was not named that on 25 January when the first Press statement came out-is that it was a stunt by a desperate Prime Minister running amok with the cheque book in the approach to his terminal election campaign. He knew full well that the country was already facing a prospective deficit for the next financial year in excess of $9 billion. In that situation, the discredited former Prime Minister-if Senator Sir John Carrick wants to associate himself with this scheme he is welcome to do so-knowing all that, produced a wildcat list of proposals for expenditure of taxpayers' funds, which included a bit of double and triple counting but which the former Government claimed amounted to $640m. That sort of fiscal irresponsibility is not practised by this Government, and it will not be. Senator Sir John Carrick has accepted responsibility for it, which under the circumstances is really quite magnanimous because the scheme in fact was cooked up by the Prime Minister in collusion with National Party pork barrellers. It has subsequently been repudiated by the former Treasurer and now Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard).

Senator Sir John Carrick made much of the alleged commitment to the Burdekin Dam by the former Government. Let us set the record straight. What the former Government did was appropriate in its last Budget $6 1/2m for the Burdekin Dam. There was no legally binding obligation for any commitment thereafter. Indeed, the Age of 19 August reported on comments of the former Treasurer as follows:
it may have been necessary to reschedule some of the capital works commitments made in the election and in the lead up.
So what Senator Sir John Carrick tells us was a formal and binding commitment was something that might have been rescheduled in general. The former Treasurer is further reported to have said:
I never believed the employment spin off from the large capital works are as great as other people think.
Then he becomes more specific:
As for the Burdekin dam, which politicians have repeatedly promised to fund but the Hawke Government has actually started to fund-
He said: 'but the Hawke Government has actually started to fund'; this is the former Treasurer and present Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party speaking, in a direct quote-
I would not have regarded the Burdekin as any more sacrosanct than other areas. I'd have put it into hotch-potch with some of the other things.

There we have from the former Treasurer himself precisely what would have happened to the retrospectively named bicentennial water resources program had the discredited former Prime Minister and the discredited former Treasurer still been in office. It would have been scuttled after the election. It was a mirage designed to shimmer between 25 January and 5 March and then disappear from view forever. Senator Sir John Carrick cannot have it both ways. He cannot assert that the former Government was irrevocably committed to funding the Burdekin Dam and support his present Deputy Leader who said in August that it was not, and indeed that it would have been rescheduled and possibly scuttled. He cannot have it both ways.

Senator Sir John Carrick also chose to comment on the Split Rock Dam. I will say more about that later. The financial arrangements for Split Rock Dam, made by the previous Government, were identical to those for the Burdekin. One million dollars was allocated in the 1982-83 Budget. The New South Wales Government wanted a commitment that there would be funding in future years. Senator Sir John Carrick and the former Government refused to give that commitment. There was no guarantee of further Commonwealth funds beyond 1982-83 for the Split Rock Dam than there was for the Burdekin.

TALK.START.PARA: —$40m unmatched.

—There was no guarantee of any further Commonwealth funds beyond 1982-83 for the Split Rock Dam or the Burdekin. No matter how much Senator Sir John Carrick cares to wriggle and prevaricate, that is the truth, that is the fact.
—You can shout it, but it does not make it a fact. What does the joint statement say?
—Order!
—Why should I come to order, why?
—Senator Lewis, if I call you to order I do not expect to have my call to order questioned.
—I apologise, Mr Acting Deputy President.

—Towards the end of January when the discredited former Prime Minister was planning what he thought was to be a successful campaign, but turned out to be a terminal election campaign, the Department was asked for a list of water resources projects for potential funding. The list was drawn up but the message came back that there were not enough projects on the list, that a few more were required. Thus all the wildcat propositions that had been gathering dust for years were brushed off and hastily put into the former Government's package, as an election stunt. The program would have been repudiated by the former Government had it been successful in deceiving the people on 5 March.

SPEECH.PARA: Some States had literally half an hour to respond to the proposals that had been put to them. So much for the consultation which Senator Sir John Carrick and others claim took place! One State-there may have been more than one, but I know of one-was given literally half an hour to respond to specific proposals. I refer to Victoria. One of the proposals on that list was the Mitchell River Dam, which the Victorian Government itself had previously decided to scuttle. If Senator Sir John Carrick wants to accept the responsibility for it-I would not nail him with it, because the people who were really responsible were the pork barrellers of the National Party and the former Prime Minister-he is welcome to it. He then stood over Victoria and said that they must accept his proposal or take nothing. Victoria wanted some other projects to be funded if the Commonwealth had so much loose cash that it could throw it to the States knowing that it was facing a $9 billion prospective deficit in the next financial year. Victoria said it would prefer something else, but was forced to accept the Mitchell River Dam because that is what the pork barrellers of the National Party wanted.

We all know that in any conflict in the former Cabinet between the pork barrellers of the National Party and Senator Sir John Carrick, the pork barrellers always won because the Prime Minister lined up with them and overruled Senator Sir John Carrick. I do not know whether to be angry at Senator Sir John Carrick's audacity in raising this matter today or to show pity for him for having to tolerate in that Cabinet for so many years a Prime Minister who always supported the pork barrellers of the National Party against the usually better advice and policy which the Government was given by Senator Sir John Carrick. It is true that these projects were on lists submitted by the State governments. There are a vast number of projects floating around because State governments from time to time, to appease pressure groups in various parts of their States, say: 'Well, we will make an application to the Commonwealth to fund this project'. For example, a proposal from Western Australia regarding the Agaton water scheme has been on the books for a decade or more.

State governments decide to make application to the Commonwealth for the funding of schemes, never expecting that those applications will be taken seriously. Of course the States accepted the offer of the money-under protest in the case of Victoria, in that it would have preferred the $20m allocated for the Mitchell River Dam to be allocated to something more socially and economically useful. But of course it accepted the money. What State government in its right mind, in the midst of the worst recession for 50 years, would have rejected it? That recession was induced substantially by years of mismanagement by the former Government. That Commonwealth handout, however ill conceived it may have been, the specific projects, however misdirected that public investment may have been, would at least have generated some employment and economic activity in the State . Of course they accepted it.

Senator Sir John Carrick had a good deal to say about the Bradfield scheme. The Bradfield study itself, as a piece of engineering, is about as cobwebby as Senator Sir John Carrick's economics. Among other things, the Bradfield study, according to the report compiled by Cameron McNamara Pty Ltd completed, I think, last year-certainly very recently-showed that Bradfield had grossly overestimated the availability of water in the rivers concerned. He was the engineer who designed the Sydney Harbour Bridge. I presume he was a competent engineer in that sense. Obviously, his earlier study in this respect was very superficial, so superficial that it was grossly in error.

An even more significant error was that Bradfield had assumed that the water from the point of impoundment could be diverted inland by gravity through tunnels across the Divide. In fact, as the Cameron-McNamara report showed, it required a lift of nearly 400 metres to reach the inland plains, as well as tunnelling across the Divide. I note that Senator Collard who, I suppose, is scheduled to speak on this collective of motions, thinks so little of the Bradfield scheme that he has not even bothered to list it on his list of complaints about projects affecting Queensland. That is what Senator Collard thinks of the Bradfield scheme. He is not even complaining about its being dropped. He has listed the Dawson River Weir, the MacIntyre River Weir, the Awoonga Dam, and the proposed feasibility study for the diversion of the Northern Rivers system inland. The last project mentioned is, of course, almost identical to Senator Sir John Carrick's reference to the proposed feasibility study for the diversion of the Clarence River inland.

Let us consider the Clarence River diversion, another project for which Senator Sir John Carrick is accepting full responsibility. As I have said, I would not apportion full responsibility for this debacle, this piece of sordid political intrigue in the run-up to a terminal election campaign, to Senator Sir John Carrick, but he is apparently willing to accept it. In the Australian of 25 January Professor Musgrave, a well known and eminent agricultural economist from the University of New England, with respect to the Clarence River, is reported as saying:
. . . there was no crop which could justify the projected cost of the water, $ 106 a million litres.

A million litres is more commonly known as a megalitre. An eminent agricultural economist with a direct knowledge of the area said that no crop could justify the cost of the water. Senator Sir John Carrick proposed to squander $4m of taxpayers money on a feasibility study into that proposal, knowing-at least if he did not know, some of his better informed Cabinet colleagues must have known- that the country was facing a prospective $9 billion deficit in this financial year, before throwing away an additional $4m on a project as worthless as that. The Australian also reported the New South Wales Water Resources Commission- which like most water resources commissions could fairly be described, and would not object to being so described, as pro-irrigation development-as saying that the investigation showed that very high capital costs are involved, even for the more favourable diversion schemes. For example, two identified schemes could each divert 755,000 megalitres annual from the Clarence River basin at capital costs of $619m or alternatively $656m based on mid-1961 figures. The delivery costs, as Professor Musgrave said and as I have already quoted, are $109 a megalitre. To put that into perspective for people who may not be familiar with that area, the normal charge for water delivered by channel to a farm is in the vicinity of $13 a megalitre to $16 a megalitre. That includes, in almost all circumstances, a substantial public subsidy. The delivery costs from the Clarence River are $109 a megalitre. That is the proposal upon which Senator Sir John Carrick agrees and accepts responsibility for squandering an additional $4m on an unnecessary feasibility study. Then he has the audacity to castigate or attempt to castigate this Government for husbanding the taxpayers' dollars with a greater sense of responsibility than he or his party displayed when in office.

Several speakers have mentioned the report entitled 'Perspective on Australia's Water Resources to the year 2000'. Senator Sir John Carrick appears to harbour the delusion that he pulled off some sort of a coup at Senate Estimates Committee C last Monday week, when I said that I believed I had received the report in April. A check revealed that that was the case. It was despatched to the States very quickly. It was the Government's intention to have the report printed and tabled in Parliament before this but there has been a delay in the Government Printer doing that work. But the States have had the report since May and early June and have been asked to respond to it. I am informed today that all States have responded. The response in general is to support the recommendations of the report. I will come to those in a minute. There is broad agreement with the recommendations. This is not a recommendation but a quotation from the report reaffirmed in the recommendation:

Several signs clearly indicate that emphasis in the water industry is now moving from development of new resources to better management of existing supplies and that this trend will continue into the foreseeable future.

Further, I observe for the record and for those who did not hear Senator Sir John Carrick that that is contradictory to the thrust of the policy which he urges upon this Government and which he himself irresponsibly pursued when in office. The emphasis that he has placed as a Minister-and he accepts the responsibility for it; if he wants to be lumbered with it he is welcome to it- and that he repeats here today is on massive new construction projects, some of which are known to be hopelessly uneconomic, some which are marginal and some which are worth while and which have been picked up by this or other Labor governments.

Senator Sir John Carrick mentioned the drought, repeating the old furphy that irrigation drought-proofs the country. He commended the people who wrote the report and said what an excellent team they were; and I agree. It found:
Irrigation development does not mitigate the effects of drought. It may even exacerbate the effects of drought if heavily stocked irrigation properties are subjected to water supply restrictions.

That is the finding of the committee which Senator Sir John Carrick has praised . But today he repeats the old furphy that irrigation will drought proof the country. Chapter 8 of the report, recommendation 4 (1) states:
Priority in water resources development for irrigation to the year 2000 should be given to the completion of those schemes already under construction.

That is precisely what this Government has done, as distinct from what Senator Sir John Carrick, Senator Lewis, Senator Archer, Senator Collard and Senator Crichton-Browne would have us do. They would have us-as a pork-barrelling measure in National Party electorates and one or two others by accident, which are scattered all around the country-start new projects. The report of this Committee-the members of which Senator Sir John Carrick appointed and whose report he has praised today-recommended that priority of water resource development for irrigation to the year 2000 should be given to the completion of those projects already under construction. Again, that is absolutely contradictory of the policy pursued by Senator Carrick and for which he is magnanamous or foolish enough to accept responsibility when a Minister, and contrary to that which he urges upon this Government today. This Government has acted completely in accordance with that recommendation.

I turn now to the list of projects in these five or six motions. The New South Wales Government announced last week that it was going to build and fund the Split Rock Dam. The same will happen to the Glenbawn Dam-stage 2. The Mid-Murray storage (Euston), the Menindee Lakes storage, and the proposed construction of an Upper Murray River storage projects are all viewed with reservation by New South Wales and are low on the priority list. I have already dealt with the proposed feasibility study with the diversion of the Clarence River inland which was mentioned by Senator Sir John Carrick. He regrets that the Government has not hastily rushed into an ill-considered project beyond 1983-84, following the example of its predecessor. Senator Lewis lists Lake Merrimu-stage 3, and the Piping Wimmera-Mallee water supply scheme-Stage 1. From memory the cost of stage 1 is $60m. Apparently Senator Lewis thinks that would have been an easy task for a government with a $9 1/2 billion deficit, from a irresponsible predecessor. Senator Lewis thinks it would have been a piece of cake to find $60m for that project. As someone who was associated with the Expenditure Review Comittee I can tell Senator Lewis that it was not. One motion includes the Mid-Murray storage (Euston) and the Menindee Lakes storage--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Lake Merrimu?
—Lake Merrimu, if I remember correctly, is principally an urban industrial supply-
—Outer metropolitan.

—Outer metropolitan, which has not normally been funded under the scheme of the previous Government. That draws attention yet again to the stunting nature of the retrospectively named bicentennial water resources program. Normally, projects such as Lake Merrimu were not picked up under that program because they were urban industrial. The view of the government of the day-and a view that I must say I tend to share-is that the State governments have traditionally been responsible for that area and should retain that responsibility. But when the former Government needed a stunt for an election campaign, which turned out to be terminal, it waived those long standing guidelines and threw Lake Merrimu in.
—What do you say about the Mitchell River Dam? Is it finished? Is there no hope?

—The Victorian Government scuttled the Mitchell River Dam project in May of 1982, and very sensibly too. Senator Hill's motion refers to the Adelaide water filtration scheme. Now that is one of the worthwhile projects. In spite of the desperate financial situation which we inherited from our irresponsible predecessors, an additional $4m has been provided in the Budget for that scheme. The South Australian Government last week agreed to match that contribution with an additional $1m. This Government is very conscious of the fact that that is a high priority scheme which deserves funding, and it has been funded. It has substantial, decisive social and economic justification criteria which are conspicuously absent from almost all of the other projects which the former Prime Minister announced on 25 January and for which Senator Sir John Carrick accepts responsibility. Of course, Senator Crichton-Browne will rave on for a while, I suppose. None of those projects has high priority.
—I am not in your class.
—Tell us about Christo Moll's cheque butts. That would probably be more interesting than what the honourable senator is likely to say. Senator Archer referred to the Craigbourne Dam.
—Is that all you have to say about Western Australia?

—The honourable senator has not spoken yet, so I cannot reply to him. He probably will not be worth replying to anyway. I invite him to tell us about Christo Moll's cheque butts. Various economic studies going back to, I think, the late 1960s or 1970 have been undertaken by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics in respect of the Craigbourne Dam. Some people have updated the reports to establish the estimated capital costs. I have a report, bearing the Tasmanian coat of arms, of the South East Irrigation Committee of the Rivers and Water Supply Commission. One member of this study committee was Mr Casimaty, a former Country Party Senate candidate and I understand a land holder in the Coal River Valley which is a potential irrigation area. The report says that after the completion of the sixth unit of the Jordan-Coal Rivers and Iron Creek scheme which would cost $29m, and on the assumption that the full output of 10,500 megalitres were paid for every year-I just observe parenthetically that is an unrealistic assumption because less than the full output would be delivered-the delivery cost of the water is $474 a megalitre for capital alone. The existing irrigation charges in Tasmania are about $6. The estimated cost was $474 plus $ 43 for servicing and administration. So much for the Craigbourne scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: The last point that I have time to make is that this stunt which the previous Prime Minister announced on 25 January and which was retrospectively named the bicentennial water resources program, with the very limited exclusions of the Harding River Dam in Western Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't come from Western Australia, do you?

—That was part of it. With the exception of the Harding River Dam and the Iron Triangle towns, the previous Government completely excluded funding water supplies for country towns. That was one of the most unacceptable arrangements. With a few minor exceptoins, it refused to accept any responsibility for people in country towns who have the worst water supplies in Australia. That was what the people in country towns got from the National Party and what they got from Senator Sir John Carrick. This Government has not accepted that. We have announced a program under the community employment program and have allocated $20m to provide water supplies to people in smaller country towns who have a high, if not the highest, priority and the greatest need for decent water supplies of any people in Australia. They have got it from a Labor government. They did not get it from the previous Government and they would not get if from such a government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation on two points. The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) said during his speech that I had personally altered a Press statement relating to a National Energy Advisory Committee report to pervert the meaning of the report. He knows, because I told him at the time as did the then Department of National Development and Energy, that the Department made a statement completely unprovoked that a departmental officer had made that clerical error. What he said was a gross, and indeed dishonest, statement on his part. I claim that that is a gross misrepresentation.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the Minister keeps saying that I talked up the Rundle shares. History will show that in the months of my Ministry the price of Rundle shares fell steadily, through none of my choosing, and that because of information I discovered after going to Rundle I had subsequent consultations with the then Treasurer. The Treasurer and I had discussions with Esso and the Rundle partners . As a result of that we arranged that a picture be released to the public different from what the public had understood, with the effect that by our actions, however peradventure, the shares fell again. So they are two completely false statements and they ought to be put to rest.
In accordance with standing order 363 I ask that the Minister table the document entitled 'Perspective on Australia's Water Resources to the Year 2000', from which he quoted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Standing order 363 states:

INTERJECT.PARA: A Document relating to public affairs quoted from by a Minister of the Crown, unless stated to be of a confidential nature, or such as should more properly be obtained by Address, may be called for and made a public Document.
Senator Walsh, Senator Sir John Carrick has asked under standing order 363 that the document from which you quoted be tabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under open government, of course we will get it.

—Honourable senators will get it as a parliamentary paper. They would have had it as a parliamentary paper last month if the Government Printer' s schedule had not been delayed. I have no objection to tabling it. However, I think it would be rather foolish if the printing resources of the Senate were needlessly overtaxed by hundreds of people asking for a copy of the document that has been tabled. Alternatively, I am willing to table it if the honourable senator wants me to because I do not regard the document as confidential. If it satisfies Senator Sir John Carrick I will supply the Opposition with a copy. Alternatively, I will table it.

—I take a point of order. It surely is quite improper for a Minister to quote from a document that is not yet the property of the Senate and to try to support his arguments from that document without being totally willing to make that document as a whole the property of the Senate. That must be an offence to the ordinary practice of the Senate. Having done it, he has committed himself to this course.
—Senator Sir John Carrick, I understand that Senator Walsh said that he was prepared to table the document. Alternatively, he made a suggestion that--
—We don't want to bargain with him. We want him to table it.

—I table the document. I might add that whether the report is subsequently presented to the Parliament is a matter, as far as I know, for my discretion. I am not obliged to present it. It is something that I intend to do, and I would have done it before had the document been available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- Senator Sir John Carrick said that a-and I stress the word 'a'-singular clerical error was made in the Press statement which accompanied the National Energy Advisory Committee report on the Rundle prospect, among other things. I do not remember the title of the report, but it was concerned with alternative sources of liquid fuel, or something like that. There were in fact in that Press statement two errors-one number was different and one description was different. I cannot quote the precise figures or words, but they were along these lines: Senator Sir John Carrick tells us that 'eight' year lead time had by clerical error become 'five' and 'possible' had become 'probable'. That may not be the precise description, but those two, shall we say, very substantial differences of emphasis which appeared in the Press statement were described by Senator Sir John Carrick as a singular clerical error.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point with regard to the Rundle shares matter is this: It is correct -and I remember this very well-that Senator Sir John Carrick, after he had been to Rundle in I think about February 1981, changed his tone in the Senate regarding Rundle shares. But in the general euphoria of the resources boom and the 1980 election stunt, the general tone of Senator Sir John Carrick's comments in the Senate about Rundle was that it was a project which was a goer. I submit that that, coming from a presumably responsible Federal Minister, must have had some influence on the share price.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My notice of motion condemns the Government for abandoning the bicentennial water resources program, which, had it been allowed to continue, would have effectively addressed two significant water resource problems in Western Australia. It is a matter of regret to all Australians, and particularly to those people in the goldfields region and the south-west farming district of Western Australia, who would have been amongst the first beneficiaries of the scheme, that the Government has adopted this attitude. Those people are aware that this Government already has a record of broken promises unparalleled in Australian history, but that amongst the very few election commitments it has kept is the destruction of a scheme that would have brought immense benefit to people in the rural and isolated regions of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party has always been the anti-rural party, and its record so far seems to confirm that view.
