The destruction of the bicentennial water resources program, which was an imaginative and carefully planned attempt to address one of Australia's most pressing problems, is yet another reminder that people outside Labor's main electoral base in the main urban centres can expect no understanding and no assistance from this Government. It contrasts starkly with the sympathetic and meaningful policies which were pursued by the previous Government to help develop those areas outside the major cities which contribute more than half Australia's export income in the agricultural and mining industries.

Australia is one of the driest continents on earth, and its development has been largely related to the availability of water. As the population grew and those areas which were served by natural water sources became populated and developed, Australians developed imaginative projects to extend the irrigated areas available to them. The Snowy Mountains scheme and the Ord River irrigation project are two significant examples of this imagination translated into projects which will have a lasting benefit for the regions they serve. Coalition governments have always been at the forefront of these developments. They have been conscious of the problems brought about by drought or simply by lack of guaranteed annual rainfall. They have responded to that challenge.

In November 1977 the Fraser Government established the national water resources program to provide funds to the States for water related purposes. Between 1978- 79 and 1982-83, a total of $147.8m was disbursed to the States in this way. The then Government recognised not only that water supplies are crucial to regional development but also that the constitutional responsibility for such works lies with the States. The Australian bicentennial water resources program would have supplemented these grants and loan guarantees which had been available to the States for the past five years. Recognising that the States have the constitutional responsibility in this area, the former Prime Minister and the former Minister for National Development and Energy worked closely with the relevant State Ministers in identifying areas of greatest need in each State. Over the next five years those areas identified in the original program outline, and others which it was felt were in need of attention, would have received the benefit of a $640m fund which the Federal Government had established for that purpose.

The fund was in two forms-an extension of the national water resources program for another four years, committing a total of $210m, and $70m a year for five years from the bicentennial fund. That was an iron-clad commitment from the former Government to provide a total of $640m by 1988 for that purpose.

In my State of Western Australia two immediate areas were to receive attention. The first was the south-west, which supports a wide variety of primary industries and which, unlike most other parts of Western Australia, receives good annual rainfall. The problem in that region is largely one of soil and water salinity, which to some extent is a product of injudicious cutting of trees in the area and to some extent the result of the heavy primary activity in the region. Last year, for example, as part of the national water resources program a sum of $2m was allocated to fund work to control dry land salinity in the Wellington Dam area. Two projects to be funded by the bicentennial program were announced last January to address the same problems-a four-year program to provide good quality water to dilute salinity in supplies currently available from the Wellington Dam by upgrading the Harris Dam and a five-year work program on the Harvey Dam to augment water supplies to the Harvey irrigation area, which is an important vegetable growing area of the State.

The significance of these projects can be illustrated by the fact that several years ago part of the town of Harvey had to be evacuated through fears about the structural safety of the Harvey Dam. While that situation was addressed by prompt action from the State Government, it underlines the fact that further work is necessary in the area. Because of the nature of the primary industries in the area, expecially in the vegetable and fruit growing and dairying industries, much more work will be required to ensure a continuity of supply of these products to Western Australia. As I have said, the area is generally well served by rainfall, though that is not to say that some difficulties have not been encountered, particularly in dry years. As a result of continuing consultations with the previous State Government, the previous Federal Government had planned to assist in reducing the likely future impact of those difficulties through the existing mechanisms that had been in place since November 1977 and by the additional funds that would have been made available from the bicentennial water resources project.

The other water scheme that would have benefited from the Federal funds was the Goldfields pipeline. Some of the original installations for that pipeline, which extends nearly 550 kilometres from the Mundaring Weir to Kalgoorlie, are uneconomic and in need of replacement. Regular upgrading of the pipeline has been going on for many years, but the allocation from the bicentennial fund would have expedited that work and enabled its completion by Australia's bicentennial year, 1988. It would have been particularly appropriate for this project to have been completed then because, as most honourable senators would no doubt be aware, the Goldfields water scheme was and remains one of Australia' s most ambitious engineering projects. In the 1890s, when the original scheme was completed, it cost the then astronomical figure of #2.5m. There were many critics who said that the goldfields of the Coolgardie-Kalgoorlie region would be short-lived like similar goldfields in the eastern States which had been worked out and then abandoned. As history has since demonstrated, these predictions vastly underestimated the huge reserves and the durability of the Eastern Goldfields. In fact, although the industry has gone through several peaks and troughs, gold mining in the Eastern Goldfields is on the verge of a new revival.

There are two projects in the Kalgoorlie region of which I am aware which are each seeking to produce in the order of one million tonnes of ore a year and, depending on the nature of the ore, they will each require in the order of 2.8 million to 4 million litres of water a day for processing. North Kalgurlie Mines Ltd has announced a $13m expansion which it hopes will increase its ore output by 30 per cent, and Western Mining Corporation Ltd has announced new work at Kambalda. Because of the small, very salty underground water reserves in the Kalgoorlie area, all the water for the present ore treatment is supplied by the pipeline, which presently has a capacity of 40 million litres a day. I understand that the Public Works Department is planning to augment that supply by 10 per cent over the next five years although, of course, as a result of the action of the present Federal Government in abandoning the bicentennial water resources program, one obvious avenue for funds has been deleted and has disappeared. Nevertheless, even the 10 per cent upgrading to an ultimate capacity of 44 million litres a day will not be sufficient for the needs of these two projects, nor for the predicted additional 500 householders who will find employment with the development of these projects. If the labour force in Kalgoorlie is increased by 500, and given the average daily consumption of water at 1,400 litres per household, another 750,000 litres a day will be required beyond that which is necessary for the treatment of ore from the new projects and the planned expansion of the existing operations.

The obvious conclusion is that the Eastern Goldfields has a very optimistic future in terms of further development of its traditional industries but much of that future hinges on the provision of suitable infrastructure, especially water . The previous Federal Government was mindful of that situation and that is why, in consultation with the previous State Government in Western Australia, the rehabilitation of the Goldfields pipeline was included in the bicentennial water resources program. Unfortunately for the people of Kalgoorlie, they have been sold out by the present State and Federal governments which have already demonstrated their complete lack of understanding of rural and isolated areas and their specific needs.

This Government has terminated a program which would have been beneficial to two separate regions of Western Australia and several other regions in other parts of Australia as well. I note that Senator Walsh said that the only project that was likely to effect rural and isolated areas was the Harding River project in the north-west of Western Australia. It makes me wonder about his knowledge of the geography in his own State. As I said, Kalgoorlie is more than 550 kilometres from Perth.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was not even interested in Kalgoorlie.
—No. He made no comment about Kalgoorlie.
—He did not even know there was an existing scheme.

—No, that is obvious otherwise he would have sought to criticise it. If it had not been for the foresight, courage, vision, imagination and the bold plans for the future as perceived by C. Y. O'Connor, that project would never have got off the ground. It is tragic to record that as a result of the sceptics like Senator Walsh who said that the project was not worth funding, was not worthy of implementation and was not worthy of expenditure ultimately C. Y. O'Connor, who was the subject of enormous pressure and depression, committed suicide. He was one of the finest engineers Australia has ever seen. Of course, his judgment, planning and implementation of the pipeline has been well vindicated. If it had not been for him the water resources in Kalgoorlie would not be as they are today.

SPEECH.PARA: It was put by Senator Walsh to Senator Sir John Carrick that it was an unnecessary expenditure. All the people of Kalgoorlie ask for is an adequate and reasonable water supply. It is not a grandiose scheme. The people of Kalgoorlie are simply asking for enough water for daily use and the provision of water for projects that are about to take place. As I said, industry in Kalgoorlie is on the verge of a new revitalisation. The area has enormous capacity to make a magnificent contribution to the economy of Western Australia and Australia and, particularly, the capacity to stimulate growth in industry in Kalgoorlie. We find that at the stroke of a pen the Federal Labor Party has slashed that program. The people of Kalgoorlie can make their own judgment about the Australian Labor Party. In my view the Government will stand utterly condemned by its action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak to my notice of motion that deplores the abandonment by the Hawke Government of the Fraser Government's $640m five- year bicentennial water resources program. In the midst of this debate we have been subjected to the rantings and ravings-we have become used to them-of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh). Of course, he raised all the usual red herrings that we have become used to, not the least of which, of course, was the financial situation that his Government--
—Do you think he has been discredited?

—He will be by the time I have finished, Senator. We had all the usual rantings and ravings about the financial situation in which the Labor Government found itself when it came into office. I must acknowledge one trait of the present Government: I refer to its deviousness. Its ability to con the people of Australia knows no end. If we had learned something from it maybe we would not be where we are now. I mention the so-called projected deficit of $9.6 billion. Never in the time I have been interested in politics have I heard discussion in February or March about a projected deficit. We have only ever heard discussions about deficits once the Budget has been brought down and the figures are on the board. That figure is then the projected deficit for that year. This Government, with all the deviousness of which it is capable, perpetrated the myth that this country was heading for a $9.6 billion deficit without giving us any firm figures whatsoever. As I pointed out to a lot of people who asked me about it, how can there be a projected deficit when there is no Budget? How can there be a projected deficit before discussion and before the Ministry has even sat down to discuss what expenditure and expected revenue will be?

SPEECH.PARA: I make this point about deficits and projected deficits. Let us go back to the discredited Whitlam Government and the Hayden Budget of 1975-76. The deficit in 1975-76 was $3,567m or 4.9 per cent of the GDP. The deficit that the Fraser Government left-in other words the deficit from the Budget of 1982-83, which we all knew would blow out and which indeed did blow out because of the drought and the many effects that drought had right through society-was $4,473m or 2.8 per cent of the GDP. These figures are taken out of his Government's Budget Paper No . 1. Indeed, this Government's projected deficit of $8.3 billion is 4.7 per cent of the GDP, something a little less than the Whitlam Government left us with in 1975-76.

Let us get this whole projected deficit in perspective. The Whitlam Government in actual fact left us a Budget deficit far worse than anything we left the Hawke Government. Yet, this Government is using this as a reason for it not being able to do many things, not the least of which is to carry on with the bicentennial water resources program. It has been said by a cynic that if Captain Cook had an economist on board the Endeavour when he sailed up the east coast of Australia, Australia would never have been settled. I take that a little further. If Captain Cook had the likes of Senator Walsh or his ilk giving advice when he sailed up the east coast of Australia, Australia would never have been settled.

It has been mentioned by Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Crichton-Browne that Australia is the most arid continent on earth. I think few people realise that we have more desert than any other continent, including Africa which has the notorious Sahara Desert. If ever a country needs to pay attention to the husbanding of its very sparse water resources, it should be Australia. We should be doing all that we can with every method at our disposal to encourage water storage and the use of that water. In this way we would provide not only for ourselves but also we would provide food for the nations that are close to us which are experiencing difficulty in feeding countless millions of people. Senator Walsh, who is the Minister for Resources and Energy and comes from the land himself, takes this stand every time the matter of water resources comes up . I put it to you, Mr Deputy President, that instead of being called the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh should be known as the Minister for famine, drought and desert because that is all that he seems to be advocating.

Let us examine the current situation. This Government blamed the Fraser Government and its Budget. Yet Senator Walsh, as the Minister for Resources and Energy, brought in a measure that sought an increase in excise on a large range of fuels. People on the land who are just trying to get over a bad drought period, have lost the benefit of sales tax exemptions. Senator Walsh is supposed to be looking after the resources of this country. He has an interest in the land himself. As a matter of fact, I would say that this Budget is like a gold lotto Budget. The Minister is responsible, as much as anybody, for the introduction of these excises. It is a gold lotto Budget in that the Government wins the lottery every six months and it is the taxpayers who are buying the tickets. This discredited Minister for Resources and Energy, or the Minister for famine, drought and desert, if one likes, is as much responsible for that as anybody else. He has said here, in defence of his position and his Government, which has taken away the bicentennial water resources program, that all the programs were new; that the Government did not take money from existing programs which were not of much use to country towns.

Let us look at the programs. I refer to the Awoonga Dam on the Boyne River. Money was allocated to go to that dam, which already exists. That project will go ahead because the State Government will put in all the money required. If Gladstone is not a developing country town, a provincial town, I do not know what is. I have taken part in debates in this chamber in which Gladstone was castigated by honourable senators opposite when they were in Opposition. Gladstone is a delightful place in which to live. Certainly it had growing pains as some of the large industries took off and it became a major coal shipping port. Because of the uninformed criticism that has taken place by members opposite, Gladstone has gained an undeserved reputation. It is a delightful town , but it certainly needs a better water supply. The Awoonga Dam was part of the bicentennial water resources program. The scheme met all the criteria which Senator Walsh laid down, yet it was one of those abandoned by this Government. Therefore, the Queensland Government has to pick up the whole tab itself.

I refer to the Dawson River Weir. I do not know how old the weir is. It is an existing scheme and, once again, meets the criteria laid down by Senator Walsh. It is an old wooden dam. Therefore, its building probably goes back quite some considerable time. The new scheme was to replace that wooden dam with a concrete structure and a far greater holding area, which would allow irrigation for all that fertile land that is around the Dawson River area and also, of course, water for the town of Theodore, which is right on the banks of the river. Theodore is a small country town. That is an existing scheme, once again a scheme which meets all the criteria laid down by Senator Walsh. There is also the Macintyre River scheme near the town of Goondiwindi.

I return to probably the main scheme, the one which has aroused such great contention. I refer to the Burdekin River scheme which I call the Australian Labor Party's 'born again Burdekin scheme'. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) went through Queensland and made a great deal about the Burdekin River. I think it is great that at long last he has found it and has found north Queensland. The Fraser Government and the Bjelke-Petersen Government came to an agreement to build the Burdekin Dam. That agreement has been given credence. I thank Senator Sir John Carrick for drawing my attention to the Hansard record of the Estimates Committee C hearing of 12 September 1983. As recorded at page 71 of Hansard, Senator Sir John Carrick asked:
At the time of the allocation of the $6.5m what was the arrangement between the Commonwealth Government of the day and the State Government in terms of the dam? Would you spell it out?
Mr Maunderson replied-and I draw attention to the reference to the previous Government:

The previous Government agreed to meet the full cost of the dam, which was estimated at about $85m in mid-1980 prices. The State was to meet the preliminary costs associated with the construction of the dam, mainly road works , then estimated at about $14m. The State Government was also to meet the costs of developing the irrigation works, which were then estimated at about $109m.

There we have it, the born again Labor Party Burdekin scheme. It was there. It was already up and running. Money had been allocated by the previous Government. The commitment was there that we would build a dam wall. I noticed, I think in one of today's Queensland newspapers, that the tenders for the construction of the dam wall have been opened. They range from somewhere in the vicinity of $50m to some $105m. The scheme is an ongoing one. As I said, I am very thankful that Mr Hawke travelled to north Queensland and found out where the Burdekin River was. But the scheme was for the axe. It was part of the bicentennial water resources program. I recall asking Senator Walsh a question before the Senate rose in early June regarding what would happen to the Burdekin Dam. At that stage he could not give me an answer. It was not until just before the Senate resumed that the announcement was made. Quite fortuitously, of course, it was made when the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, went to north Queensland. I guess that when he was up there he had to say something. He has done nothing else. He did not fulfil all his promises to the sugar industry. Indeed, I think the same $10m has been hawked around by Mr Hawke at least twice. All it is for is loans through the Rural Reconstruction Board. The Government had to do something so it literally agreed to continue a program which had been put in place by the Fraser -Anthony Government. The Labor Government has agreed to continue that program.

I turn to the Bradfield scheme and the disparaging remarks that are continually heaped upon such schemes by Senator Walsh. I am not an engineer. I have never purported to be an engineer, but I do know, as I have said, that Australia is the most arid continent on earth. It has more desert than has any other continent. Seventy per cent of the water in Australia is uncommitted. It flows mainly into the Coral Sea, the Gulf of Carpentaria and the Timor Sea; in other words, it is from the heavy rainfall belt in north Queensland. I do not think we could live with ourselves over a period, knowing the aridness of this country and with all that water going to waste, if we did not make some investigations as to how best it could be used. I think that about $5m was allocated in the bicentennial water resources program for investigation into the Bradfield scheme . Vast amounts of water are flowing out every day-let alone during the wet season-right along the north coast of Queensland and, of course, Arnhem Land, into the Gulf of Carpentaria. It will be to the ultimate detriment of this country if we do not get our act together-77 per cent of Australia's water being uncommitted-and do something about using that water. The abandonment of this program by the Labor Government happened just as Australia was coming out of one of the worst drought periods in its history. So much for its concern for rural Australia. So much for the concern of the Minister, the now discredited Minister for Resources and Energy. As I said, he should be known as the Minister for famine, drought and desert.

TALK.START.PARA: —Buffoonery.

—Buffoonery should be included in the title for his performance. He is not present in the chamber. I think that he should become known as the Minister for famine, drought and desert. If ever a country has a potential to feed the countless starving people in this world it is Australia. Yet we cannot do it. We should be ultimately condemned if we do not manage our water resources far better than we are doing now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the item which appears in the Notice Paper in my name relative to the cancellation of the bicentennial water resources program, in particular as it affects Tasmania. I move in this direction for two main reasons. Firstly, I deplore the cancellation of the program. Secondly, it does reek of very heavy-handedness as far as Tasmania is concerned, particularly as to the Craigbourne Dam proposal. I listened with great interest to what the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) had to say. I believe that all he really said was enough to make every Australian person absolutely terrified. I think that Australia can despair as far as water is concerned because very obviously the Government has no policy whatsoever. All the Minister did was stand here ranting, raving and roaring about various people and various places. He destroyed absolutely everything on a very full schedule and offered absolutely nothing in return. I do not think he made one comment that would indicate that anything was satisfactory. In other words, while ever he is the Minister all we can expect is for things to get worse and worse.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, the Minister does not want any money to be spent on these sorts of projects. He believes that it is better to spend money on the dole than on development. I think that dole or development is probably another connotation that we could add to his portfolio. He did not offer us one proposal to replace all the projects he said were wrong or the schemes that he tore down. He referred to wildcat schemes in the broad generality. He did not dare to list what he considered to be wildcat schemes. He then accused us of not concentrating on existing schemes or concentrating our attention on country towns. I would like to run briefly through the list.

In New South Wales, the Glenbawn Dam is an existing dam. We are talking about stage 2. In Victoria, Lake Merrimum is at stage 3. It is also an existing dam. Piping the Wimmera-Mallee water supply project has been in existence for years and years and years. It is an existing scheme. As Senator Collard said, in Queensland, the Awoonga Dam will service one of the biggest country towns in Australia and one of the most needy. All schemes mentioned in South Australia are existing schemes. They will bolster up the water supply, not only for Adelaide, but for the country towns in the Iron Triangle. Exactly the same applies to Western Australia. The Goldfields pipeline rehabilitation is an existing scheme for country towns. I will deal with the Craigbourne Dam in Tasmania separately. I find it quite extraordinary that Senator Walsh can get up , speak for half an hour, say absolutely nothing and be totally wrong in his facts at the same time.

I return now to the Tasmanian situation. The ups and downs through 1983 are really quite important. They began on 25 January 1983 when the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) produced a statement setting out what the program would be. This was followed on 5 February by a meeting in Sydney at which Senator Sir John Carrick and Mr Beswick agreed that the Commonwealth would fund the Craigbourne Dam to the tune of $6.5m. It was agreed and everything was finalised. It then happened that, on 21 February, the Hobart Mercury reported that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) had been to Tasmania, made an inspection of the south-east Tasmanian area and pledged Federal funding of the Coal River irrigation scheme, the Craigbourne Dam. There were no ifs or buts; he pledged Federal funding. Then , of course, the great white chief turned up on 4 March and said:
The ALP Economic package for Tasmania and encompasses such water and irrigation schemes as Warners Creek, Coal River/South-East and Cascades.

Those were the three schemes that were promised by the present Prime Minister. What happened? They have all been cancelled since then. We went from three to nothing. By 29 March, the Minister, Mr Beswick, was getting a little bit nervous because he had not had any confirmation that these promises would be kept. He sought confirmation and tried to find out what was going to happen. On 12 April, he received a letter from Senator Walsh stating that he was not prepared to confirm the commitments and that there would be a review. That was the first time that that idea had ever been mentioned.

On 19 April, the Tasmanian Minister wrote to Senator Walsh expressing his disappointment and noting the commitments that had been given by Mr Kerin and the then Prime Minister. He also noted the commitment given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) to undertake the Winnaleah project, the Cascades scheme. The saga continued on 9 May when Senator Walsh again wrote to Mr Beswick and disputed that a commitment had been made. I notice that the Government had not, at any stage, written letters to the Press stating it had been misquoted. Senator Walsh then disputed the fact that any commitment had been made. It was then up to the Premier to write to the Prime Minister, on 20 May, seeking confirmation of the commitments on the three projects. There was a meeting. On 27 May, the Prime Minister said that the national water resources program still existed and that he would have talks and include the Craigbourne Dam in it. He said also that Craigbourne Dam would not be tied to any dam compensation. Senator Walsh, besides disputing the commitments, on 9 May said that the project could be used as a bargaining counter in the lower Gordon hydro scheme. That is the way it has been going on. On 27 May 1983, Senator Walsh again wrote to Mr Beswick still disputing that there had been a commitment.

Referring again to what Senator Walsh said, I mention that he claimed that the previous Government had tried to foist the Mitchell River Dam on the Victorian Government. He said the Victorian Government did not want it; it was not one of its priorities. As far as the Craigbourne Dam is concerned, it was on the Tasmanian list of priorities; it was wanted; and it was the No. 1 project. Senator Walsh now says that he has far greater knowledge of what is best for Tasmania, what is good for Tasmania or what Tasmanians should want; and it is not the Craigbourne Dam. I have news for Senator Walsh: It is what the Tasmanians want; they will go ahead with the project. I believe that every Tasmanian will expect the Federal Government to carry out the promise that it made prior to the election and which was very much part of the campaign at that stage.

So that this chamber may know a little about the matter in hand, I wish to give some information on the Craigbourne Dam. There are three dams in the proposal but the Craigbourne Dam was included in the bicentennial water resources program . The Craigbourne Dam is designed to provide irrigation water to an area of about 35,000 acres in south-east Tasmania. It is a particularly excellent piece of soil. It is in a very favoured location, handy to transport, handy to the city of Hobart, well sheltered and an ideal area for summer cropping of specialist crops, provided there is water to get them growing. That is the crux of the matter. It is useless country until it has regular, dependable water. When this country is developed, it will be amongst the highest employing pieces of rural land anywhere in Australia. It will provide high employment and a whole range of new industries which currently do not exist. I suggest that, if Senator Walsh is concerned about the cost of the project, he should find out whether the cost of providing many of these make work schemes that seem to be fashionable around Australia at present is more or less beneficial than building a great capital work with a very long term benefit for a whole group of people.

The project will proceed, make no mistake. It has to. It is terribly important to the economy of Tasmania and its future development. As I have said before, I and the people of Tasmania, will look to this Government to proceed with what it promised. I am in no doubt that I will not have any difficulty with any of my Tasmanian colleagues on this matter because all of them will, of necessity, support a scheme which they fully understand, the value of which they appreciate and which is very much a part of the relationship that Tasmania has with the Federal Government. No part of Australia really has any greater problem with drought than this part of south-east Tasmania. Rain is not terribly dependable in this area. More often than not it has a sub-economic rainfall. The soil is good, the site is close to Hobart, it is close to transport, but it needs the water. I think very few people would appreciate that currently between one- quarter and one-third of Tasmania is still very much in the grip of a severe drought which has been going on for four years. People do not usually associate Tasmania with droughts. Drought is a fact at the moment, and unless there are extraordinary rains in the next month or so, Tasmania will be entering yet another year of continuing drought.

The cancellation of the Craigbourne Dam project and other water schemes is, regrettably, only part of what Tasmania has so far suffered at the hands of this Government. Two other water schemes were cancelled. The upgrading of the Wynyard airport was cancelled, and the Gordon below Franklin scheme was cancelled. Some 70 per cent of Tasmania's future power development potential was completely taken away by that cancellation. We have an undertaking from the Government that nobody in Tasmania will be disadvantaged as a result of the cancellation of the Gordon below Franklin scheme. We are told that other occupations will be found. We are told that tourism is to be assisted and that new industries will be fostered. I am at a loss to see how we can develop new industries and foster tourism in line with the cancellations by this Government.

I do not really think the Government can honestly say that it will foster tourism in Tasmania by cancelling the upgrading of the Wynyard airport, which is the main access to the north west, the west coast of Tasmania and that part of the State with the greatest tourist potential. I cannot see that part of helping Tasmania is to cancel what was already started, what had already been approved, by just saying: 'No, we will not go ahead with it'. How will it help Tasmania, if the Government cancels or defers irrigation schemes that prevent new agricultural industries or prevent the extension of existing industries that in themselves would have provided thousands of extra jobs in Tasmania and beyond? How does this fit in with the national policy? Then there is the Gordon below Franklin Dam. To take away 70 per cent of the remaining potential development of Tasmania's hydro power, which in turn will eliminate thousands of primary and secondary jobs for decades, is hardly backing up the statement of the Prime Minister: 'We are going to look after Tasmania'.

Tasmania is no different from the mainland States. Its entire future is tied to the use and development of its water resources. There are a considerable number of schemes, not as good as the ones put forward, but ones that will be necessary for the on-development of the State in years to come. The future of Tasmania will be far more closely tied to the further development of the schemes that we already have than to some of the high-faluting nonsense that various Ministers and people in the wild keep saying Tasmania can enter into. I would venture to suggest now that in 50 years time Tasmania will still be far more dependent on the things that it has now than on many of the potential schemes that people are still talking about. Our forestry, our fishing, our farming, our mining and our tourism will still be the industries that will be keeping Tasmania afloat at that stage. It is important that we have these fundamental resources. It is important that the Federal Government understand that every time it interferes in the projects that are going ahead in Tasmania, the things that are budgeted for, it is working strictly against plans that, in many cases, have been in the making for many years. Water, the access to it and what we will do with it will provide jobs for many people. The development of the west coast of Tasmania is very much an integral part of all this. We need the roads, we need the airport and we need the industries that follow. I see a whole range of new industries, and on-development of existing industries coming with the extension of the water resources.

The three schemes in my proposal are, firstly, the Craigbourne Dam; secondly, the Warners Creek Dam, and thirdly, the Cascade Dam. The Cascade Dam proposal in the north east of Tasmania is one that has a lot of support. It is in an area which has a good, reliable rainfall. More irrigation water will probably change that land from dairying country into cash cropping country. It is most important that that happen so that the area around Scottsdale and the factories in the town of Scottsdale can utilise the extra products that come from it. The third project, the Warners Creek Dam, is a mixed operation that will provide town water for the towns of Deloraine and Westbury and will provide irrigation water for farmers in that general vicinity. These projects are all absolutely essential as far as the future progress of Tasmania is concerned.

Tasmania does not wish to be dependent on the Commonwealth for anything. It does not wish to be told what it can and cannot do. I do not think any joy is being felt by Tasmanian people at present on being told that various jobs are appropriate and various jobs are not, as far as compensation for what the Commonwealth has done to the State this year is concerned. I believe that the Federal Government, in taking the action it did in relation to the power resources of Tasmania, put itself into a simple situation of having to compensate in the normal manner. When one is deprived of one's property or assets the normal manner of compensation is that it shall be in the currency of the realm. I find it absolutely untenable that the Commonwealth should now be saying: 'We will not pay you in money, we will pay you in kind'. It will be offering the Tasmanians beads and biscuits before we know where we are. That proposition is totally unacceptable.

In conclusion I wish to say that I support the motion of which I have given notice. I deplore the abandonment by the Hawke Government of the Fraser Government's $640m five-year bicentennial water resources program. I stress the vital importance for Australia's future of the maximum conservation of our limited water resources. I emphasise that the main projects in the program had been indicated by the States as having high priority, advanced planning and preparedness, with short lead times for commencement and relatively short construction times. The program stresses that many of the projects would create both immediacy and useful employment in the construction period and significant long term job opportunities in the new industries dependent on water. The motion focuses attention on the importance to Tasmania of the Craigbourne Dam project and rejects the Hawke Government for giving no indication that it will continue to support the existing national water resources program which is a Federal- State dollar for dollar sharing program of great significance to all Australians .
Debate (on motion by Senator Jones) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendments made by the Senate to this Bill.
Debate resumed from 14 September 1983, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Loan Bill (No. 2) of course is the traditional Bill designed to finance the deficit. It is traditional that on the discussion of the Loan Bill the deficit, its composition and the economic principles flowing from it should be commented upon. The Government, in putting together its Budget, said with great force and emphasis that it could not tolerate a deficit bigger than $8.4 billion. It invented the spurious figure of $9.6 billion, saying that that would have been outrageous and would have created great inflation and great pressure on interest rates. It said that it cut $1.8 billion out, and now has a Budget deficit of $8.4 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to show in the course of this debate just how the Australian Labor Party speaks with two voices. The thrust of this Loan Bill and the deficit is that $8. 4 billion is as far as a government can go; that governments must not increase deficits because if they do they will get higher inflation and higher interest rates. But, Mr Deputy President, the Labor Party went to the Federal elections in March with an economic policy statement given on 10 February. It was the definitive statement of the Labor Party's economic policy-a very long statement. I want to quote from it in regard to the thesis on the relationship between deficits, interest rates and inflation. The Labor Party invited the electorate to support it in government on this principle:

Another false assumption underlying the Fraser government's policies concerns the relationship between budget deficits and inflation. The conservative argument is that the budget deficits, by adding to the money supply add to inflation. It is therefore argued that to reduce inflation the deficit must be reduced.
The policy document goes on to say:

In practice, in the first few years of the Fraser government we had continuing high deficits but inflation declined. During the last two financial years the deficit has been considerably reduced, but the rate of inflation has increased.

Therefore on the basis of the Australian experience it is difficult to sustain the argument that deficits are a basic cause of inflation or that the higher the deficit the higher is inflation. Analysis of the experience of other countries confirms the remoteness of any relationship-with some countries running high deficits associated with low inflation and others having low deficits with high inflation.
That is the economic policy statement which seeks to break the link between deficits and inflation. In regard to the link between deficits and interest rates, it goes on:

Similarly the government has argued that reductions in the budget deficit are essential to keep interest rates down. However, the two financial years in which substantial reductions in the budget deficit were achieved-1980-81 and 1981-82- were the years during which interest rates rose to the highest level in Australian history! Recently interest rates have begun to fall concurrently with a substantial rise in the deficit.
The document concludes:

Furthermore, interest rates have risen faster than in most other industrial countries and are now higher than in all but a few. Many countries with much larger budget deficits as a percentage of national income have interest rates well below Australia's. The conservative assumption about the relationship of budget deficits and interest rates is clearly misleadingly simplistic.

I do not happen to agree with that, but what I want to do is show in a number of ways how, in putting together its economic thesis, the Labor Party one day speaks with a particular set of principles and within a week or two completely shatters those principles and goes the other way. It said: 'It doesn't matter how high your deficit is because it won't affect inflation and interest rates. Then the Treasurer (Mr Keating), at the National Economic Summit Conference and when bringing down his Budget, said diametrically the opposite. The Government cannot have it both ways. On 14 February, a few weeks before the election, the Labor leader, Mr Hawke, pledged that under Labor policy unemployment would be held at present levels over the next year. That level was then around 9 per cent . He went on to say:
You could expect that unemployment would be two percentage points less at the end of a full three-year term under Labor.

That was the clear statement in February. But what did we find in March and April? The Labor Party went to the National Economic Summit Conference and, in defiance of all the advice it got from industry and from outside organisations, it supported an Australian Council of Trade Unions option, option A. The National Economic Summit Conference document of April 1983 says that under option A unemployment, which in 1982-83 was 8.9 per cent, would move in the second year of the Labor Party in office, 1983-84, to 10 per cent and, in the third year, 1984-85, to 10.1 per cent. In other words, the Government itself at the Summit said that it would have higher unemployment at the end of the three years. Indeed, the Treasurer stated in the course of his address to the Summit that there would be no fall in that period.

So we have, on the one hand, a series of statements being made for election winning purposes and, on the other, those statements being completely reversed and twisted as the Government goes along. Quite clearly, what is happening now is the very reverse of Mr Hawke's promise to restrain the unemployment rate and drop it 2 per cent over the next period of years. That will not happen. Unemployment at the moment is rising. It is rising most notably in the large Labor State of New South Wales, under a State Premier who came to office on the pledge that he would create full employment. His promise was very clear. He said , only several years ago, that he would create full employment, that he could attract industries to Australia and that he had surplus electricity that was cheaper than anywhere else in the world and so he would have full employment for New South Wales. Of course, within weeks of that, electric power generation collapsed around him and he could not even supply power to his existing industries. Within months of that the industrial tariffs for electricity in that Labor governed State rose to be not only the highest in Australia but also, as consultants have indicated, some of the highest tariffs in the whole free world. This was the invitation: 'Follow Labor policies and we will survive'.

Another deception-it is inherent in this Budget and in the putting together of the deficit-is that inflation in the coming year will run at 7.5 per cent. Everybody knows that if we use the consumer price index on exactly the same basis as we have in the past, we cannot take off the 2.6 per cent but in fact 10 .1 per cent becomes the true comparison. But more than that-the Ministers are now putting up answers to this-as each day goes by and each State Budget comes down it is quite clear that the State Budgets will create an increase in inflation throughout Australia on top of the Commonwealth inflation rate of somewhere between at least one and 2 per cent. On the admission of the Ministers , it is clear that increased State charges particularly on alcohol, tobacco, fuel and so forth will make the true projected inflation figure closer to 11 or 12 per cent in the course of this year. That figure is higher than before, not lower.

It is true that whilst the inflation rate will be at that high level, a pretty poor device will be used to ensure that in the fixing of pensions and wages a CPI calculation is used which takes out the 2.6 per cent factor for private medical insurance. By using that device, the inflation rate is brought down to 7 .5 per cent. It is true, in fact, that if we pay out of our left hand pockets for private medical insurance the inflation rate is 10.1 per cent based on the CPI. If we do not do that, but pay by means of direct taxes-that is, if it is taken out of our pay before we put it in our pockets-the inflation rate drops by that 2.6 per cent. I wonder how the Government will explain this contrivance in view of the fact that what is now emerging is that every principle on which this Budget and this deficit was based is falling away.

Does the Government now say what it said in February as the basis of its economic statement? Does the Minister now say that there is no relationship between large deficits and high inflation, between large deficits and rising interest rates? That is what they said before the election without any equivocation. Do they say it now? Of course they do not. They say that we must get the deficit down. Do the Ministers now say that they must get unemployment down by 2 per cent by the end of their third year in government. Of course they do not. As soon as they got into government, they changed their tune. Their device is to say that they did not then really know the size of the Budget. But, mark you, Mr Deputy President, that excuse was completely destroyed by their economic statement. It said that it does not matter how large the deficit is; it cannot affect adversely inflation and interest rates. How the Government can reconcile those two things is a mystery to be unravelled. But the fact is that the Government built this edifice around a deficit of $8.4 billion. In so doing, it did a great many punitive things to the people of Australia.

In speaking to this Bill I want to talk about the double talk of Labor. Let me take, for example, the Labor Party's quite clear promise that there would be no capital gains tax. Yet we have the extraordinary behaviour of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) saying that he will continually advocate it. With great respect, the ethics of an honourable senator who represented to the people before the election, as did the Leader of the Government in the Senate, that there would be no capital gains tax and who now says that in spite of that promise he will do his darnedest to bring it in, must be challenged. This is, of course, a device that has been used. I refer to the device by which Ministers can say: 'Look, I am not speaking as the voice of the Government; it is my personal view'. In this case there is a massive ethical view to be considered. Of course there will be a capital gains tax.

Once the Labor Government set out on its taxation of lump sum superannuation payments and its screwing down on the assets of retired people, it had to move to wherever there was an accumulation of capital and hit it. A government cannot say simply that it will hit people on the head if they accumulate capital by receiving superannuation payments, when they can accumulate capital by fixed trusts, real estate deals and in other ways. The jackhammer will go on. In fact, the Leader of the Government in the Senate is refreshingly honest in this regard . But the same thing happens time after time. At this moment the papers are full of the fact that the Labor Party is in conflict over the uranium issue.

I will make it perfectly clear how the Government's uranium policy stands at the moment. As the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) said when asked a series of questions in Estimates Committee C, there may be assumptions by people outside but there is no reason for anyone to assume that the Government has given any undertakings at all. He said that there had been no undertakings given. Lest there be any doubt about this I will read what he said. In Estimates Committee C on 12 September on page 74 of the Hansard the following exchange is reported:

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you aware of any assurances given by the Commonwealth Government, whether through the Department of Trade or through the Prime Minister?
—I am not aware of any.

SPEECH.PARA: I pressed him on this matter as he is a Cabinet Minister and knows the decisions that are made not only with respect to his own portfolio, but with respect to others as well. I asked:
Will you indicate why the Press believes that the Prime Minister is indicating that there are assurances?
His answer was:
I cannot answer for the Press. I can only answer for the Government.

In answering for the Government, he in fact said that there were no assurances given to the people involved in the Western Mining Corporation or Roxby Downs. Here we have the most extraordinary conflict. Day by day what has been said before is turned around. Promises that something will be sacrosanct tomorrow are broken.

Thus we have the putting together of a Budget which has collapsed. It was put together on the basis, so the Government said, of an economic policy statement, a very long policy statement which I read. The policy statement said: 'Put us in . Do not worry, because we believe in expansionary policies. It is not true, however large the deficit, that that deficit will impact upon inflation or high interest rates'. Those were the words used. When the Budget came out we saw a complete reversal of those words. It is now said that we cannot have large deficits and that we have to bear down on them because they will create inflation; they will create high interest rates and will therefore harm the economy. The Labor Party said that if they were elected they would reduce unemployment. They are in for a moment and they then say: 'The policy that we have squared off with the ACTU is a policy that will, in fact, increase unemployment over the three years. But there it is. We are sorry about that'. So it goes with every policy that formed this Budget.

The ugliest deception practiced is the citing of a 7.5 per cent inflation rate. How could that be the real inflation rate? The wages accord is falling apart around the Government. It was interesting that the Government of the day did nothing and said it would do nothing to condemn the Australian Council of Trade Unions for threatening, as it did the other day, the arbitral system of this country. When the ACTU threatened the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission the greatest silence on earth fell. Yet it is the responsibility of governments to maintain morals and ethics in this regard. But for the Government threats were all right in this extraordinary situation. In point of fact, the one thing that Australia could depend upon to have worked for the present was the wages pause which was put into place by the Fraser Government and which at that point the Labor Party and the ACTU set out to destroy. The only thing that has run as an econmic policy has been the wages pause. There is talk of accords. We want to see a demonstration of them.

I now come to what I regard as the most unethical principle; that is, to construct a Budget on the thesis of a 7.5 per cent consumer price index. The Government is simply saying: 'We can get away with that because direct taxes are not in the CPI, indirect taxes are and we are taking them out'. The Government says that, knowing that under the new Medicare scheme probably 50 per cent of the people under that scheme will still be paying for bridging insurance out of their left-hand pockets. Presumably no consideration has been given to that. We have been asking: 'What is the ingredient that has been put in the CPI to allow for the raid on the people by the States? Yesterday's edition of the Age shows that tram and bus fares have gone up, that city tram rides have doubled, to 60c. For most people there is a basket of tax rises worth $203m. It states that the price of petrol is to rise by one cent a litre, cigarettes by 18c a packet and a $5 bottle of wine is to cost 50c more. Stamp duty is also up. How is it that this can be happening, that this fraud is being perpetrated on the people? Of course the CPI will go up more than 7.5 per cent. Indeed I heard a very well respected professor of economics say on Budget night that in fact the real inflation rate that the Government had set for the year would be at least 10.1 per cent-that is, 7.5 per cent plus 2.6 per cent. The professor said it would even rise to 11 per cent. Quite clearly the picture is emerging that all the framework of this Budget has crumbled around the Government. One cannot tell from day to day what is going to happen next. I understand that the Government desires Loan Bill (No. 2) 1983 to be passed tonight, and I will not impede its passage. On that basis I conclude my remarks and commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Senator Sir John Carrick has raised some questions about the consumer price index and whether the Loan Bill (No. 2) 1983 is an appropriate measure. In my view he raised some valid points, one being that direct tax increases or reductions do not affect the CPI but indirect tax increases or reductions do. Logically I think he has a point in that both changes are made in either direction by government for revenue raising or for general economic management purposes. There is a legitimate argument that it is something of an anomaly, but it is the system that has prevailed for many years. If Senator Carrick is so concerned about it I suggest that he should have taken the opportunity to change it in the seven years or so that his party was in government.

SPEECH.PARA: That matter, together with the others that he raised, are legitimate matters that could be legitimately put forward in a debate on the Loan Bill, but are really more pertinent to a general economic debate or a debate on the Budget Papers. Every second reading speech for every Loan Bill that I can remember is really only a machinery measure which all governments have employed for as long as I have been in this Parliament and even before then. I thank the Opposition for expediting the passage of this Bill. In view of the time constraints, I do not propose to speak any longer.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I present a report on proposals for variations of the plan of layout of the city of Canberra and its environs (78th series) second report. I also table extracts of minutes of items 1, 2 and 7 of the 79th series of variations. I seek leave to make a statement relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have a tabling statement and I seek leave to incorporate that part of my remarks in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
The Report I have just tabled covers four items outstanding from the 78th Series of Variations to the City Plan. These concern roadworks associated with the new Parliament House.

The previous Committee when reporting on the 78th Series of Variations late last year expressed concern that a number of substantial modifications were being presented to it as one item. Accordingly, that Committee divided the variation into 10 separate items. The Committee, in its report tabled in the Parliament on 14 October 1982, approved six items and deferred consideration of the following four items: the Commonwealth Avenue Ramp to the New House; the Kings Avenue Ramp to the new House; Kings Avenue/State Circle intersection; and Canberra Avenue/State Circle intersection. The previous Committee was concerned at the visual impact the two ramps would have.

Commonwealth Avenue is a major element of Canberra's transport system. The Variation proposes to provide access from Commonwealth Avenue to the perimeter road around the new Parliament House via a ramp within the median strip, rising from the existing road level south of the Canadian High Commission. The ramp will be 341 metres long and will form a two-5 metre lane (compared with standard 3.7 metre lanes) single carriageway, with a maximum grade of 8 per cent.
The proposal will also require the removal of five mature trees from the median of Commonwealth Avenue. The estimated cost for the Commonwealth Avenue extension at April 1983 prices is $3.6m.

At present Kings Avenue connects to Capital Circle via two ramps. The current layout is considered to be unsatisfactory as there is a high accident rate at the entry from the ramp on to Capital Circle because of lack of sufficient room for merging traffic in Capital Circle and visibility problems.

The proposed variation will delete the two existing ramps and instead provide access from Kings Avenue and State Circle to the Parliament House perimeter road . The road will be one of the primary access roads to the new building, and will directly link Parliament House to State Circle which is a major distributor road encircling the New House.

The difficulties with the ramps encountered by the Committee are primarily those associated with Commonwealth Avenue. The Kings Avenue ramp, unlike the Commonwealth one, fits into the landscape but would create symmetry problems if built without the Commonwealth ramp.

The Committee is concerned about the visual impact of the Commonwealth Avenue ramp but believes that by providing an undulating earth form on which part of the ramp sits, with plantings to further soften its appearance the ramp will not be the imposition on the landscape that it was in the form first proposed.

The Committee approves the extensions to Commonwealth and Kings Avenues, provided that the visual impact of the rising roadways is minimised. The ramps should be harmonised with their surroundings by having a contoured and undulating landform supporting the ramp, complemented by an appropriate level of plantings and concealed parapet lighting instead of overhead lighting.
The Committee approves the Kings Avenue/State Circle and Canberra Avenue/State Circle intersections.

In the first Report on the 78th Series, the previous Committee approved the Melbourne Avenue extension on the condition that a workable system be produced to deter through traffic to the south from using Melbourne Avenue. During the hearings, NCDC undertook to provide such a solution by the next Series of Variations. The Committee has still not received definite proposals on this matter from NCDC although it believes work is well advanced on the project and some public consultation has been conducted.

The Committee has received a considerable number of submissions on the resolution of these traffic problems some of which have objected to the Commonwealth and Kings Avenue Ramps. The Committee has considered these objections and notes that they essentially object to the contribution these ramps will make to through traffic along Melbourne Avenue. The Committee has taken into account these objections but believes that the traffic problems to the south have to be addressed in those areas and not by limiting access to the New House.

It is clear that the Committee will need to conduct public hearings on the proposals for minimising traffic problems to the south. However, the Committee does not wish to delay reporting on major works outstanding in this series and therefore defers reporting on traffic management to the south of the New House to a further report on the 78th Series.

TALK.START.PARA: —The thrust of this report is to deal with some of the roads associated with the development of the new Parliament House site. The proposals for variation came before the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory some time ago and we divided them up and approved most of the variations but withheld approval of four of them. They related to two sections of the road-Kings Avenue and Commonwealth Avenue, there being ramps going from each of those two roads up to the new building. At the time we were first presented with the proposals I think all of us on the Committee felt that the Commonwealth Avenue ramp in particular was an extremely ugly structure and we were not prepared to approve it in that form. The Kings Avenue ramp was less offensive in that it followed more closely the lie of the land and was not apparently as steep as the Commonwealth Avenue one. The Committee also felt that we could not have one without the other and that they were either both in or both out. Subsequently discussions have been held with the National Capital Development Commission. The proposal came back to us a short time ago sufficiently modified, I think, for the Committee to feel that the road is necessary for the Parliament House and is now in a more satisfactory state. It is still as steep as it was originally but it will be built up and have more earth underneath it so that it will not appear to be as steep and, we hope, as much of a ramp as it did previously.

SPEECH.PARA: The NCDC has also said that there may be landscaping of an undulating nature on each side of the ramp so that the height of it will be somewhat disguised, that there can be plantings of trees and shrubs on those areas and that the whole effect will be less ugly than we thought it would be when it was first presented to us. The architect gave evidence to us. The plans of the whole building including the two roads led all of us I think to agree that this work was necessary. But many of us were concerned about the view from Commonwealth Avenue . Senator Georges, with whom I spoke earlier today, was a member of the Committee at the time as was Senator Colston who may speak on this matter later tonight. I know that I speak for Senator Georges-he said that I could-when I say that he had very firm views about the ugliness of the plan as it was originally presented. I think the Committee has justified the position that it took. The proposed plan will work out to be better than the original one. We have also suggested that lighting should be on the sides of the ramp, that is, on parapets . It should not be overhead lighting.

Another aspect of the variations in regard to the roads around Parliament House was important to the Committee. This related to Melbourne Avenue. We approved the changes to the exit of Melbourne Avenue onto State Circle, but we were very conscious of the representations that we had from many citizens of Melbourne Avenue about their worries about what this change would in fact mean to the use of that avenue. There is some risk that Melbourne Avenue and the new Commonwealth Avenue ramp will be used as a speedway to get from Melbourne Avenue down to Commonwealth Avenue by travelling around Parliament Road which is a new road around the site. Such a possibility is not satisfactory. But the NCDC said that there are ways in which it can avert that happening. I hope that the Commission does not mean that speed humps will be constructed because speed humps around the Parliament building would not be particularly satisfactory. There are options. Melbourne Avenue should perhaps be designed in such a way that vehicles turning in and out can do so only by making a left hand turn.

The NCDC also has undertaken to survey the area surrounding Melbourne Avenue and to bring the matter back to us in due course. In particular it is to look at the problems at the other end of Melbourne Avenue where there is a large school and several adjoining roads. It is important to consider the flow of traffic through Deakin and Forrest as they adjoin Melbourne Avenue and the impact of the traffic of both of these areas in relation to Parliament House. The changes that will occur will have an important effect on these two residential suburbs. The NCDC has put out three proposals. From the representations that I have received so far, it would seem that none is popular with the residents of the area. So, a great deal in the way of more work and discussion is still to take place before the matter can be finally resolved. The Committee looks forward to these matters being put before it again because it is very aware of the significance of the changes that may need to be made to ensure that any problems are resolved satisfactorily and a hopeless traffic situation is not created.

That brings me to the role of the Parliamentary Joint Committee as far as these road variations are concerned. The NCDC report of the Committee of Review of the Role and Functions of the National Capital Development Commission, which the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) finally made public yesterday says several things about the role of the Joint Committee. Recommendation 4 is:

The Committee supports the view that the role of the Joint Parliamentary Committee should be wider, and accordingly the Committee recommends that NCDC policy plans should be referred to the Joint Parliamentary Committee for comment .
The Committee of Review also recommends that:
. . . changes in the gazetted plan should no longer be referred to the Joint Parliamentary Committee.

An earlier recommendation comments that the role of the Committee is a valuable one and should be continued. The fact is that at present it is only through changes to the gazetted plan that the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory can in fact have any real influence on the changes that take place and have any real influence on the policy decisions. In this case-and as Senator Colston would know we have done this in other cases-we have deferred approval so that we can find out more about what the plans really are about and their impact. If consideration of changes to the gazetted plan is withdrawn from the role of the Committee, that right to exercise some veto role will be withdrawn completely.

Even though the Committee of Review said that the role of the Joint Parliamentary Committee is a valuable one and even though it says that NCDC policy plans should be referred to us for comment, I do not really believe that has any significance whatsoever. If the recommendation is agreed to, the Joint Parliamentary Committee would merely become another group which makes comments to the NCDC on plans that it puts forward. We would be no more than one of many making comments to the Commission. We may or may not be taken notice of. I think that, if the Committee of Review is serious when it says that we play a valuable role and that that role should be wider, some real significance has to be given to that recommendation. The only way we can have any influence at the moment is to make changes to the gazetted plans in terms of proposed variations. I think the Parliament needs to think seriously, in the light of this report, as to what the future role of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory should be. These recommendations I think seriously erode the Parliamentary Committee's status even though in fact the Committee of Review says that what it was trying to do was to widen the Parliamentary Committee's role. The current report approves the remaining roads that are relevant to the construction of the new Parliament House. We are still awaiting the review and the continuation of discussions as far as the impact of this work on Melbourne Avenue is concerned. That is something that the Committee will be pursuing and taking up later in the year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the third report of the Publications Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 September 1983, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Senate take note of the papers and the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence by asking the Government what is happening as far as the international hotel and convention centre, known as the White Industries Ltd development, is concerned. This question is very relevant to the Budget. The Budget stresses the importance of jobs and I will refer to that subject in more detail subsequently. The Budget provides a substantial increase in funds to the Australian Tourist Commission because of recognition of the importance of tourism to Australia. The White Industries Ltd development is particularly important for tourism in that it will consist of an international hotel and convention centre. It is important also because it will provide a significant number of jobs. I understand that about 600 jobs will be provided at the construction stage. Once the hotel is completed and operating, another 1,200 jobs are likely to be provided. The project was approved. Many people in the community support it and are anxious to see it go ahead. But in the five months that this Government has been in office, we do not seem to have heard much about what is happening in regard to this important development. I think we are entitled to know. I think the private sector is entitled to know because it wants to get on with the job. The relevant roads and other adjustments that need to be made to the area have been approved. So the question really is: Why has the Government held up the project for five months? Why cannot it proceed immediately? What in fact is going on? I think it would cause considerable lack of confidence in the private sector in Canberra if it were to be abandoned.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another aspect of the White Industries project which is significant. Honourable senators may remember that only a week or so ago, when I asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) a question about opening offices of his Department in Canberra, he explained that the reason for the delay was the lack of office space in Canberra at present. He now says that he has found some suitable place in one of the older buildings. The fact is that offices are not being constructed at present in the Australian Capital Territory . This project will have office space in it. It is time that a decision were made. I cannot imagine what the hold-up is, and I ask that priority be given to resolving the problem so that the project can go ahead.

As far as the Australian Capital Territory is concerned, the Federal Budget is far more than just the Federal Budget; it needs to be analysed from several points of view. It is a State Budget and a municipal Budget on the same night as the Federal Budget, and all three of these are important to the community. From whichever point of view one begins to examine the Budget, jobs are the centre of the interest of most people and are the dominating considerations. In the Budget , the Treasurer (Mr Keating) referred to employment and said:
Today's unemployed are victims of events beyond their individual control.
It is unconscionable that they also be made victims of government indifference.
He went on:
Later in my Speech I will announce substantial increases in benefits to the unemployed.
The Community Employment Program also makes its contribution in this area.
It is directed at the longer term unemployed who, because of their lack of recent work experience, are particularly disadvantaged in job-seeking.

Those proposals are very significant for the unemployed. The real gap in the Treasurer's Budget Speech is that it fails to show any concern for real jobs and real career prospects. Many people who voted Labor on 5 March are now very disillusioned indeed that there have been no real prospects of jobs and no real prospects of careers. I quote from an article in the Canberra Times of 7 August. It is headed 'Unemployed: by an angry young man'. The man is identified as Larry Anderson. He states:
I have been unemployed since January, I am 27, and have been feeling trapped and angry.

I have checked the noticeboards of the Commonwealth Employment Service daily, five days a week, and checked the notices at the Australian National University daily for casual work, and earnestly want to work.
Later in the article he states:

People have been tolerant of the Hawke Government, giving it time to fight the problem. The election result brought me some hope but when confronted with the problem as an individual, I became less tolerant, less sympathetic, whether it is a Labor or Liberal Government.

There does not seem to be any end in sight. If there was a glimmer of hope that things were getting better it would act as some kind of encouragement, but there are no real guarantees or assurances that the position is going to improve in the near future. They are not coming through and there is a limit to anyone's patience.

There is more to the article than that, but I think that indicates the despair and frustration of those in this community who really want jobs. They voted Labor in the hope of a better scene as far as jobs are concerned, but it just has not happened.

To get back to the Budget as far as it affects Canberra, we saw the heading in the Canberra Times the following morning which referred to the Press release of the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren). The heading was: ' Canberra does well in Budget: Uren'. The allocation was said to be up by 19 per cent, but what are the realities? Those are the sorts of figures that headlines are made of. As far as the Department of Territories and Local Government was concerned, the actual increase was $8.6m, which was in fact an increase of only 6.2 per cent. The Treasurer made it plain in his Budget Speech that inflation had been 11.5 per cent. As far as all those areas that relate to the Department of Territories and Local Government are concerned, it was not an increase but a decrease. The actual increase for the National Capital Development Commission of $13.5m or a 10.96 per cent increase is less, but only slightly less, than the Budget Speech figure of 11.5 per cent for inflation.

The big increase related to the construction of the new Parliament House, which was a 58 per cent increase on last year's figure. That figure represented the natural progress of the building, to be completed by 1988, and the amounts needed during this financial year to maintain the program. I am not for a minute suggesting that there are not some benefits to the Australian Capital Territory in terms of jobs on that site, but not all of the money is spent here or is relevant to the local community. It is quite wrong to include those national projects as if they were local projects. It is a distortion of the figures on the part of the Minister for Territories and Local Government when he makes it look as though the people of the Australian Capital Territory are being pampered by a Budget increase of 19 per cent, greatly in excess of the inflation rate. Enough people in this country already do not understand the financial arrangements in the Australian Capital Territory without the Minister using the Budget figures to put the position in that light.

For the Department of Territories and Local Government, the Budget is in real terms a decrease. There are many areas where last year's figures, as adjusted, have not kept up with inflation, and in many areas there has been an actual decrease. The municipal services-services for parks, gardens, recreation areas and the Tourist Bureau; I will come back to that later-have the same amount as last year. There is a cut in the amount for bush fire control, which I hope is a reasonable judgment. There are cuts in many other areas. At the same time, there has been an increase in motor vehicle registration charges, making our rates one of the highest rates in Australia. There has been an increase in motor vehicle licence fees, an increase in rates, an increase in sewerage rates and a number of other lesser ones. The day after the Budget, rent for government houses went up. People in the Australian Capital Territory are paying more and getting less in the area covered by the Department of Territories and Local Government. This fact should be known.

In one particular area I was disappointed that the Minister did not see his way clear to include some funding. It related to disabled people and the use of multi-cab-a taxi service to enable severely handicapped people to get around. In this regard there was a demonstration outside Parliament House not long ago. The amount sought was not a large amount, and it was a pity that it was not included . It is a service effectively provided by our local taxi firm at present, which is bearing the financial burden of it. It seems to me that this was an area where the Minister could have allocated some of his resources.
Debate interrupted.
