DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Pilbara Iron Ore Industry: Industrial Situation-Asian Coalition of Human Rights Organisations

PROCTEXT.PARA: Pilbara Iron Ore Industry: Industrial Situation-Asian Coalition of Human Rights Organisations
Motion (by Senator Button) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Senate to the appalling industrial situation in the Pilbara iron ore industry in Western Australia which on two separate strike issues has virtually closed down two of the largest producers of iron ore in the region. Honourable senators may be aware of an answer to a question given by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) last week in which the Minister made several pertinent points. Firstly, he pointed out that the claim for a 36-hour week being pursued by nine unions at operations of Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd was not consistent with government policy, nor with what is necessary for economic recovery. Secondly, he added that with several long term contracts coming up for renewal next year, and with the Japanese looking to diversify their sources of supply it would assist those forthcoming negotiations if a period of industrial harmony could prevail in the region.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately for the objectives of promoting economic recovery and securing an equal or even larger share of the Japanese iron ore market, the Government has done nothing and is apparently not planning to do anything to address the situation. If a major export market is permanently impaired and jobs are lost in the Pilbara as a result, the blame will lie in equal proportions with the trade union movement and the Federal Labor Government. It is not good enough for the Federal Government, which claims to have a special relationship with the unions, to sit back and watch the drama unfold.

The Minister said in his answer that a 36-hour week is 'not in accord with government policy; indeed, nor is it in accord with the prices and incomes policy'. Yet the nine unions involved in the Hamersley Iron dispute are demanding a 36-hour week, apparently in spite of government policy and the agreement which it is supposed to have with the trade unions. It confirms what we on this side have been saying about the prices and incomes policy all along- that it is a one-sided document which commits the Government to high spending policies and programs and achieves nothing in return in terms of restraint and moderation from the trade union movement. It proves also that when the unions choose to ignore the prices and incomes accord, as by the Minister's own statement it is clear they are in this case, there is absolutely nothing which the Government can or will do to rectify the situation.

The consequences of the Government's inaction will be disastrous. On 1 September the Tex Report, the authorative organ of the Japanese steel industry, reported the Mount Newman Mining Co. Pty Ltd strike and its consequences in the following terms:
Japanese steelmakers such as Nippon Steel are now obliged to drastically change their ship assignment programs for September.

The report suggested Hamersley as an alternative supplier, though it is now history that Hamersley has also closed down its mining operation and retrenched 1,400 staff. On 5 September the Tex Report noted that Hamersley had also ceased to be an alternative, and in a note that should be a warning to the unions involved, added:
Two major ore supply sources in Western Australia have now been crippled. Japanese parties concerned are now reminded of the problemed instability of Australia as a supply source.

It is astounding that while these strikes were going on, a seven-member delegation of Japanese steelmakers visited the Pilbara to be greeted by what one newspaper described as a 'study in still life'. Although the unions involved would have clearly understood the significance of the visit at a time prior to new contract negotiations, those same unions did nothing to improve the image of the region as a future reliable supplier of iron ore to the Japanese. It is hardly surprisingly that when Mr Saito, a Vice-President of the Nippon Steel Corporation and the head of the mission, gave an interview to the Press, he had this to say:

. . . what Japan is now expecting from Australia is the stability of supply and the maintenance of international competitive price, which are indispensable for long maintaining friendly trade relations with the same share of trade as in the past.

There are several crucial aspects to Mr Saito's comments: reliability of supply, competitive price and, as a result of these factors, the maintenance of Australia's share of the Japanese iron ore market. Reliability of supply has been a source of constant warnings from Japanese steelmakers. In 1975 Australia supplied 47 per cent of iron ore to Japan, and the two largest Pilbara miners, Mount Newman and Hamersley, were the two most significant suppliers. By 1980 Australia's share had fallen to 44.5 per cent, while in the same period Brazil had moved from 17.6 per cent of the market to 21.2 per cent. In this fiscal year , Hamersley is again expected to be the largest single supplier of ore to Japan, but now the Brazilian producer Companhia Vale Do Rio Cohe is the second most important supplier. Slowly but surely Australia is losing its pre-eminent position as an iron ore supplier, and that is largely related to reliability of supply.

The Japanese are being inconvenienced by these latest strikes. The Japan Echo of 10 September reported that ships which had been scheduled to carry Australian iron ore to Japan were being dispatched to India and other supply sources.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a Japanese echo in here.

—The Minister should take careful note because it will effect his Government and my economy. The Japan Echo reported that congestion was already a problem at Indian ports. The Japanese steelmakers are hard-headed businessmen who will not tolerate these inconveniencies, especially when, in Hamersley's case at least, the Federal Government is prepared to sit idly by while the unions act in direct contradiction not only to government policy but also to a so-called agreement they are supposed to have with the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has advantages over other suppliers in terms of transport costs which , but for the industrial relations problems which plague the Pilbara, should enable us to sew up the Japanese iron ore market. The freight cost per tonne of Australian ore to Japan is $7 compared to $10.50 from Brazil and $11 from South Africa. The South African costs are higher largely as a result of the smaller ships used for that trade, but the Brazilian and Australian ships are largely comparable in size. In other words, ships from both countries can maintain a high volume steady supply. Ore costs in both countries are comparable, so to date our advantage has been in the freight costs alone. However, if the economics of the Pilbara industry are affected to the point where Pilbara iron ore becomes more expensive, the freight advantage will be eroded. Of course, that impinges on Mr Saito's second criterion of competitive price.

If Australian trade unions create a situation in which, after freight costs are taken into account, Australian ore costs are the same as Brazilian ore costs, the Japanese will naturally go to the supplier which is most reliable. That supplier will naturally be Brazil, because of the record of industrial problems in the Pilbara, which, as I said at the outset, has been appalling. In the period 1973-75, the average number of working days lost per employee in the non- coal mining industry, of which the iron ore industry is by far the largest component, was 3.22 days. In the following three-year period-that is, from 1976 to 1978-3.71 days per employee were lost, and in the period 1979 to 1981 that had jumped to 4.88 days per employee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame, Fraser, shame!

—It had nothing to do with Fraser. In both 1979 and 1981 more days were lost per employee in the non-coal mining sector than in any other industry in Australia, and in 1980 the record was exceeded by the coal industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Mining generally in Australia has been plagued by problems, not because of poor conditions or low pay but because of a preconceived notion by unions that this is an industry which is a bottomless pit in respect of wage demands and reduced hours. The number of disputes in mining, especially in the non-coal sector, has been steadily rising over the past 10 years. In 1973 there were 132 strikes in that sector and in 1981, the last year for which full statistics have been published, the number was 331. Those figures are not selectively chosen. Referring again to the three 3-year periods, the annual aveage number of strikes between 1973 and 1975 was 166, between 1976 and 1978 it was 212, and between 1979 and 1981 it was 296. Again, in my view, that illustrates that in terms of the number of strikes the situation in the non-coal sector is worsening. Incidentally, the situation is paralleled now in the coal mining industry as well.

Mr President, the Japanese are aware of that situation and have frequently expressed concern at the problems which are being caused to their domestic industries. They will naturally seek to diversify their supplies to ensure that the effects are minimised. That is why this Government must act, not only to assure the Japanese of its good intentions but also to genuinely address the problem of Australia's worsening reputation as a reliable trading partner.

I call on the Government and the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, to reply, not with empty words in this chamber, but with positive actions to prove to all parties that this agreement with the unions is more than a one-sided surrender to union militancy which, so far at least, it appears to be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will detain the Senate for only a few minutes. I want to draw to the attention of the Senate and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), through the Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Senator Button) who is present in the chamber, the first meeting of the Asian Coalition of Human Rights Organisations which was held on the second and third of this month in Manila. The Coalition comprises 34 non-governmental human rights organisations from 12 countries in the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific region. Its history is worth noting briefly. In July 1982, the United Nations sponsored and promoted a Seminar on National, Local and Regional arrangements for the promotion of Human Rights in the Asian Region which was held in Colombo, Sri Lanka. At that seminar a number of resolutions were passed. Rather than delay the Senate, although the list of resolutions is not particularly long, I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The list read as follows-
U.N. Seminar on National, Local and Regional arrangements for the promotion and protection of Human Rights in the Asian Region
Conclusions and Recommendations 1. At its 14th meeting on 1 July 1982, the seminar adopted by consensus the following recommendations and conclusions.

International Human Rights Instruments 2. The seminar recommends that urgent attention should be given to encouraging States Members of the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (ESCAP) which have not yet done so to ratify the basic international treaties on human rights, particularly the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the International Covention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination, the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide and the Convention relating to the Status of Refugees of 28 July 1951, and the Protocol relating to the Status of Refugees of 31 January 1967.

3. The seminar recommends that the United Nations, as well as other organizations such as the Asian-African Legal Consultative Committee, should consider ways and means by which they can assist governments within the Asian and Pacific region, at their request, in the preparation of legislation designed to bring international instruments on human rights into force within their respective countries, as well as for giving effect to such instruments, the ESCAP should also contribute to these ends as appropriate.

Promotion of education and training 4. The seminar recommends that the United Nations, including the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific ( ESCAP) be requested to contribute to the promotion and realization of human rights through, inter alia, the carrying out of studies and research, the organization of seminars, symposia and conferences and the dissemination of information on human rights. This seminar welcomes UNESCO's plan for the development of teaching of human rights approved by the Executive Board at its 108th session and by the 21st General Conference and looks forward to its implementation in the Asian and Pacific region.

5. The seminar recommends that a programme for teaching, seminars, training and education in the field of human rights be developed for the Asian and Pacific region and expresses the view that the United Nations as well as UNESCO could play an important role in this. Non-governmental organizations could also cooperate and contribute actively in this programme.

6. The seminar recommends that within the context of the world-wide programme of action for the dissemination of basic international instruments on human rights currently under way in the United Nations, particular attention be given to the needs of the Asian and Pacific region and to the need for the translation and dissemination of these instruments in the various languages of the region. The seminar urges UNESCO, ESCAP and the United Nations Information Centres in the region be requested to pay special attention to the dissemination of information on human rights within the region and to develop and maintain collections and/or ''depository centres'' of United Nations documents and materials relating to human rights.

Research and Study 7. The seminar recommends that a study be undertaken on the integration of human rights in the development process of the region as soon as possible with the participation of ESCAP as appropriate.

8. The seminar recommends that the United Nations University be requested to undertake a study of areas in which regional standards on human rights may be needed in the region in order to supplement the universal standards of human rights already proclaimed in the United Nations system.
9. The seminar recommends that the ILO be requested to undertake a study of needs in the promotion and protection of labour rights in the region.
10. The seminar recommends that UNITAR be requested to undertake a study on the development of regional organizations in the area.

Meetings of Government Representatives and Experts 11. The seminar recommends that steps be initiated to hold periodic meetings of government representatives and/or recognized experts designated by States of the region or sub-regions with a view to establishing regular exchanges of experience and information and to compare national legislation and practices on human rights.

12. The seminar suggests that periodic meetings of representatives of national institutions in the field of human rights within the region should be organized at the regional or sub-regional level so as to enable these persons to exchange their experiences.

Non-governmental organizations 13. The seminar recommends that the non- governmental organizations develop co-operative activities in the region with a view, inter alia, to enhancing the dissemination of information on human rights in the region.

Other conclusions and recommendations 14. The seminar expresses its deep appreciation to the Government and people of Sri Lanka for the excellent arrangements and facilities provided for the seminar as well as for the hospitality extended to participants and observiers at the seminar.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to one resolution that the non-governmental organisations develop co-operative activities in the region with a view to enhancing dissemination of information on human rights in the region, Lawasia's Standing Committee on Human Rights invited approximately 200 national, local and international NGOs to meet with it in New Delhi in October last year to discuss the establishment of a regional co-ordinating NGO. As Senator Button would know, but some honourable senators may not, Lawasia was founded in 1966. It is an association of lawyers from Asia and the Pacific. It is the only regional organisation of its kind. The number of lawyers who are, individually or through association, members of it can now be measured in thousands. Pursuant to the association's recognition of the role that law and lawyers should play in furthering the interests, both economic and personal, of the communities which they serve, in 1979 it decided to form a permanent Standing Committee on Human Rights. I think that the Committee's objectives are also worth recording in Hansard. I seek leave to incorporate those objectives.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The objectives read as follows-

(i) to work towards the establishment of a Centre or Centres for Human Rights in the LAWASIA Region, the principal function of such centre or centres being the promotion, propagation and protection of Human Rights in the region, by research, education, the use of mass-media and the publication of literature concerning Human Rights, and by other means.
(ii) to initiate as a matter of priority steps towards the ultimate establishment of an Asian Commission and/or a Court for Human Rights in the LAWASIA region.
(iii) to take steps towards the implementation of the principles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights in specific form within the LAWASIA region .
(iv) to promote by education and publicity awareness of Human Rights among the members of LAWASIA.
(v) to prepare and publish reports on matters affecting Human Rights within the LAWASIA region.

(vi) to urge the ratification of the International Covenants relating to Human Rights by Governments within the LAWASIA region, and to work towards adherence to other UN instruments in the field of Human Rights, including those concerning law enforcement and refugees.
(vii) to safeguard the independence and freedom of judges and lawyers in the discharge of their duties in matters concerning Human Rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be said that this Standing Committee was formed out of the acceptance, in terms of the preamble to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, that the inherent dignity and equal and inalienable right of all members of the human family is 'the foundation of freedom and justice and peace in the world'. There was also a recognition that such a situation by no means had been achieved in the Lawasia region. The meeting was held in New Delhi. It unanimously resolved to establish a Coalition of Human Rights Organisations which would be active in the region and decided that the Coalition should work towards the establishment of an Asian charter of human rights and an Asian human rights commission similar to the commissions now existing in the continents of Africa, Europe and America.

SPEECH.PARA: The Lawasia Standing Committee on Human Rights, upon which a number of Australian lawyers are serving, undertook the co-ordinating role for the new Coalition and accepted the administrative role of formulating a three-year plan of co-ordinated activities for the affiliate members of the Coalition. That committee accepted, as a first activity, that two studies be prepared for the Manila conference on the subjects of, first, the adequacy of laws affecting women in the ESCAP region and how far they may be implemented and, secondly, preventive detention, law and practice in the ESCAP region. These papers, which were prepared by Mr Kapila Hingorani and Justice Rangarajan, were presented to and discussed at the Manila meeting. I intend to ensure that copies of those papers are lodged in the Parliamentary Library.
At the Manila meeting it was resolved that the structure of the Coalition should be as follows:

(1) That the Coalition take the form of an association of non-governmental organisations active in the areas of promotion and/or protection of human rights in the ESCAP area, and encourage greater participation of and membership from rural organisations in the region,
(2) That membership of the Coalition be open to all such governmental groups, whether social, legal or religious, or concerned with only one particular aspect of human rights activities,

(3) That the Coalition should set up a preparatory committee under the chairmanship of Mr Ceaser Espiritu whose task would be the drafting of its constitution and for detailing its specific objects and areas of action. The other members of the preparatory committee were to be from each of the countries in the ESCAP region,
(4) That Lawasia, through its Human Rights Standing Committee, may assist the preparatory committee in its administrative work.
Members of the Senate and the Minister no doubt will be interested to learn of the non-administrative resolutions passed at the Manila meeting which were as follows:

(a) the Coalition of Human Rights Organisations is outraged at and deplores the assassination of Senator Benigno Aquino, respected Opposition Leader in the Philippines while returning to his homeland and requires that all independent measures be taken to secure the ends of justice

(b) the Coalition of Human Rights Organisations deplores the continued imprisonment in Taiwan of Mr Yao Chia Wen and other persons imprisoned as a result of the Kaoshiung incident in 1979 and calls upon the Government of Taiwan to improve the conditions of such prisoners and to grant early parole and amnesty to such prisoners

(c) the Coalition of Human Rights Organisations condemns all forms of preventive detention in the region and decides to set up as soon as may be convenient, fact-finding missions which will visit various countries in the Lawasia region and report to the Coalition the state of the laws relating to preventive detention and the implementation of those laws in each such country

(d) the first meeting of the Asian Coalition of Human Rights Organisations, being made aware of the grave situation relating to the oppression of women in Iran and the seeming total withdrawal of human rights from them, condemns the continuous violation of women's basic human rights in that country and calls on the government of Iran to specifically: (i) stop itself, its revolutionary guards and the mobs harrassing and humiliating them
(ii) refrain from executing among others, women accused of alleged physical and anti-social activities

(iii) abolish rules, laws and procedures which may discriminate against women in any way or re-establish the equal right of employment for women and their reintroduction to judicial and teaching positions particularly
(iv) reintroduce and maintain the equal right of women to education,

and further calls upon and urges all international bodies and governments concerned in human rights to exert positive influence upon the Islamic Republic of Iran to effect and implement immediate reforms affecting human rights to its women

(f) the Coalition of Human Rights Organisations condemns the recent shooting down of a defenceless civilian aircraft even if it may have violated the airpsace of another country and calls on all responsible governments concerned to compensate adequately the relatives of the deceased passengers and crew,

(g) the Coalition of Human Rights Organisations condemns killings, savaging or summary executions of criminals and dissidents in Indonesia, Iran, Philippines, Sri Lanka and other countries in the region.

Apart from the Coalition, honourable senators will be interested to learn that Lawasia has had prepared a report on repression of lawyers and interference with their freedom of expression in Pakistan. I will ensure also that that report is lodged in the Parliamentary Library. Additionally, Lawasia has sent representatives to Sri Lanka to investigate alleged violations of human rights arising out of and in relation to the recent disturbances during which some 300 deaths occurred. I urge honourable senators also to read the Human Rights bulletin which is published from time to time by Lawasia which details changes which have occurred in the region, whether they be for better or for worse. I raise these matters in order to urge honourable senators and the Government to take an interest in and support work being done by this new Coalition and the Lawasia Standing Committee on Human Rights. There are many ways in which we can press for change that will better secure basic human rights, but to do so we need to be informed of the true and continuing position in our region. These bodies will contribute to enabling us to be better informed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank Senator Hill. I am sure the four honourable senators in the place were interested to learn what he had to say. I will certainly pass his comments on to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) as he requested. I am sure honourable senators will be very receptive to the work of the Asian Coalition of Human Rights Organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say a brief word about Senator Crichton-Browne's remarks. I will be brief because I am concerned about my own human rights; I am very hungry at the moment. The Government is aware of practically all the information of which Senator Crichton-Browne gave us the benefit in his speech. The only thing I was not aware of was that I did not appreciate how much industrial relations in this country had deteriorated under the Fraser Government. That is, no doubt, attributable to the discredited former Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Peacock, who is now the Leader of the Opposition. The consequences of the disputes in the Pilbara are very severe. The Government is aware of them. We are trying to get them fixed up. I would not want Senator Crichton-Browne to go back to Western Australia and say that he had exposed the accord and the relationship between the Government and the unions and that when he had done all this the Government had no answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am far too humble.

—There is always the temptation to do those sorts of things. I do not want Senator Crichton-Browne to fall into that error. I hope that by the time the Parliament resumes again these matters will be resolved. They are matters of serious concern to the Government and some steps have been taken in connection with them. I take issue with Senator Crichton-Browne's assumptions about all these matters. He said at one stage that the dispute in the Pilbara was the fault of the unions and the Federal Government, that unholy alliance about which he no doubt has nightmares and will continue to, because we will keep feeding those nightmares for him. We do not make the same assumptions about any industrial disputes. There are always problems in any industrial situation which are attributable to all sides and which are recognised by some of the companies involved in the Pilbara with whom I have had discussions about this issue. I will certainly draw his comments to the attention of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). But I repeat: We are aware of those difficulties and will certainly endeavour to act on them.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.53 p.m. until Tuesday, 4 October, at 2 p.m.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 May 1983 (Hansard, page 774) Senator Mason asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the following question without notice concerning part time work:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Government aware of a large and growing body of opinion in the community for a system of part time work and job sharing in appropriate circumstances for those who want it? Would the Minister agree that these measures would share available work more fairly and so reduce unemployment? Is the Government currently negotiating with the trade union movement to gain its acceptance of these principles? If not, when will the Government do so? When can we expect changes in the industrial law to provide for a fair and regulated system of part time work in which at present many young people in particular are being shamefully exploited?

I gave a partial answer at the time, and raised the matter with the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. He has provided the following additional information in response to the honourable senator's question:

The Government notes the growing interest in part time employment patterns in the Australian community. A number of recent reports have suggested that sections of the labour force would support the introduction of, and in some cases seek to participate in, voluntary permanent part time work and job sharing options. In particular, a survey of attitudes to alternative working arrangements conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in 1982 showed that 8 per cent of employees currently working 10 or more hours per week would, given the opportunity, work less hours for commensurately less pay.

Permanent part time work opportunities are increasing in State public sector employment; a permanent part time work scheme operates in the South Australian public sector, limited schemes currently exist in the New South Wales and Western Australian public service, and the introduction of permanent part time schemes is being considered by the Northern Territory and Tasmanian governments.

The introduction of more flexible methods of work organisation into Australian Government employment is part of ALP policy and will be examined in the context of implementation of that policy. However, discussions with all relevant parties on the various issues involved will be required before initiatives are introduced.

There is little doubt that greater sharing of employment opportunities through job splitting, greater facilitation of part time work, and other measures, could expand the number of people engaged in employment. Indeed in a number of countries Government programs have been introduced to encourage the development of such alternative work arrangements. There is however some uncertainty about the long term effects of such programs and considerable discussion as to whether part time work is an acceptable alternative to full time employment.

Where fundamental alterations to working arrangements are implemented, the Government believes they should be based on negotiation and agreement between the employees, unions and employers involved, and subject to appropriate industrial regulation. In this connection it might be noted that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in a recent decision concerning an application for part time employment in the vehicle repair services and retail industry, outlined the following principles in determining whether to provide for part time employment, namely, that it must be shown to be desirable and meet the particular needs of the industry; and that it would not be detrimental to full time employment.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: South Africa: Business Code of Conduct

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 September 1983, (Hansard, page 754) Senator Missen asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, a question without notice concerning the status of investigations into the possible introduction of a code of conduct applicable to Australian business and trading interests in South Africa.

QUESTION.PARA: The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

As I mentioned in my statement of 5 June, the appropriateness of a code of conduct for the industrial practices of Australian companies operating in South Africa is under active review. The question of such a code is extremely complex and extensive investigations and consultations are required. It is hoped that the review will be completed as soon as possible.
